abstract: Legislature is manifesting a wholesome desire to meet the requirements of these "hard times" by reducing the ferry rates between New-York and Williamsburgh from three to two cents per passenger, would it not be as well for them to carry their public spirit one step further, and supervise with a view to reduction the fares charged on all the City Railroads now in operation, and on which the various companies have made enormous yearly profits, -- in some cases enabling them to double or treble their capital in the course of a very few years, while also declaring handsome annual dividends and paying, or pretending to have paid, perfectly fabulous prices for the running stock and road-bed to contractors having relations of friendly acquaintance with the directors?

abstract: Quite a scene transpired at the President's house yesterday. On Friday Senator BAKER, of Oregon, presented to the President ten or eleven men as representative Californians, who, after he retired, recommended Senator BAKER to the Executive as a proper arbiter of the California appointments. The President then invited "all" Californians to call on him yesterday morning.

abstract: The startling intelligence which we published on Friday from our Paris correspondent in regard to the preparations being made by European Powers to send out a fleet of war steamers "for observation" on our coasts, and perhaps, in certain contingencies, to take a hand in our intersectional quarrel, -- confirmed, too, as it was in at least one important particular on Saturday, by the news of the seizure of Dominica, by a Spanish naval and military force, and the probable speedy reduction of the whole Island of Hayti to Spanish domination, -- marks by far the most portentous consequence of our Great Conspiracy. It is, however, but what our most sagacious statesmen long ago forewarned us would be the inevitable corollary of domestic rupture, and what, in such event, the prophetic WASHINGTON predicted three quarters of a century ago. Europe and its Governments have been transformed wonderfully since his time, it is true, and so also have the power and position of America; but the traditional ambitions of Governments seldom die out, and the aggressive lust of despotism is as enduring as despotism itself.
lead_paragraph: The startling intelligence which we published on Friday from our Paris correspondent in regard to the preparations being made by European Powers to send out a fleet of war steamers "for observation" on our coasts, and perhaps, in certain contingencies, to take a hand in our intersectional quarrel, -- confirmed, too, as it was in at least one important particular on Saturday, by the news of the seizure of Dominica, by a Spanish naval and military force, and the probable speedy reduction of the whole Island of Hayti to Spanish domination, -- marks by far the most portentous consequence of our Great Conspiracy. It is, however, but what our most sagacious statesmen long ago forewarned us would be the inevitable corollary of domestic rupture, and what, in such event, the prophetic WASHINGTON predicted three quarters of a century ago. Europe and its Governments have been transformed wonderfully since his time, it is true, and so also have the power and position of America; but the traditional ambitions of Governments seldom die out, and the aggressive lust of despotism is as enduring as despotism itself.

abstract: We give elsewhere in extenso the Act of the Montgomery Convention for the establishment of the free navigation of the Mississippi. This Act, which is framed in a liberal spirit, provides for the free transit of vessels and their cargoes from Port to Port, within the limits of the Confederacy, "without any duty or hindrance, except Light money, Pilotage, and other like charges." The importance of this measure will be at once perceived by all acquainted with the features of the American Trade, and who know, as we pointed out some two months since, that the grand object of the Southern States is to make the Mississippi the highway for the great Trade of the West, and so divert that Commerce from the Ports of the Atlantic to the Ports of the Gulf of Mexico.

abstract: The Associate Artists of the Italian Opera troupe have met with so much success in Boston, and have been greeted there with so liberal a spirit, that the season, instead of ending on Saturday night, as previously announced, will be continued for another week. This is Boston's gain, and our loss. We must wait until next Monday for a resumption of those meritorious entertainments which last season insured the success of an enterprise considered at the time as more than doubly hazardous. It is said that the stockholders of the Boston Theatre were so pleased with the efforts of the Associated Artists, that they agreed unanimously to let them have the theatre this present week without any consideration. The precedent is worth putting on record, even if it is not likely to be followed.
lead_paragraph: The Associate Artists of the Italian Opera troupe have met with so much success in Boston, and have been greeted there with so liberal a spirit, that the season, instead of ending on Saturday night, as previously announced, will be continued for another week. abstract: is being made to aid the Board of Governors of the State Woman's Hospital, -- which Institute is, at present, occupying temporary and very insufficient quarters at No. 83 Madison-avenue, in this City, -- by a timely and generous donation from the State Treasury, conditioned upon the raising, by the Board, of double the sum to be donated by the State, within twelve months from the date of the passage of an act for that purpose. As an evidence of the character of this Institution, it is proper to mention that the Common Council, during the administration of Mayor TIEMANN, made a free gift of an entire block of ground, comprising an area of 200 feet by 405 feet, and lying between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth streets, and Fourth and Lexington avenues, in this City, and at present valued at $160,000. The location is one of the most desirable and elevated in the City, and it is proposed to erect a Hospital building which shall cost not less than $150,000, and to accommodate at least two hundred patients.

abstract: sensation in the Cotton States has been caused by an announcement in the New-York correspondence of the Charleston Mercury that the loan of eight million dollars for which Secretary CHASE has issued proposals, is to be used for the purpose of "arming the free blacks of the North to aid insurgent negroes in the South," -- the Mercury gravely reminding us that Lord CHATHAM rebuked the Government of GEORGE III., "because it employed the scalping-knife and the tomahawk of the savage against the white men of its own race." What is to be done with a journalism that circulates, and a people who believe such monstrous inventions as this? All Northern papers contradicting these fictions are rigidly excluded from general circulation in the Confederacy; and thus the public mind of the extreme South is poisoned systematically, while rigid care is taken that no antidote of truth shall be administered.

abstract: On Saturday night, about 10 o'clock, when the Hudson River train reacaed the Chambers-street depot, an attempt was made, on the part of two thieves, who had been loitering about the premises for some hours, to carry off one of the United States mail bags, containing a large amount of moneyed correspondence.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, about 10 o'clock, when the Hudson River train reacaed the Chambers-street depot, an attempt was made, on the part of two thieves, who had been loitering about the premises for some hours, to carry off one of the United States mail bags, containing a large amount of moneyed correspondence. The mail pouches had been transferred from the car to a wagon, in which they were to be conveyed to the General Post-office, and Mr. J.A. Stephens, the mail agent, was about to whip up his horses, when he saw a man lean over the dash board and grasp the handle of one of the bags with one hand, while with the other he held fast to the iron railing of the car platform, thus expecting to retain the bag when the wagon had departed. Mr. S. quickly jumped down and pulled the robber away, first having to strike him severely with the whip in order to loosen his hold of the booty, which he did not seem at all desirous of relinquishing. Finding himself folled, the thief ran away, and a confederate who had stood ready to assist in removing the bag followed after his principal. One of the rascals -- he who had been most active in the matter -- was overtaken, however, by Officer Doran, of the Third Ward, and yesterday Justice KELLY committed him, peacing an examination before a United States Commissioner. The prisoner is a young man giving the name of Francis Henry.

abstract: Charter election takes place to-morrow. We have always insisted, and still believe, that our Municipal elections should be decided without any controlling regard to national politics. The welfare and good government of great cities like New-York and Brooklyn are matters of sufficient intrinsic interest to demand the most vigilant attention of our citizens; and they ought never to be sacrificed to a desire for partisan success.

abstract: Notwithstanding all the assertions which have been made that the Administration would follow the order for the evacuation of Fort Sumpter with a similar one for the evacuation of Fort Pickens, it seems to be now pretty well understood in Washington that no such course will be taken. On the contrary, it has been determined, according to the dispatch of our correspondent, to hold that, as well as the other forts in the Gulf now in possession of the Government, at all hazards, and the necessary orders to that effect will soon be issued. The Southern Commissioners now at Washington, after consultation, have come to the conclusion to "wait a little longer" for the course of the Administration to be decided.
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding all the assertions which have been made that the Administration would follow the order for the evacuation of Fort Sumpter with a similar one for the evacuation of Fort Pickens, it seems to be now pretty well understood in Washington that no such course will be taken. abstract: The services at Trinity Church, yesterday, were of a very elaborate and imposing character, and drew together a much larger audience than could be accommodated with sitting or even standing room within its walls. The chancel was tastefully decorated with bouquets of flowers, the chief of which, a colossal pyramid of lilies and roses towering from the baptis- mal font, attracted particular attention.

abstract: porting the seizure of a United States supply vessel off Pensacola a few days since. The seizure was at Mobile and not off Pensacola, and the sloop detained was the property of a Mobile Captain. As our correspondent reported at the time, when the order of Gen. BRAGG was issued forbidding the inhabitants of Pensacola to supply the United States fleet with provisions, this Captain volunteered to procure them from Mobile, saying that he was willing to trust the United States Government to any extent. Gen. BRAGG got wind of the movement and telegraphed to Mobile at once to have the vessel, the Isabella, seized. This was promptly done, and the Captain, whose name was JONES, was committed to prison.

abstract: A Roman Emperor inaugurated his reign by declaring that he was determined to be hated. A similar ambition may he said to possess the statesmen of Southern America, whose constant effort, it seems, is to cut themselves off from all human sympathy, to be abhorred, and to concentrate upon their faction the obloquy of the world. There is something preternaturally repulsive in the slang, the swagger, and the ruffianism of these cowbide desperadoes.

abstract: SUPPRESSION OF STREET LOAFING. Aid J.L. AYRES, assisted by four officers of the force, on Sunday afternoon, arrested James Rickman, Wm. McGinley, Wm. Willis, Charles Jobbs, Peter Waggner and James Maul, who belong to the thieving, pennypitching, corner-loafing fraternity.
lead_paragraph: SUPPRESSION OF STREET LOAFING. -- Aid J.L. AYRES, assisted by four officers of the force, on Sunday afternoon, arrested James Rickman, Wm. McGinley, Wm. Willis, Charles Jobbs, Peter Waggner and James Maul, who belong to the thieving, pennypitching, corner-loafing fraternity. These youngsters have infested the corners along Grove-street for a long time, insulting females, and showering obscene and scurrilous remarks on all passers by. They have been remarkably alert when an officer made his appearance, but by a little strategy on the part of the Aid, they found themselves in a municipal trap, and were escorted to the City Prison. Recorder TILDEN will deal with them this morning, and if the result shall be the breaking up of the heretofore disgraceful gatherings on the corners on Sunday, the officers will deserve, the cordial thanks of the community.

abstract: PRESENTATION TO COL. DURYEA, OF THE SEVENTH REGIMENT. -- Probably the most beautiful service of plate ever presented in this country is now on public exhibition for a few days, with the consent of the recipient, at Messrs. BALL, BLACK & Co.'s, the manufacturers, on the corner of Prince-street and Broadway. It has a testimonial from the officers and privates of the Seventh Regiment, to their late Colonel, DURYEA, under whose fostering care the corps had earned and received a world-wide reputation for superiority in all that pertains to an organized volunteer corps. The service was manufactured by Messrs. BALL, BLACK & Co., at a cost of $5,000, and, aside from its magnificence, it is a masterpiece of workmanship. It consists of eight pieces, a centre piece or epergne, one soup tureen, two gravy tureens, two vegetable dishes, and two meat dishes, with stands for lamps. The epergne is of circular base, about twenty inches in circumference, with three small external bases, on the summit of which are the arms of a culrassier, with flags on each side. The middle base is thirteen inches in diameter, surmounted by all the arms of modern warfare, stacked in graceful style. From the centre of this pile protrudes a cannon, in the mouth of which is a bundle of spears, with halberts. Six arms extend from above at the extremity of which are holders for glass dishes. Above these are three branches, surrounding the centre around which are wreaths, with all the arms and instruments of ancient warfare. This sustains a glass dish, eighteen inches in diameter. From the centre of the dish protrudes a small pyramid, upon the summit of which is perched an eagle, with wings spread for flight. Upon the other dishes are cannon, carriage boxes, muskets, swords, caps, and, in act, all sorts of military equipments. In addition to the above, Col. DURYEA was the recipient of a magnificent service from the merchants of New-York, upon the occasion of his resignation of the command which he had held for so many years with such distinguished honor.

abstract: On March 28, Gov. PICKENS sent in a long Message to the South Carolina State Convention, now in session. First he explains the inaction in re Fort Sumpter, the C.S.A. took from him all responsibility in the premises. The troops which the State enlisted ...
lead_paragraph: On March 28, Gov. PICKENS sent in a long Message to the South Carolina State Convention, now in session. First he explains the inaction in re Fort Sumpter, -- the C.S.A. took from him all responsibility in the premises. The troops which the State enlisted for this purpose, with the officers, are still in commission, and Gov. PICKEES urges the necessity of their being provided for by the Confederate authorities.Thus far the expenditures of the State in her new experiment have been $640,317, of which amount $195,000 was disbursed by the Ordnance Board. Since this expense was incurred for the common weal, Gov. PICKENS cherishes the belief that the C.S.A. will assume it. Some action should be taken authorizing the transfer to the new Government of the arms seized by the C.S.A. Having disposed of these practical matters, Gov. PICKENS proceeds to set forth the philosophy of the secession movement. Hitherto in the history of the world the struggle has been to secure personal rights. That has been accomplished. The United States Government was framed to secure the rights of political communities; and having failed in that object it became necessary to make a new attempt, The Governor adds:

abstract: SUPREME COURT -- CITY AND COUNTY OF NEW-YOKK. -- THE ARTISANS' BANK Plaintiff, against LOUIS HIRSHFELD and JACOB HIRSHFELD, Defendants -- Summons for a money demand on contract. -- (Com. not ser.) To the defendant above named, and each of them: You are hereby summoned and required to answer the complaint in the above entitled action, which was duly filed in the office of the Clerk of the City and County of New-York, State of New-York, on the 13th day of March 1861, and to serve a copy of your answer to the said complaint, on the subscriber at his office, No. 64 Merchants' Exchange, in the City of New-York, within twenty days after the service hereof, exclusive of the day of such service and if you fail to answer the said complaint within the time aforesaid, the plaintiffs in this action will take judgment against you for the sum of Two Thousand Dollars, with interest from the 4th day of July, 1858, on Nine Hundred and Fifty Dollars, parcel thereof; and from the 4th day of September, 1858, on Ten Hundred and Fifty Dollars, the residue thereof, besides the costs of this action. -- Dated New-York, March 13, 1861.

abstract: A disagreeable storm prevailed last night, which interfered seriously with the reception of the returns of the Connecticut election, which took place yesterday. From the brief dispatches received up to 1 o'clock this morning, however, there is little doubt that the Republicans have carried the State by an increased majority electing their State ticket and at least three out of the four Congressmen.
lead_paragraph: A disagreeable storm prevailed last night, which interfered seriously with the reception of the returns of the Connecticut election, which took place yesterday. From the brief dispatches received up to 1 o'clock this morning, however, there is little doubt that the Republicans have carried the State by an increased majority -- electing their State ticket and at least three out of the four Congressmen.

abstract: We have before us the statement of WM. H. RUSSELL, of the firm of RUSSELL, MAJORS & WADDELL, army contractors, in reference to his late dealings with the War Department, the official acceptances of Secretary FLOYD, and the abstraction of Indian Trust Bonds from the Department of the Interior. It is a statement very ingeniously drawn, very plausible in many of its appeals for sympathy instead of censure; and not the less likely to have a mitigating effect upon public judgment, because frankly confessing grave and even criminal errors at one very critical stage of these perplexed transactions.

abstract: STRIKE FOR HIGHER WAGES. The laborers employed by Messrs. BARNES Co., contractors for constructing the sewer on Debevoise and other streets in the vicinity, yesterday morning, demanded $1 per day, instead of 90 cents, as they have received during the past Winter.
lead_paragraph: STRIKE FOR HIGHER WAGES. -- The laborers employed by Messrs. BARNES Co., contractors for constructing the sewer on Debevoise and other streets in the vicinity, yesterday morning, demanded $1 per day, instead of 90 cents, as they have received during the past Winter. The foreman of the gang, Mr. STERLING, to whom they applied, told them that they must see their employers, whereupon all the men on that section picked up their tools, and proceeded to Fulton-avenue, where they were joined by another gang of men, and the two parties thus formed, proceeded to Flatbush-avenue, and attempted to compel another gang to quit work. This they declined to do, and the result was a fight, during which stones were freely used. The Police were notified, and reached the ground in season to prevent serious consequences. The ringleaders were arrested, when the balance of the strikers dispersed.

abstract: TRIAL TRIP OF THE STEAMSHIP ILLINOIS. -- The steamship Illinois made a trial trip on Saturday to test the working of DINSMORE's feathering floats, which have been attached to that vessel during the past Winter. She ran out as far as the light-ship, leaving her dock at 11 A.M. and returning at 3:30 P.M. By account kept on board, on her outward trip she made an average speed of 15 knots an hour, against a strong head wind, and 13 1/4 knots per hour on her return, against the ebbtide. Average pressure of steam cut on at hall stroke of piston, 18 pounds per square inch; vacuum in condensers, 26 inches; average revolutions of puddles, 20 per minute; highest pressure of steam, 25 pounds; greatest number of revolutions, 24 per minute; greatest speeed through water, 10 knots per hour; diameter of paddle wheels, 33 feet; paddles, 20 inches wide, 9 feet 6 inches long; immersion of paddle, 5 feet 6 inches; paddles immersed at same time, 4. The results of the trial were extremely satisfactory, showing clearly the great superiority of the feathering paddle over the fixed paddle in common use. This is the first ocean steamer which has adopted the improved paddle wheel, and it is believed that her next voyage to Southampton and Havre will fully test its entire practicability for seagoing steamers. The Illinois, throughout hull and cabins, has been refitted in the most thorough manner, with iron bulkheads water-tight. She will sail on Saturday next, April 6, for Southampton and Havre, under command of Capt. P.E. TERRY, an able and experienced seaman, long and favorably known in the European line.
lead_paragraph: TRIAL TRIP OF THE STEAMSHIP ILLINOIS. -- The steamship Illinois made a trial trip on Saturday to test the working of DINSMORE's feathering floats, which have been attached to that vessel during the past Winter. abstract: It would be difficult, without the deliberate declaration which Vice-President STEPHENS has given to the world, to believe that a national revolution could ever be conducted on the theory which he assigns as underlying secession.
lead_paragraph: It would be difficult, without the deliberate declaration which Vice-President STEPHENS has given to the world, to believe that a national revolution could ever be conducted on the theory which he assigns as underlying secession. Some noble human motive-- some yearning toward light and liberty -- has hitherto consecrated every revolution: some indeed have been steeped in splendors; while this age has been cheered and blessed with the spectacle of a spontaneous upheaval of popular life, on another Continent, which is a pure gain to progress, and claims the tears and laurels of mankind. It has been reserved for the Slave Power of America to bring into the theory of society a doctrine utterly wicked, retrograde, diabolical. As stated with applause, the other day, by Mr. STEPHENS, in the town of Atlanta, it is perhaps the most purely atrocious thing in history. It may well give us pause that in this Nineteenth of the Christian centuries, and in America of all countries in the world, a theory of the social contract such as this could be seriously promulged:

abstract: The news from Texas, which we publish this morning, indicates that Mexico is not disposed quietly to wait to be conquered by the Southern Confederacy, but is determined rather to take the initiative, and endeavor to conquer the Southern Confederacy or at any rate Texas.
lead_paragraph: The news from Texas, which we publish this morning, indicates that Mexico is not disposed quietly to wait to be conquered by the Southern Confederacy, but is determined rather to take the initiative, and endeavor to conquer the Southern Confederacy -- or at any rate Texas. It is stated that AMPUDIA, at the head of three thousand men, was marching on Brownsville, with the determination of invading the State, and that numbers were flocking to his standard. He had sent forward expresses with placards, and issued handbills, announcing that Texas rightfully belongs to Mexico, and that now, when she no longer enjoys the protection of the Federal Government, is the time to retake her. Col. FORD, the Commander of the Texas forces, was taking measures to repel the invasion, and had ordered all the heavy guns and ordnance stores to be transported from Brazos Island to the scene of the expected difficulties. The Texans are apparently doomed soon to reap the bitter fruits of their insane action.

abstract: To guard against the taking of foreign merchandise out of bond for the purposes of transportation to States which do not acknowledge the authority of the Federal Government, thus defrauding the Government of its proper revenues, the Secretary of the Treasury has issued the following order to the Collectors of Customs at the various Atlantic ports. The practice of withdrawing goods from bond in order to introduce them into Southern ports under their "more favorable" tariff dues, or without the inconvenience of paying duties at all, was getting to be quite too common to be longer tolerated. The following is a copy of the order:

abstract: Mr. MEAGHER'S LECTURE ON McMANUS. THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER speaks to-night at Irving Hall, on the life, character and fortunes of TERENCE BELLEW McMANUS, who died but a few months ago in California, McMANUS, it may be remembered, was one of the State Prisoners of '48 in Ireland, and was tried and sentenced by the same Court which condemned MEAGHER, SMITH O'BRIEN and O'DONOHUE to exile in Australia.
lead_paragraph: Mr. MEAGHER's LECTURE ON MCMANUS. -- THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER speaks to-night at Irving Hall, on the life, character and fortunes of TERENCE BELLEW McMANUS, who died but a few months ago in California, McMANUS, it may be remembered, was one of the State Prisoners of '48 in Ireland, and was tried and sentenced by the same Court which condemned MEAGHER, SMITH O'BRIEN and O'DONOHUE to exile in Australia. Previous to his participation in the abortive outbreak, Mr. MCMANUS had been one of the most wealthy and respected commission merchants in Liverpool, taking no public part in politics, and only identified with the Young Ireland movement by being a member of "Ninety-eight Club" -- the most brilliant assemblage of patriotic talent, intelligence and social rank, called into existence by the troubled state of Irish affairs. He was also participant with Mr. MEAGHER in the skirmishes had with the Constabulary at Burlagh Common and elsewhere; and the lecture to be given this evening will doubtless furnish a striking and deeply interesting account of the whole Young Ireland movement, with the romantic incidents of its earlier stages and the sad fate overtaking nearly all who were engaged in it. On such a theme, Mr. MEAGHER cannot fail to put forth the brightest and most pathetic powers of his eloquent nature.

abstract: In the Tax levy of last year there was an appropriation made of about $76,000 for grooving and roughening the Broadway pavement, in a manner that would give better foothold to the unfortunate horses condemned to travel through our chief thoroughfare.
lead_paragraph: In the Tax levy of last year there was an appropriation made of about $76,000 for grooving and roughening the Broadway pavement, in a manner that would give better foothold to the unfortunate horses condemned to travel through our chief thoroughfare. But from reasons never explained, nor likely to be, the intended contractors for the job, who had procured the insertion of the item in the Tax-levy, were not able to obtain the expected contract for doing the work. There was a hitch somewhere in the machinery; larger shares were demanded than the contractors could afford to give. And thus, with $76,000 taken out of the pockets of the people for the express purpose of having this particular thing done, the smooth-worn pavement of Broadway has been allowed to retain to this day all its horse-killing facilities.
headline: {'main': 'Grooving Broadway.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Grooving Broadway.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The social revolution in Russia, which transforms TWENTY MILLION serfs into freemen is announced as really having taken effect on Sunday, the 17th of March hencefort and forever a memorable day in the history of Russian civilization.
lead_paragraph: The social revolution in Russia, which transforms TWENTY MILLION serfs into freemen is announced as really having taken effect on Sunday, the 17th of March -- hencefort and forever a memorable day in the history of Russian civilization. The extinction of serfdom, first proposed as an academic question by CATHERINE II. -- which was actually initiated by ALEXANDER I. -- and which occupied the mind of NICHOLAS ere he became wholly swallowed up in more ambitious projects, is at last achieved by the generous coup de main of ALEXANDER II., whose whole attention, since his accession, has been absorbed in this stupendous task. In the scientific view, this innovation presents itself simply as a colossal experiment in Political and Social Economy: but it has really far deeper claims on our sympathies as a very profound and touching human fact. Long looked forward to by the poor peasantry, generations have lived and died in the hope of the good time coming, and there is a certain pathos in the brief telegraphic announcement that "the emotion created throughout the Empire is immense."
headline: {'main': 'Emancipation in Russia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Emancipation in Russia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At a meeting of the Republican Central Club, at Cooper Institute, last evening, Mr. GOULD called up a series of resolutions offered by him at a previous meeting, declaring that the Republicans had advanced to the extreme verge of the Chicago Platform for the purpose of conciliating the Border Slave States; recommending a special session of Congress to annul the Fugitive Slave law, as far as pertained to those States, unless they cease to give moral support to the Secessionists; in favor of sending fugitives to Hayti free of charge, and making provision for compensation subsequently to Union-loving slaveholders who should thus lose their slaves.

abstract: MR. DE CORDOVA's ENTERTAINMENT. -- In our reference to Mr. R.J. DE CORDOVA's entertainment on Monday last, we stated erroneously that it would take place at Irving Hall. Instead of this, it will come off at Hope Chapel, and to-night, as previously announced. The programme is one of the pleasantest that we have seen this season, and combines elocution with music in a most agreeable manner. Mr. DE CORDOVA is the popular lecturer now before the public, and, as a humorist, has no equal. Assisted by Miss SARA STEVENS, Miss PEARSON and Mr. MILLARD, it will be strange, indeed, if he does not fill to overflowing the somewhat limited capacity of Hope Chapel. If patronage goes by desert, he will certainly do so.

abstract: In our political imbroglio, the Englishman, like the heroine in the play, "perceives a divided duty." He is under great obligations to his moral convictions and training, but he is wedded to commerce and trade, and must follow these wherever they lead. "We think none the less of him for the position he has taken, though apparently purchased at the expense of his moral sense. It was a great triumph of humanity when in State affairs, political and religious ideas and motives gave way to commercial -- when the promotion of the material good of the people took the place of the advantage of the few who happened to wield power. England says she hates Slavery, but must sell to those that pay best, and extend a certain degree of sympathy to those who agree with her in her great essential -- the promotion of her material welfare, no matter how much she may differ from them in moral or political ethics.

abstract: "There is a woman in the public eye, whose name had all along been associated, in our mind, with the 'Yankee,' 'Quack,' and 'Humbug.' But it is so no longer, and we desire to wrest her name from all each suspicious association in all other minds. Whatever notions we may have of womanly delicacy and propriety, we will all admit that woman alone is the Nurse -- the GOOD Nurse -- the BEST Nurse. Whether we shall have female physicians or not is a question which must be decided by time and principle, and not as a matter of taste. Pride, prejudice, caprice and custom may as well behave themselves, for if there is really a want there will also be a supply -- if there be a 'calling,' there will be a 'coming.' Nature and Human Society are always self-supplying, and though Art and Fashion may binder, they canned prevent.

abstract: ANNIVERSARY OF THE MARINE TEMPERANCE SOCIETY. -- The twenty-eighth anniversary of this Association, auxiliary to the New-York Port Society, was held at the Mariner's Church, Madison-street, Tuesday evening. Capt. EDWARD RICHARDSON, the President, occupied the chair, and a large audience was in attendance. In the absence of the Secretary, Capt. ELLIOT read the annual report, from which it appears that the Society now numbers 37,343 enrolled members, 886 of whom have signed the pledge during the past year. The report states that during the twenty-eight years of the existence of the Society, it has proved, and is still proving, a valuable auxiliary to the New-York Port Society, and through its instrumentality thousands of seamen have been redeemed from a life of intemperance, and have become members of Christian churches. At the conclusion of the report the audience was addressed by Rev. C.W. DENNISON, Rev. CHAS. J. JONES, REV. Mr. MCLAUGHLIN and Capt. ELLIOTT.

abstract: IMPORTANT MILITARY AND NAVAL NEWS. It impossible to conceive, without witnessing it, the extraordinary change which twelve hours can make in the aspect of military and naval affairs at the New-York station. On Monday last, everything was dull and uninteresting on Governor's Island, at Fort Hamilton, on Bedloe's Island, and at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. Yesterday there was intense excitement apparent in all these places.
lead_paragraph: IMPORTANT MILITARY AND NAVAL NEWS.

abstract: The debate on the Slave-trade in the British Parliament, on the 26th ultimo, in which the history of the efforts of England, France, Portugal and Holland to suppress it were reviewed, and the obstacles apparently opposed to those measures by Spain and the United States were exposed, has elicited a warm expression of remonstrance and indignation from the Spanish Cortes. We took occasion, at. the time, to review that debate, with special reference to the exaggerated strictures of Lord JOHN RUSSELL on the obstructive attitude of this Government in the vexed question of Right of Search, as well as to the extended remarks of Lord PALMERSTON, which included certain severe but just animadversions upon the honor and responsibility of Spain. After alluding to "the mistaken but respectable sense of national honor which induced the American Government to suffer with impunity that prostitution of its flag which covers theabomination of the Slave-traffic," his lordship proceeded to denounce, in language as emphatic as that which Lord JOHN RUSSELL had just employed toward the United States, "the profligate, shameless, and disgraceful bad faith with which the Spanish nation have acted with reference to the treaties concluded with England on this subject. He as unhesitatingly charged Spain with dishonesty, in that she had received L400,000 from England in 1817, as indemnity to those who might suffer by her new compact with the British Government for the abolition of the Slave-trade; and with ingratitude, in that she had forgotten or disregarded the signal aid and protection that England had rendered her toward the establishment of a free Constitution in 1835 -- at which time she pledged herself to execute faithfully the terms of her old treaty, and by means of machinery mutually established, such as right of search, mixed commissions, &c., to assist in the suppression of the traffic. His lordship declared it extraordinary that a nation of men who, taken singly, would blush to do aught that could be construed unfavorably to their honor, should, when taken in the aggregate, be guilty of so shameless and abominable a violation of loyalty -- such conduct, he did not hesitate to say, as would have afforded England just cause for war, if she had chosen to avail herself of it.
lead_paragraph: The debate on the Slave-trade in the British Parliament, on the 26th ultimo, in which the history of the efforts of England, France, Portugal and Holland to suppress it were reviewed, and the obstacles apparently opposed to those measures by Spain and the United States were exposed, has elicited a warm expression of remonstrance and indignation from the Spanish Cortes. We took occasion, at. the time, to review that debate, with special reference to the exaggerated strictures of Lord JOHN RUSSELL on the obstructive attitude of this Government in the vexed question of Right of Search, as well as to the extended remarks of Lord PALMERSTON, which included certain severe but just animadversions upon the honor and responsibility of Spain. After alluding to "the mistaken but respectable sense of national honor which induced the American Government to suffer with impunity that prostitution of its flag which covers theabomination of the Slave-traffic," his lordship proceeded to denounce, in language as emphatic as that which Lord JOHN RUSSELL had just employed toward the United States, "the profligate, shameless, and disgraceful bad faith with which the Spanish nation have acted with reference to the treaties concluded with England on this subject. He as unhesitatingly charged Spain with dishonesty, in that she had received L400,000 from England in 1817, as indemnity to those who might suffer by her new compact with the British Government for the abolition of the Slave-trade; and with ingratitude, in that she had forgotten or disregarded the signal aid and protection that England had rendered her toward the establishment of a free Constitution in 1835 -- at which time she pledged herself to execute faithfully the terms of her old treaty, and by means of machinery mutually established, such as right of search, mixed commissions, &c., to assist in the suppression of the traffic. His lordship declared it extraordinary that a nation of men who, taken singly, would blush to do aught that could be construed unfavorably to their honor, should, when taken in the aggregate, be guilty of so shameless and abominable a violation of loyalty -- such conduct, he did not hesitate to say, as would have afforded England just cause for war, if she had chosen to avail herself of it.

abstract: egram announced, last week, that a memorial had been presented by the "German Republican Central Committee" in favor of the repeal of the Sunday theatre and liquor laws. We were aware that the Chairman of the Committee, and some of its members, were connected with the liquor and lager traffic -- as they have a right to be -- and that the early meetings of the Committee were held on Sunday. At least one instance came to our knowledge of the expulsion of a member because of his avowed "Sabbatarian" views. But we were quite unaware that any part of the objects of the Committee embraced questions like that treated of in their memorial. Elastic as the Republican creed may be, none but Teutonic expounders would stretch it so as to cover Sunday tippling or beer-garden, theatricals. We cannot but exclaim, Non tali auxilio.

abstract: A correspondent, writing from Constantinople under date of Feb. 27, gives an account of the manner in which Washington's Birthday was celebrated is that city. Such of the American residents, or sojourners, as chose to do so, accepted invitations to call on Col. JAMES WILLIAMS, the United States Minister, during the day, and in the evening that gentleman
lead_paragraph: A correspondent, writing from Constantinople under date of Feb. 27, gives an account of the manner in which WASHINGTON's Birthday was celebrated is that city. Such of the American residents, or sojourners, as chose to do so, accepted invitations to call on Col. JAMES WILLIAMS, the United States Minister, during the day, and in the evening that gentleman held a reception, at which the Diplomatic Corps and other functionaries were present, while Mrs. WILLIAMS gave her friends a soiree. The residence of Col. Williams was beautifully illuminated with colored lamps, and inside the building the Stars and stripes were profusely displayed, while the likeness of WASHINGTON. wreathed in evergreens, occupied a prominent position in the central saloon.

abstract: Frederica Newland, Administratrix, &c., Respondent, vs. The New-York Central Railroad Company, Appellants. -- The plaintiff, as administratrix of her late husband, obtained a verdict for $1,000 against the defendants, for injuries to her husband causing his death, alleged to have been sustained inconsequence of the negligence of the defendants' employes. The accident occurred in the village of Tonawanda, near Buffalo, and was occasioned by the deceased's horse running away, in conjunction with a neglect to stop a hand-car they were trundling on the part of the defendant's employes, they seeing the horse coming in time to have done so. A collision taking place, Newland was killed. The defendants, asserting that the verdict is "contrary to the weight of evidence," appealed, and now presented their case to this Court. Decision, reserved.
lead_paragraph: Frederica Newland, Administratrix, &c., Respondent, vs. The New-York Central Railroad Company, Appellants. -- The plaintiff, as administratrix of her late husband, obtained a verdict for $1,000 against the defendants, for injuries to her husband causing his death, alleged to have been sustained inconsequence of the negligence of the defendants' employes. A collision taking place, Newland was killed. The defendants, asserting that the verdict is "contrary to the weight of evidence," appealed, and now presented their case to this Court. Decision, reserved.

abstract: English papers received by the Africa announce that the Directors of the Great Ship Company have determined upon dispatching the Great Eastern to New-York on the first of May ensuing. Capt. JOHN VINE HALL. her commander on the first voyage, has been superceded by Capt. CARNEGIE, R.N., who is to be her future commander. Upon the death of Capt. HARRISON, Capt. HALL was selected as the commander of the great ship, on account of the reputation he had won in the service of the East India Mail Company, as commander of their steamers. He had distinguished himself on several important occasions by the exercise of superior skill and judgment under trying circumstances. Upon the successful conclusion of the first Atlantic trip of the monster ship, he was highly complimented, in connection with his associate officers, for his skillful management during the voyage. Joining in this testimonial was Capt. CARNEGIE, with four others, Captains of the Royal Navy, who were among the passengers.

He had distinguished himself on several important occasions by the exercise of superior skill and judgment under trying circumstances. Upon the successful conclusion of the first Atlantic trip of the monster ship, he was highly complimented, in connection with his associate officers, for his skillful management during the voyage. Joining in this testimonial was Capt. CARNEGIE, with four others, Captains of the Royal Navy, who were among the passengers.

abstract: KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. -- An adjourned meeting of this body was held in the County Jail yesterday, Supervisor CROWELL, President, in the Chair. The Committee on Accounts, to whom was referred the bill of JONES & Co., for $1,100, for rebinding books in the Register's Office, reported that the work had been very imperfectly done, and competent judges estimated the value of what had been done at $800, which amount was ordered paid. An application was made by the officers of the Home for Deaf Young Mutes for an appropriation. The officers say that children under 12 years of age are not admitted into the State institution, and the object of this Society is to provide for them. The clerk was directed to notify the applicants that the Board of Supervisors has no authority to make the appropriation called for. Mr. COIT, Chairman of the Committee on Court-house, presented a contract for the purchase of the Schenck property in Fallon and Joralemon streets, as a site for a Court-house, for $70,000, with a resolution authorizing the County Treasurer to issue bonds to the amount of $100,000 to meet the same and incidental expenses; and that the Committee be authorized to offer premiums for plans for the new Court-house, viz.: $250 for the best, $125 for the second best, $75 for the third best, and $50 for the fourth. The whole subject was laid over until the next meeting. The Board, after the transaction of some routine business, adjourned.

abstract: Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest yesterday, at the New-York Hospital, upon the body of a man named John Hopps, whose skull was fractured on the 19th inst. by a blow from a stick in the hands of a young man named Henry Rowland. The testimony was in substance as follows: Rowland and a colored man, Frederick Johnson by name, both of whom are employed at Schermerhorn's livery-stable, No. 172 Mercer-street, were amusing themselves on the afternoon of the 19th ult. by playing cards: while so employed, Hopps, the deceased, who acted as coachman for a gentleman whose horses were kept at the stable, went in and became a witness of the game; he was apparently somewhat intoxicated, and, looking over Johnsons hand, volunteered advice as to how the cards should be played, much to the annoyance of Rowland, who requested him to mind his own business and leave Johnson to act without assistance; Hopps thereupon became angry, and high words passed between the men, resulting in Rowland receiving a blow in the face from his opponent's fist; at this point other parties interposed and prevented further violence; Rowland then asked Hoops to leave him, but the latter again made an effort to renew the assault; having lost all patience, Rowland wrenched a stick from a bale of hay and struck Hopps upon the forehead with such force that he fell to the floor insensible; efforts were made to restore him to consciousness, but they failed, and he was removed to the Hospital, where, having languished until Tuesday night, death resulted. Rowland was not arrested at the time of the assault, as none who witnessed it would lodge a complaint against him. As soon, however, as the Police of the Fifteenth Ward heard of Hopps' death they took him into custody pending the result of the inquest. After hearing all the evidence in the case the jury were of opinion that "death was caused by a blow at the hands of the prisoner, HENRY ROWLAND, who had inflicted it under circumstances of great provocation." The accuse, was thereupon committed by the Coroner to await the action of the Grand Jury. HOPPS was a native of Cleveland, 28 years of age.

abstract: -- (if indeed the Robin Hood convention, which was to be held at Mesilla on the 16th ult., has kindly let it remain ours thus far) -- that the good old times of the bowmen of Sherwood Forest are in full blast down there. The ancient salutation of "Stand and Deliver!" which erst rang cheerily through the lonesome woods of Old England, is now again heard resounding shrilly o'er the solitary plains of the great Southwest. Instead of the trusty bow of the days of yore, however, the bold highwaymen of Arizona use the most approved patent rifle, and instead of the Robin Hood plea of charity in excuse for their doings, they put in the statesmanlike apology of the "necessities of the State." These freebooters are known as "Secession Rangers," and sweep through Texas, up to the Messilla Valley, seeking whom and what they can find to devour. A band of such fellows it was who, at San Antonio, a week or two ago, seized the $30,000 which the United States had sent to pay off our gallant army, which has been for years defending the frontier against the Indian savages; or, as the San Antonio Herald vividly described it:

abstract: Hugh Appenheimer, a German, known to the police as a sneak thief, was successful on Monday afternoon in obtaining possession of $72, by entering Mr. Wm. Miltner's house, No. 64 First-avenue, with false keys, and robbing a bureau drawer. One of the neighbors happened to notice the rogue as he was leaving the house, and from her description of his appearance given to Officer Prout, of the Seventeenth Ward, after the robbery became known, the latter had no difficulty in arresting him. He was found with a number of his friends enjoying himself with cards and beer at a German saloon in Avenue C, and when taken into custody would scarcely believe that his ate delinquency had brought him into trouble. A portion of the stolen money, amounting to $60, was found in the prisoner's possession, and the owner was enabled to identify some of it. Justice BRENNAN committed the accused to answer.

abstract: The news from Texas, published yesterday morning, created the greatest excitement in Washington, both in and out of Administration circles. What action will be taken by the Government in relation to it, provided it proves to be correct -- of which there is some doubt entertained -- is of course unknown. The Cabinet were in session yesterday, and are supposed to have been engaged in discussing the condition of affairs in the South, and definitely shaping a policy to be pursued. Gen. SCOTT was called before them, as were also other prominent military men, and rumors were afloat that the reinforcement of Fort Sumpter had been determined upon; but the Administration keeps its own counsels, and whatever is decided upon is not likely to be known in advance.

abstract: Matter of the Attachments against the Estate of Edward Bounoffe and August Bounoffe. This case is familiar to the reader of the law reports of the TIMES, it having been several times stated at great length. The question involved is one of considerable commercial importance. The creditors of the firm of
lead_paragraph: Matter of the Attachments against the Estate of Edward Bounoffe and August Bounoffe. -- This case is familiar to the reader of the law reports of the TIMES, it having been several times stated at great length. The question involved is one of considerable commercial importance. The creditors of the firm of Bounoffe & Co., residing in France, and a few of those resident in this City and elsewhere, upon the failure of that firm, joined in a "concordat,"or composition deed. The concordat is an agreement between debtor and creditors, by which the former agrees to surrender his assets and entire estate for the benefit of the latter, they agreeing to be satisfied therewith, and that he shall be discharged from any further liability to them on account of his indebtedness.

abstract: This Association met last night at their rooms in the Cooper Institute. During the temporary absence of the President, Prof. MASON, the Chair was occupied by Mr. J.P. VEEDER. The Professor subsequently arrived, and assumed his post. Mr. J.T. SEELY presented a model of a new water-wheel for grist mills, factories, &c., which would, as alleged, cost much less than the wheels now in use, while it would perform much more work. No action was taken thereupon. Mr. C.A. SEELY made some remarks on the use of Kerosene oil and other burning fluids, which elicited some discussion respecting their tendency to explosion. The main topic of the evening was "Iron-clad Ships," which was introduced, in continuation of the same subject, left unfinished at the last meeting, by Mr. DIBBIN. He claimed that Mr. R.L. STEVENS, of Hoboken, was their originator, and instanced, what he admitted wasa "nondescript," the mysterious battery not yet finished, in that, or rather under that, desirable locality in New-Jersey. He proceeded to describe the "non-descript," but did not do much to clear up the obscurity which will probably for a long time to come envelop the work which has cost the Government so much money, and of which the present generation, in all probability, will not see the benefit. In Mr. DIBBIN's opinion an iron-plated ship would be far less useful in warfare than a ship built of wood, for the reason intimated by Mr. STETSON at the last meeting, namely, that the shot striking it would tear away so much of the surrounding iron work, that ten times the damage would be done which would accrue to a wooden vessel. The question to which the attention of the meeting was thence directed was the comparative invulnerability of a series of iron plates riveted together, and of a solid plate of iron of the same thickness. Wrought iron, it was claimed on one side, could not be shattered by a projectile made of cast-iron, while the contestants, on the other hand, argued that it could. Mr. STETSON and others continued the argument. Capt. BARTLETT, U.S.N., spoke at length on the subject of resistance to projectiles, and exhibited several specimens of shells to be thrown from cannon. Iron-clad ships, in his opinion, might be used in harbors, for defensive positions, but would not be available for general naval warfare. The subject, at the adjournment of the meeting, was held to be still under discussion.

abstract: military body which it represents a very questionable service by its championship of Major YELVERTON. That officer stated under oath that from the time when he first met her as a Sister of Mercy at the hospitals in the Crimea, his sole object in his attentions and professions of love to Miss LONGWORTH had been to make her his mistress; and that, to accomplish this object he went through the form of a marriage ceremony twice, he believing it to be merely a sham, while he knew she believed it to be real and binding. The Gazette is very severe on one Major GAVIN, who, it says, "harked in with the ruthless hunting down of a brother-officer, by calling in the House of Commons on the Under-Secretary for War to dismiss him from the army;" and it is still more savage on the Authorities for having "so far succumbed to public clamor," as to suspend Major YELVERTON from military duty.

abstract: After having been in session for about a week, the Spring Trade Sale of the New-York Book Publishers' Association was last evening brought to a close. The important features of the last day were the invoice of Messrs. LEAVITT & ALLEN, and some very fine specimens of ambrotypes contributed by CHARLES TABER & Co., of New-Bedford. The invoice of LEAVITT & ALLEN, consisting chiefly of valuable standard works, in most attractive bindings, sold well, though suffering under the disadvantage of coming at the close of the catalogue. In book collations, as in dinners, the last courses are very apt to go off untouched. The ambrotypic collection abovementioned shared this disadvantage. Had it been brought forward earlier in the sale, there is no question but what its merit would have secured a most favorable reception.

abstract: MEETING OF JOURNEYMEN PAINTERS. -- On Wednesday evening the journeymen painters of Brooklyn held a meeting at 190 Myrtle-avenue, Mr. IRVING in the chair. After the regular business of the meeting had been transacted, the following employers were named as paying the prices asked for by the journeymen: Messrs. Phillips, Jones, Bradly, Young, Edmonds and Kirby F. Davy, namely, $1 75 per day. Before adjourning they decided to attend the painters' mass-meeting, to be held at No. 193 Bowery, New-York, on Monday evening next.

abstract: very interesting letter from Washington will be found in another column, detailing certain discoveries made by the Secretary of the Navy, in relation to the fraudulent contract system which has prevailed under the two last Administrations, though not reaching its culminating point, apparently, until during the latter half of Mr. BUCHANAN'S term. The system will be found wonderfully ingenious, securing every appearance of absolute impartiality between bidders, while really giving a monopoly to certain favored dealers, or at least insuring the ruin of any outside contractors so foolish as to under-bid the Departmental pets.

abstract: The schooner Wells, of Greenport, L.I., was seized at that place, on the morning of the 3d, by the Custom-house authorities, upon suspicion that she was bound upon a slave voyage to the coast of Africa. She had on board all the necessary cargo, and the usual large supply of water and casks for a slaver. The Wells is a new vessel, having been built in 1860. by H. BISHOP, and belongs, according to the American Lloyds, to C. WELLS & Co. of Greenport. She is 140 tons register.

abstract: There is not the slightest doubt that, to-morrow or Sunday, a large force of army soldiers will leave for some unknown destination. The garrison of Fort Hamilton was paid off yesterday, the last move preparatory to marching. Officers were arriving from Washington, individually, all day yesterday, and, carpet-bags in hand, reporting themselves for duty. The village of Fort Hamilton was like a stormed citadel.
lead_paragraph: There is not the slightest doubt that, to-morrow or Sunday, a large force of army soldiers will leave for some unknown destination. The garrison of Fort Hamilton was paid off yesterday, the last move preparatory to marching. Officers were arriving from Washington, individually, all day yesterday, and, carpet-bags in hand, reporting themselves for duty. The village of Fort Hamilton was like a stormed citadel. Troops, who had just got their money, having been indulging freely in stimulants, thronged the sidewalks in knots of from five to ten, boisterously discussing the affairs of the nation.

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington, this morning, are of the highest importance, and taken in connection with the activity which is displayed in the Military and Naval Departments of the Government, as exhibited at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, and the various military stations in our harbor, and elsewhere, indicate with sufficient significance that a line of policy has been decided upon by the Administration, which will speedily test the strength of the Government, and its ability to enforce the laws. In less than a week -- our correspondent telegraphs -- it is probable that every port of importance, south of Charleston, through which inland communication can be had, will be blockaded, and that the Revenue laws will be everywhere enforced, if the Navy is strong enough to do it. Not the least important statement in our correspondent's dispatch is that the Government is likely to be sustained in its efforts to sustain its authority by the sympathy of the great European Powers, whose representatives have decidedly, though unofficially, expressed the hope that the integrity of the Union shall be maintained. The greatest excitement exists in Washington in view of the supposed warlike action of the Administration, but the general feeling seems to be one of satisfaction that the present state of suspense will soon come to an end.

abstract: Amos Neary vs. Charles Germaine. -- This was an action to recover damages for personal injuries. The plaintiff was a deck-hand on the steam-tug Screamer, of which defendant was captain. When the steamer Black Warrior was wrecked on Rockaway Beach, some two years ago, the tug was engaged in trying to pull her off the shoal, in connection with the steam-tug Satellite. The Satellite was pulling ahead of the Screamer, when her hawser broke, and by the action of the wind and tide, the Screamer was swung round towards the shore. Her master, to bring her up, ordered the hawser, on which she was pulling, to be carried from the bitts amidships to the quarter-check. The plaintiff, with two other hands, was engaged in doing this, and after two unsuccessful trials, succeeded in getting it fast to the quarter-rail, the chock being carried away. When the strain came on the hawser as the boat went ahead, it broke away a piece of the rail which swung round inboard, and striking the plaintiff, who stood near, broke both his legs. For this injury the suit was brought, the plaintiff claiming that the defendant maliciously, and with intent to injure him, gave the order to go ahead at full speed instead of going slow until the hawser was taut. The only evidence of malice, however, which he offered, was that the defendant was swearing at the men for not fastening the line quicker, and on receiving what he understood to be a saucy answer from one of them, said, "If you don't look out I'll break some of your necks," or, as one witness said, "I'll come down and break your head."
lead_paragraph: Amos Neary vs. Charles Germaine. -- This was an action to recover damages for personal injuries. The plaintiff was a deck-hand on the steam-tug Screamer, of which defendant was captain. When the steamer Black Warrior was wrecked on Rockaway Beach, some two years ago, the tug was engaged in trying to pull her off the shoal, in connection with the steam-tug Satellite. The Satellite was pulling ahead of the Screamer, when her hawser broke, and by the action of the wind and tide, the Screamer was swung round towards the shore. Her master, to bring her up, ordered the hawser, on which she was pulling, to be carried from the bitts amidships to the quarter-check. The plaintiff, with two other hands, was engaged in doing this, and after two unsuccessful trials, succeeded in getting it fast to the quarter-rail, the chock being carried away. When the strain came on the hawser as the boat went ahead, it broke away a piece of the rail which swung round inboard, and striking the plaintiff, who stood near, broke both his legs. For this injury the suit was brought, the plaintiff claiming that the defendant maliciously, and with intent to injure him, gave the order to go ahead at full speed instead of going slow until the hawser was taut. The only evidence of malice, however, which he offered, was that the defendant was swearing at the men for not fastening the line quicker, and on receiving what he understood to be a saucy answer from one of them, said, "If you don't look out I'll break some of your necks," or, as one witness said, "I'll come down and break your head."

abstract: Messrs. Stanton Co., brokers, at No. 83 Canalstreet, yesterday caused the arrest of a young foreigner of very distingu appearance, styling himself Baron de Vielinghoff, on a charge of forgery. The prisoner, it is alleged, came to this City last December, and pretending to be a Prussian nobleman, induced the complainants to advance him $1,250 upon certain drafts of the house of Hanbro Son, London, made payable at the Bank of Berlin, Prussia.
lead_paragraph: Messrs. Stanton & Co., brokers, at No. 83 Canalstreet, yesterday caused the arrest of a young foreigner of very distingu appearance, styling himself Baron de Vielinghoff, on a charge of forgery. The prisoner, it is alleged, came to this City last December, and pretending to be a Prussian nobleman, induced the complainants to advance him $1,250 upon certain drafts of the house of Hanbro & Son, London, made payable at the Bank of Berlin, Prussia. These drafts were forwarded by Messrs. Stanton & Co. to the firm of Oppenheim & Warfchauer, bankers at Konigsberg, who pronounced the signatures of Messrs. Hanbro & Son to be forgeries, and information of this fact was forwarded- to the New-York brokers. The services of Detectives Farley and Eustace were then invoked in the matter and the Baron was apprehended. It has now become known that the Baron is a nobleman, only by title, and that the appellation is self-conferred. He left Konigsberg, it is said, to avoid a prosecution for forgery, having formerly been a clerk in the employ of Messrs. Oppenheim & Warfchauer, whose names he made free use of in extensive forging operations, but who detected him before any loss accrued to their firm. His real name is G.H. Wenghoefer, although since his residence in this country he has sometimes called himself Robert Gilbert. He was taken before Justice WELSH, at the Tombs, by whom he was committed for examination, and it is supposed that he has other victims beside Messrs. Stauton & Co., who will appear and prosecute. Upon being taken into the cell, the prisoner protested against the inhumanity of the law which compelled a Baron to take up with quarters no better than those provided for the canaille.

abstract: The sick man is at last terribly sick. There are invalids in the European family. German States suffering from depletion French provinces weakened by a rush of capital to the Parisian head there is Italy in a convulsive fever, and Denmark subject to fits but none of them are positively unable to get along, and the worst are hopefully convalescent. Only Turkey seems to appeal, as though in articulo mortis, to the sympathies of humanity.
lead_paragraph: The sick man is at last terribly sick. There are invalids in the European family. German States suffering from depletion -- French provinces weakened by a rush of capital to the Parisian head -- there is Italy in a convulsive fever, and Denmark subject to fits -- but none of them are positively unable to get along, and the worst are hopefully convalescent. Only Turkey seems to appeal, as though in articulo mortis, to the sympathies of humanity.

abstract: The machinery of criminal Justice has at length been put in motion towards investigating the organized system of bribery and corruption so freely charged against "the Mayor, Aldermen and Commonalty" of our unfortunate City. The somewhat notorious GEORGE MOUNTJOY, who has long been regarded as the secret agent of civic bribes, has been committed to prison for thirty days by the Court of Oyer and Terminer, for having refused to answer a question as to whether he had ever known of the expenditure of money for the purpose of influencing the official action of any branch of our Municipal Government. Mr. MOUNTJOYreplied that he could not answer without degrading himself; but as a special statute is in force exempting witnesses who are called upon to testify in regard to municipal affairs from any criminal prosecution for the disclosures they may make, the Court very properly held that the witness could receive no protection from his plea, and that he must either answer or stand committed for contempt. Mr. MOUNTJOY accepted the latter alternative, perhaps as the lesser evil; and at this point, so far as he is personally concerned, the matter for the present rests.
lead_paragraph: The machinery of criminal Justice has at length been put in motion towards investigating the organized system of bribery and corruption so freely charged against "the Mayor, Aldermen and Commonalty" of our unfortunate City. Mr. MOUNTJOYreplied that he could not answer without degrading himself; but as a special statute is in force exempting witnesses who are called upon to testify in regard to municipal affairs from any criminal prosecution for the disclosures they may make, the Court very properly held that the witness could receive no protection from his plea, and that he must either answer or stand committed for contempt. Mr. MOUNTJOY accepted the latter alternative, perhaps as the lesser evil; and at this point, so far as he is personally concerned, the matter for the present rests.

abstract: The signs of the times indicate "that the Government has decided to enter upon a vigorous and decided policy, in vindication of its authority and in protection of its interest. Our advices from Washington render it probable, to say the least, that the Revenue laws are to be enforced in Southern ports, as well as Northern, and that vessels will not be permitted to enter ports where duties upon their cargoes will not be paid.
lead_paragraph: The signs of the times indicate "that the Government has decided to enter upon a vigorous and decided policy, in vindication of its authority and in protection of its interest. Our advices from Washington render it probable, to say the least, that the Revenue laws are to be enforced in Southern ports, as well as Northern, -- and that vessels will not be permitted to enter ports where duties upon their cargoes will not be paid. It is probable that New-Orleans will be blockaded, as well as every other Southern port.

abstract: We have taken pains to ascertain whether there is any truth in the report, that Gen. AMPUDIA, at the head of three thousand Mexicans, has invaded, or is about to invade Texas, in the neighborhood of Brownsville. From all that can be ascertaind, we are satisfied it is utterly without foundation.

abstract: The unusual activity at the War and Navy Departments, and news of orders to the vessels at the Brooklyn and Boston Navy Yards, give rise to innumerable, and some very ridiculous, stories. The local papers have it that the Navy is ordered to Southern ports, and that a blockade is to be commenced at once. Another rumor has it that the vessels go to carry reinforcements to the Forts, including Sumpter; and still another, that they are sent to resent the action of the Governor-General of Cuba. In reply to all this the Cabinet officers answer that everything will be amicably settled "in due time."
lead_paragraph: The unusual activity at the War and Navy Departments, and news of orders to the vessels at the Brooklyn and Boston Navy Yards, give rise to innumerable, and some very ridiculous, stories. In reply to all this the Cabinet officers answer that everything will be amicably settled "in due time."

abstract: The regular monthly meeting of this Society was held last evening at the rooms, Clinton Hall. There was, as usual, a large attendance. The presiding officer was ARCHIBALD RUSSELL, Esq. On the motion of Mr. DISTURNELL, the Governor of Colorado, Mr. WM. GILPIN, was elected a member of the Society. The Librarian announced the receipt of 84 bound volumes and 220 pamphlets, presented to the Society since its last meeting.
lead_paragraph: The regular monthly meeting of this Society was held last evening at the rooms, Clinton Hall. There was, as usual, a large attendance. The presiding officer was ARCHIBALD RUSSELL, Esq. On the motion of Mr. DISTURNELL, the Governor of Colorado, Mr. WM. GILPIN, was elected a member of the Society. The Librarian announced the receipt of 84 bound volumes and 220 pamphlets, presented to the Society since its last meeting. The Secretary read the report of the Council, recommending for election, as resident member, A. VON STEINWHR, and as corresponding members, all the Ambassadors to foreign countries, just apponted by the new Administration. Mr. CHARLES DANA, of New-York, a resident for the past three years in Honolulu, and its neighborhood, read a paper on the Sandwich Islands, in which he treated of heir history, natural productions, scenery, and present states of civilization and cultivation. Thousands of miles from any continent, they were a sort of half-way house for navigators. The natives, far from being the savages they were supposed to be, were among the most inoffensive beings in the world. A stranger might travel anywhere there without apprehension, and sleep in any native hut without fear. The women, when young, were remarkable for beauty, and equally notable for hideousness when old. In "full dress," they overburdened themselves with clothing, but relieved themselves after that ceremony by emulating the pristine simplicity of Eve in Paradise. The men rejoiced in blankets, which they wore with dignity, feeling that with dress, or without dress, "a man's a man for a' that." The food of the natives was principally fish, but dogs were also eaten, though not so much as formerly. The lecturer had eaten "dog," and thought it. far better than "hog." It was a more cleanly animal than a pig, -- it was, in fact, very good eating. Mr. DANA took a new view of Capt. COOK'S history. The Captain and his crew were a hungry set. They ate so much that they starved the Hawaiians out, and only paid for their food with a few trinkets. COOK caused himself to be worshipped as a God; he broke the idols of the natives, and attempted to abduct their king. They accordingly rose up and murdered him. Mr. DANA gave a highly graphic account of a visit to the celebrated volcano of Kileuau. A vote of thanks was passed for his discourse, and the meeting adjourned.

abstract: Thomas Sheridan, a middle-aged Irishman, was admitted to Bellevue Hospital on the 26th ultimo, with inflammation of the stomach. He told a patient who lay in the bed next to him that his sickness had been brought on by a kick which was given him a few days previously by the bar-keeper in a liquor store at the corner of Park and Mulberry streets. He went into the bar-room, he said, to get a glass of beer, and when it was given to him he complained of its being muddy. This offended the bar-keeper, who first abused him and then kicked him out of the store. After lingering until yesterday Sheridan died, and Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest in the case. The keeper of the drinking place was summoned, but he emphatically denied the truth of the statement of deceased, and there being no evidence to corroborate it, the jury declared that the violence was inflicted at the hands of some person unknown.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Sheridan, a middle-aged Irishman, was admitted to Bellevue Hospital on the 26th ultimo, with inflammation of the stomach. abstract: Egbert Deming, Trustee of the New-York Marble Co. vs. The New-York Marble Co., Henry Dwight, and James R. Bame, Trustee, &c. -- The above action having been brought to trial before GEO. G. BARNARD, one of the Justices of this Court, at aSpecial Term thereof holden at the New City Hall, in the City of New-York, on the 12th day of March, 1861, and all the proofs and allegations of the plaintiff having been heard and duly considered, and, on motion of Levi S. Chatfield and Edwards Pierpont, of counsel for the defendant, and after hearing Wm. H.L. Barnes, Esq., attorneyfor the plaintiff, it is hereby ordered, adjudged and decreed that no cause exists for the removal of the said Henry Dwight and James R. Bame from the office of Trustee of the New-York Marble Company, or for the suspension of their powers or functions as such Trustees, and that they be not removed from the office of such Trustee.

abstract: The United States revenue-cutter Harriet Lane yesterday left her moorings off the Battery, and anchored subsequently at Quarantine. abstract: say that we read the newspapers published in JEFF. DAVIS' Republic with very deep interest at the present time. There are developments constantly made down there that the world would be the worse (or at any rate less wise) for losing. The entire mind of the Confederate States is in a condition of high excitement -- we might say, in a state of exaltation -- and the manifestations are peculiar and abnormal. There are discoveries in ethics, in mathematics and physics, to say nothing of political economy, well calculated to astonish the world and displace the books of schoolmen.

abstract: Mr. BRUNO WOLLENHAUPT, a violinist, whose first appearance at a concert some months since was hailed with great satisfaction by the audience, will give his first grand concert on Saturday night at Irving Hall. Signor CENTEMERI, the baritone, and a full orchestra will assist on the occasion -- Mr. CARLBERGMANN conducting the latter. The programme is one of the best we have seen this season, and is interesting apart from the special attraction of Mr. WOLLENHAUPT'S playing. The pieces selected by Mr. WOLLENHAUPT are VIEUXTEMPS' Grand Concerto in E major; ERNST'S Airs Hongrois, and a concerto on a theme by David by the performer.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BRUNO WOLLENHAUPT, a violinist, whose first appearance at a concert some months since was hailed with great satisfaction by the audience, will give his first grand concert on Saturday night at Irving Hall.
