abstract: Hon. JOHN MCLEAN, L.L.D., who died at Cincinnati yesterday morning, was born in Morris County, N.J., on March 11, 1785. His father, who was an Irish emigrant, and a weaver by trade, removed to the West when his son was four years of age, settling first at Morgantown, Va., afterwards in Jessamine, near Nicholasville, Ky., then in the vicinity of Mayslick, finally taking up his permanent abiding place in 1799, in that section of Ohio now included in Warren County. Here Mr. MCLEAN cleared a farm on whichhe resided until the time of his death, which occurred in 1839. His son was sent to school at an early age, and availed himself of the limited advantages which were afforded him so eagerly, that when sixteen years of age he was placed under the tuition of Rev. MATTHEW WALLACE and one Mr. STUBBS, who grounded him pretty thoroughly in Latin and Greek. All this time he was doing his full share of labor on the farm, with that self-reliant disposition which has characterized him through his long and eminently useful career, refusing to allow his father to defray the expenses of his education. When eighteen years of age Mr. MCLEAN left the farm to enter upon the study of the law in Cincinnati, and while pursuing a course of reading in the office of ARTHUR ST. CLAIR, he contrived to support himself by husbanding the meagre salary which he received from a position which he had procured in the office of the County Clerk. A short time before his admission to the Bar, in 1807, he married Miss REBECCA EDWARDS, daughter of Dr. EDWARDS, formerly of South Carolina, and in the Fall of that year opened an office in Lebanon, Warren County. Mr. MCLEAN rapidly attained eminence in his profession, and in 1812 was the successful one of three competitors for Congressional honors in the Cincinnati District. At this time Mr. MCLEAN was an ardent Democrat, never allowing his devotion to party, however, to overcome his sense of duty, for again and again where principle was concerned, he left the ranks and voted against political friends. During his first Congressional term he was an ardent supporter of Mr. MADISON'S war policy, and so successfully did he represent his constituents that in 1814 he was returned to the House without opposition, actually receiving every vote cast in his District. During his second term he rendered distinguished services on two Committees -- those on Foreign Relations and the Public Lands. In 1815 he was tendered the nomination for the United States Senatorship, which was equivalent to an election, but he could not persuade himself that he would be doing his duty to his constituents in withdrawing from the position in which they had placed him, and declined the honor. In 1816, however, having nearly completed his term, he resigned his seat in the House, to take one on the Supreme Bench of Ohio, to which the Legislature elected him unanimously. This position he held for six years, when President MONROE appointed him Commissioner of the Land-office, and in the next year (1823) he was elevated to the Postmaster-Generalship. He discharged the duties of the office with such eminent success, that the salary attached to it was raised from $4,000 to $6,000, by a nearly a unanimous vote in both the Senate and House -- JOHN RANDOLPH remarking at the time that he would vote for the bill if it were made to expire when Judge MCLEAN left the position. When President JACKSON came into office he was desirous of retaining Judge MCLEAN in his Cabinet, but he thought it expedient to decline all offers which were made him to this end, and wasnominated for a seat on the Supreme Bench, which he accepted, entering upon his duties in the January term, 1830. The decisions which he has given during the thirty years which he has occupied this position have filled out the measure of his fame, and given him a leading place among the first jurists of this or any other country. One of his most memorable charges was delivered during the Canadian excitement, in 1838, when he took strong ground against the practice of aiding or in any way favoring unlawful military combinations among our citizens against any Government with which we were at peace. His opinion on the Dred Scott case, in which he dissented from that given by Chief Justice TANEY, will cause his name to be remembered.
lead_paragraph: Hon. JOHN MCLEAN, L.L.D., who died at Cincinnati yesterday morning, was born in Morris County, N.J., on March 11, 1785. His father, who was an Irish emigrant, and a weaver by trade, removed to the West when his son was four years of age, settling first at Morgantown, Va., afterwards in Jessamine, near Nicholasville, Ky., then in the vicinity of Mayslick, finally taking up his permanent abiding place in 1799, in that section of Ohio now included in Warren County. Here Mr. MCLEAN cleared a farm on whichhe resided until the time of his death, which occurred in 1839. His son was sent to school at an early age, and availed himself of the limited advantages which were afforded him so eagerly, that when sixteen years of age he was placed under the tuition of Rev. MATTHEW WALLACE and one Mr. STUBBS, who grounded him pretty thoroughly in Latin and Greek. All this time he was doing his full share of labor on the farm, with that self-reliant disposition which has characterized him through his long and eminently useful career, refusing to allow his father to defray the expenses of his education. When eighteen years of age Mr. MCLEAN left the farm to enter upon the study of the law in Cincinnati, and while pursuing a course of reading in the office of ARTHUR ST. CLAIR, he contrived to support himself by husbanding the meagre salary which he received from a position which he had procured in the office of the County Clerk. A short time before his admission to the Bar, in 1807, he married Miss REBECCA EDWARDS, daughter of Dr. EDWARDS, formerly of South Carolina, and in the Fall of that year opened an office in Lebanon, Warren County. Mr. MCLEAN rapidly attained eminence in his profession, and in 1812 was the successful one of three competitors for Congressional honors in the Cincinnati District. At this time Mr. MCLEAN was an ardent Democrat, never allowing his devotion to party, however, to overcome his sense of duty, for again and again where principle was concerned, he left the ranks and voted against political friends. During his first Congressional term he was an ardent supporter of Mr. MADISON'S war policy, and so successfully did he represent his constituents that in 1814 he was returned to the House without opposition, actually receiving every vote cast in his District. During his second term he rendered distinguished services on two Committees -- those on Foreign Relations and the Public Lands. In 1815 he was tendered the nomination for the United States Senatorship, which was equivalent to an election, but he could not persuade himself that he would be doing his duty to his constituents in withdrawing from the position in which they had placed him, and declined the honor. In 1816, however, having nearly completed his term, he resigned his seat in the House, to take one on the Supreme Bench of Ohio, to which the Legislature elected him unanimously. This position he held for six years, when President MONROE appointed him Commissioner of the Land-office, and in the next year (1823) he was elevated to the Postmaster-Generalship. He discharged the duties of the office with such eminent success, that the salary attached to it was raised from $4,000 to $6,000, by a nearly a unanimous vote in both the Senate and House -- JOHN RANDOLPH remarking at the time that he would vote for the bill if it were made to expire when Judge MCLEAN left the position. When President JACKSON came into office he was desirous of retaining Judge MCLEAN in his Cabinet, but he thought it expedient to decline all offers which were made him to this end, and wasnominated for a seat on the Supreme Bench, which he accepted, entering upon his duties in the January term, 1830. The decisions which he has given during the thirty years which he has occupied this position have filled out the measure of his fame, and given him a leading place among the first jurists of this or any other country. One of his most memorable charges was delivered during the Canadian excitement, in 1838, when he took strong ground against the practice of aiding or in any way favoring unlawful military combinations among our citizens against any Government with which we were at peace. His opinion on the Dred Scott case, in which he dissented from that given by Chief Justice TANEY, will cause his name to be remembered.

abstract: The Secessionists in, the Richmond Convention are making desperate efforts to create the impression that their cause is gaining strength among the people; but all accounts from the interior, except their own, concur in stating that the pestilent fever is abating, and that the public mind is becoming calm and indifferent to their appeals. Secession hac, from the beginning, been an affair of the politicians, and has never had any hold upon the popular heart.

abstract: REPUBLICAN NOMINATIONS IN JERSEY CITY. -- The delegates to the Republican City Convention held an adjourned meeting last night at Franklin Hall, Jersey City, for the purpose of completing the city nominations for the coming election. Mr. W.J. STITT presided. The following nominations were made: For Water Commissioner, long term, D.S. Gregory; short term, A.S. Whiting. Collector, Thomas Howe. Assessor, First and Second, D.W. Stone; Third to Sixth Ward, F.P. Budden. School Superintendent, M.R. Case. A Committee of one from each Ward was appointed to fill vacancies, should any of the above nominees decline. The following-named gentlemen were appointed an Executive Committee for the ensuing year: J. Davenport, A. Jenkins, J. Hutton, S. Quaif, J. Houston, F.R. Hill, and William H. Bumsted. A discussion arose as to the propriety of making a nomination for the office of Recorder, and a motion to go into ballot was declared lost by the Chairman, by a tie vote, and the Convention adjourned. It afterwards appearing that the Chairman had made a mistake in the tally, the Convention was again called to order, and a second ballot resulted in 14 votes in favor of a nomination, against 10 opposed. The second ballot for Recorder was as follows: WM. L. DICKINSON. Principal of Public School No. 3, 15 votes; Dr. H. D. HOLT, 7; blank, 2. Mr. DICKINSON was accordingly declared the nominee. The Convention then adjourned. A portion of the delegates were opposed to a nomination of a Recorder, as there are already two in the field, the present incumbent, Mr. TILDEN, who will be strongly supported by the Temperance men, and Mr. MARTINDALE, who will receive the support of the Anti-Temperance party.

abstract: DEDICATION OF THE ANTHON MEMORIAL CHURCH. -- The new Episcopal Church, recently erected in Forty-eighth-street, near the Seventh avenue, was dedicated yesterday under the name of the Anthon Memorial Church. This church was built by the congregation of St. Mark's Church, at the instance of the late Rev. Dr. ANTHON, as a mission Chapel, and, as such, has been occupied for the past two years. On the death of Dr. ANTHON, St. Mark's offered the building to a new congregation on easy terms for the establishment of an independent church. The offer was accepted, and, out of respect to the late Dr. ANTHON, who may be considered its founder, it was consecrated under the name above mentioned. Rev. EDWARD ANTHON, son of Dr. ANTHON, has been chosen Rector. The dedication services were performed by Bishop POTTER, assisted by Rev. Messrs. WILEY, MOORE and CHAUNCEY. The sermon was preached by Bishop EASTBURN, of Massachusetts, from a text found in Psalms vii., 2. A large congregation was in attendance, including many clergymen. The church is a neat and commodious building. 100 feet by 65, and seats 1,200 persons. In the basement is a well lighted lecture-room, and also a Sunday-school room. The officers of the new church are as follows:

abstract: This mineral, obtained from the mountains of New-Jersey, is a natural pigment, a chemical compound, and not a mechanical mixture. In this respect it differs from most of the earths and red shale which have been so extensively introduced in the market. This paint hardens by exposure to the air, and becomes in a short time a fine and water-proof coating for roofs and outside work, and thoroughly spark and cinder proof, and impervious to the rain or snow. This paint was originally introduced 11 years ago. It has stood the test of time, and has outlived many inferior articles which have flooded the market. It has been applied to the Government buildings at West Point, at Governor's Island, and the New-York Arsenal, on the cars of the principal railroads, and by innumerable shipmasters on their vessels, on canal boats, and everywhere it has met with commendation. The color of this paint is a rich chocolate, and this, when mixed with white lead or zinc, produces that color which is now universally in use upon the cottages and villas that dot the Hudson River. Without enlarging upon its virtues, we cordially invite the attention of the public to the testimonials and certificates from parties whose evidence is entitled to the most implicit confidence, and which may be seen at the depot. The advertisement will be found in another column.

abstract: Sir: The new American tariff having been passed by Congress, will come into operation on the 1st prox.: and should the Southern secession be fully carried out, there is every probability of its remaining in force for some time to come, as, owing to the retirement from Congress of a large portion of the Southern members, the Northern manufacturing interest is all powerful in both branches of the Legislature.

abstract: The Chamber of Deputies, while discussing that paragraph of the Address relating to the budget and the financial and commercial condition of the Empire, paid a passing salute to the American crisis. Several members spoke of the crisis and its probable influence on French affairs, but no opinions of importance were expressed.

abstract: As the legislative hundred days are now rapidly drawing to a close, we beg to ask the conscript fathers of the State, individually and collectively, whether they mean that this City shall be doomed to endure another term of DELAVAN and the cohort of incompetents facetiously known as Board of Health, Health Wardens, Street Inspectors, and what not?
lead_paragraph: As the legislative hundred days are now rapidly drawing to a close, we beg to ask the conscript fathers of the State, individually and collectively, whether they mean that this City shall be doomed to endure another term of DELAVAN and the cohort of incompetents facetiously known as Board of Health, Health Wardens, Street Inspectors, and what not? It is no use now reciting for the hundredth time the long and ghastly record of official incompetence and neglect. It is needless at this day to tell again of the hecatombs of Christian citizens and innocent children that have been sacrificed during the brief sway of the present City Inspector, -- and indeed ever since political influences controlled the office, -- or how vastly the interests of the Metropolis have suffered at the hands of so-called sanitary officials, who hold place, but that they may prey upon its plunder and grow rich upon the public ruin. The enormous ratio of mortality during the past year -- (1 death to every 35 of the population, or 29 to every 1,000) -- the fact that last week no less than 17 deaths were officially reported from that fearful epidemic, small-pox, every one of which might have been and ought to have been prevented, -- the 13,958 children who last year were consigned to the grave, from which at least a half of them might have been saved, had these Health Officers performed even half their duty, -- the chronic filth of the streets, the thousand and one nuisances, the slaughter-houses, soap-factories, stables, garbage and garbage-boxes, -- the swill-milk, diseased meats, rotten fruits, adulterated goods of every kind, -- the murderous tenement houses, the worse than murderous subterranean dens in which the vast cellar population burrow and rot -- the want of drainage, the defective sewerage, -- all these, and a hundred more that are unmentionable, are facts patent to every citizen, and unfortunately not to be disproved by the most audacious political partisan. It were equally supererogatory to go over again the unparalleled advantages in point of healthful ness which naturally appertain to this imperial island. Manhattan, in fact, as every Manhattanese knows, is just such an isle as the gods themselves would have chosen as the site for an ideal commercial city, where a million freemen should grow up in moral and physical proportions worthy the republic of which it should be the grand sensorium.

abstract: About three weeks since Messrs. Livermore, Clews & Mason, Stock-brokers at No. 29 Wall-street, received a quantity of Virginia State Sixes from a man named James Elliott, then in Washington, D.C., with the request that they should be negotiated, and the money forwarded to him. This was done, and a day or two since Elliott called in person at the office of the firm, and put in its hands what purported to be $3,500 worth of the same stock, with the request that it should be sold, and the proceeds retained, subject to his order. Certain peculiarities in the appearance of these last-named bonds, induced the brokers to suspect that they were not genuine, and upon comparison their suspicions were confirmed. Yesterday morning, therefore, when Elliott sent down a draft for $1,000 on account of the bogus stock, it was refused ostensibly because of an informality in the filling up, and Detectives Slowey and King were informed of the matter. These officers took stations at the brokers' office in anticipation of Elliott's appearance, and they had not long to wait ere he arrived. In the midst of his explanations to Messrs Livermore & Co., he was astonished to feel a hand upon his shoulder, while at the same time one of the officers whispered in his ear the ominous words "You're my prisoner." Elliott was then removed to Head-quarters, where he will be detained pending a magisterial investigation of the case. The forged drafts bear a strong resemblance to the genuine, but a minute comparison shows that they are not of so dark a color, and the paper is of poorer quality. The signature of U.R.C. Drinkhard attached to the coupons, is also unlike that gentleman's autograph. These forged bonds are dated "Richmond, Va., July 1, 1861," and are made payable in this City. It is probable that a large number of them have been manufactured and are in circulation. During his negotiations with Messrs. Livermore & Co., the prisoner went by the name of Barbour, but after his apprehension he stated that his real name is Elliott. He asserted that he obtained the bonds from responsible persons, and his ability to prove his innocence of the crime laid to hit charge.

abstract: The intelligence from Charleston looks warlike, and indicates that a collision is likely to take place at any moment. The reports which have reached there relative to the movements of the Administration have created much excitement, and the feeling appears to be general that war is inevitable within a short time. Gen. BEAUREGARD, who yesterday morning
lead_paragraph: The intelligence from Charleston looks warlike, and indicates that a collision is likely to take place at any moment. The reports which have reached there relative to the movements of the Administration have created much excitement, and the feeling appears to be general that war is inevitable within a short time. Gen. BEAUREGARD, who yesterday morning before sunrise proceeded to Morris Island on business connected with the batteries there located, is understood to have declared that Major ANDERSON and his command must either evacuate Fort Sumpter or be shelled within forty-eight hours. The report that the supplies for the garrison had been cut off by authority, is corroborated by the Charleston papers which reached us last night. The Southern Commissioners, now in Washington, our correspondent informs us, still express a belief that a peaceful policy will prevail, though their sincerity may with propriety be questioned, in view of all that is transpiring. On the other hand, they assert that if the policy of the Administration is the enforcement of the Federal laws, the seceded States are ready to resist to the bitter end.

abstract: It is impossible that and right-thinking or light-feeling man should regard with indifference, with resentment, or with mockery, the movement new in progress in seven Southern States, looking to their complete severance from the Federal Union, and the establishment of a separate sovereignty of their own.
lead_paragraph: It is impossible that and right-thinking or light-feeling man should regard with indifference, with resentment, or with mockery, the movement new in progress in seven Southern States, looking to their complete severance from the Federal Union, and the establishment of a separate sovereignty of their own. How shall we be indifferent when we remember how long we have shared with the people of those States the common dangers, the common interests, and the common glories of a great Government? Their people have been our people, and their God has been our God. Dating from the trying times of the Revolution, we have cherished common memories, revered the same heroes, and struggled side by side, animated by the same ambition, to win an honorable position for our country among the nations of the earth.

abstract: The conflicting character of the reports and rumors touching the movements of the Army, and of naval vessels, many of which have turned out to be incorrect, have naturally made the public distrustful of any intelligence on that subject which is not a record of facts actually accomplished. Avoiding all mere speculations on so important a subject, it will be our object, as far as possible, to report only such movements of the Government forces as can be relied upon as correct, or which have actually occurred.
lead_paragraph: The conflicting character of the reports and rumors touching the movements of the Army, and of naval vessels, many of which have turned out to be incorrect, have naturally made the public distrustful of any intelligence on that subject which is not a record of facts actually accomplished. abstract: On the 17th of last November, the warehouse of Messrs. Thomos and William Fisher, lace importers, at No. 69 North-street, was visited by burglars who entered by removing the scuttle on the roof, and managed to carry away nearly $3,000 worth of laces without attracting attention. Detectives Farley and Eustace were assigned to the work of tracking the thieves, and after two months labor, notwithstanding the fact that the search was prosecuted under the disadvantage of having no clue upon which to base their movements, these officers arrested one of the burglars, named George Shrimpton, who was convicted and is now serving a term of four years and six months in Sing Sing prison. At the time of his arrest, the Detectives recovered $800 worth of the stolen laces, but not being satisfied with obtaining so small a portion of the property, their efforts to secure the remainder were not at all relaxed. Recently they received information from one of those secret sources whom "shadows" delight in knowing, which carried with it the conviction that the Test, of the laces were concealed at a house in West Hoboken, about five miles from the ferry, formerly tenanted "General" Greenthal, -- as expert a rogue, 'tis said, as ever England furnished to the criminal ranks of this country, who is at present also doing the State "some service." On Thursday evening the officers decided that a call should be made upon the "General's" wife, who still retained possesion of the premises, and a request be made her to surrender the goods. This arrangement was duly executed, but Mrs. Greenthall was not communicative, and although she did not deny for a moment that the officers had received correct information as to where the goods had been concealed, she refused to point out the precise spot, requesting the police to look it up themselves, chuckling triumphantly as she bade them search the premises, in the belief that the lace was beyond their reach. Nothing discouraged, the detectives, who had been joined in the matter by Sergeant Dickson, also of the detective force, entered upon a minute examination of every nook and cranny where it was thought possible the plunder could be stowed away. When, however, the search was extended to the coach-house, Mrs. Greenthal, (weo had closely watched these movements, and had in turn been watched herself,) betrayed considerable anxiety, which only served to convince the police that the prize was there concealed. A very minute examination was then undertaken, -- the hay bales and feedbags were overturned, on the supposition that the lace had been buried in them, the walls and floors and lofts were each subjected to a close scrutiny, but no suspicious trap-doors or panels were found. Finally the officers were about to give the matter up as a bad job, when one of them noticed that several of the crevices in the flooring, in the centre of the stable, were free from dirt, while the remainder of the cracks were choked up as would ordinarily result from use. This fact convinced him that the flooring ead recently been taken up, and consequently he proposed to push the search in that direction. His companions acquiesced, and after ripping up the planks they were rewarded for their pains by the aight of a number of sacks. These were speedily, emptied of their contents, which consisted of the laces that they had been seorching for. The property was gathered up again and brought over to New-York, where it was fully identified by Messrs. Fishers & Co., whose trademarks were still upon it. The woman Greenthal was arrested, as well as her daughter, Hannah Davis, a young woman of 25 years, and a man named Jacob Ort, each of whom is held as a receiver of stolen goods. They are at present detained at Police Headquarters. An inventory of the goods recovered, showed that the whole amount carried off by the thieves ($2,600 worth) had been returned.

abstract: The People ex rel. vs. Charles R. Harvy et al. Henry A. Hart et al. -- This action now came on for trial. The occurrence out of which the action grew has already been made familiar to the public. The plaintiffs claim to have been legally elected, on the evening of March 12, 1860, to the office of Trustees of the Church of the Puritans, on Union-square, and to have been deprived of the certificate of their election; and to have been prevented from entering upon the duties of their office though the fault and misconduct of the defendants.
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel. vs. Charles R. Harvy et al. Henry A. Hart et al. -- This action now came on for trial. abstract: OF AFFAIRS. -- The Mozart Hall General Committee held a meeting at No. 814 Broadway, on Thursday night, over which Hon. JOHN COCHRANE presided. abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMANN, Edward O. Kane, convicted of assault and battery, was sentenced to the City Prison for five days. The lightness of the punishment was due to the fact that the assault had hardly been anything more than an act of self-defence, the complainant himself having made a severe attack on prisoner and his wife.

abstract: Mr. BARNEY, the Collector of the Port, it is well known, has been literally besieged by applicants for office. It is doubtful if even the President himself has been pressed with a larger or more importunate army of persons in search of places under the Government. It has been officially announced by the new Collector that he will make no appointments for at least a month to come. This, it is presumed, will be sufficient to relieve him of the incessant tax upon his time which these applications cause, and permit him to arrange the details of his office without so much annoyance.

abstract: supremely melancholy in the thought that ideas such as the following, could be uttered by a Christian minister in regard to the diabolical Disunion Conspiracy. abstract: Early on Saturday morning Redmond McManus, a Deputy Sheriff, formerly a Police Officer attached to the Lower Police Court, in company with one of his friends named Davenport, went into the coffee and cake saloon No. 36 Bowery and ordered refreshments. McManus was intoxicated, and while the waiter went to procure what had been called for, he produced a revolver and offered to bet Davenport that he could extinguish a gas-light in the rear part of the saloon at the first shot. Davenport expressed incredulity, and immediately the boastful drunkard fired. As might have been anticipated, the ball went wide of the mark, but McManus excused himself for the failure by pleading nervousness, and nothing further was thought of the matter. Having eaten what had been ordered the men stepped to the bar, and while settling with the proprietor, the subject of pistol-shooting was again spoken of. Suddenly, McManus a second time drew his revolver and discharged it in the same direction as at first, unhappily with a more serious result. The bullet entered the forehead of a man named Wm. Hogan, who was seated at one of the tables, and glancing around the skull, caused a very severe and painful scalp wound. The excitement attending the occurrence attracted several police officers, to the saloon, and McManus was taken into custody. Hogan was removed to the Tenth Precint Station-house, and attended by a police Surgeon, who failed to extract the bullet, and the patient was afterwards taken to the New-York Hospital. The Surgeon of that institution was finally successful in tracing the course of the missile, which he succeeded in removing, finding it to have been flattened by contact with the skull. The injury is said to be of a dangerous character, but at present no fears of a fatal result are entertained. The prisoner was taken before the magistrate at the Tombs on Saturday morning where affidavits were made by several witnesses of the occurrence, and he was committed, pending Hogan's recovery or death. He asserts that he had no intention of injuring Hogan, who was a stranger to him, and attributes his conduct to his drunken condition.

abstract: On Friday night an attempt was made to set fire to the tenement-house No. 102 Ridge-street, in which twenty-four families find accommodation. SIMON SALEY, a butcher, occupies the front basement as a shop, and the passage-way leading to the cellar was used as a storehouse for his meats, while a large dog was chained near by as a protection against thieves. Through this animal the incendiarism was discovered before much damage was done. Hearing him bark, Mr. SALEY ran down stairs, when a man rushed past him in the darkness and escaped. On examining the cellar it was found that shavings had been piled against the wood bins, and marches, partly burned, were scattered about. The building although new, is unprovided with fire-escapes, and, had the flames gained headway, a great destruction of life must have resulted. The lives of the inmates of the large tenement house No. 37 Mulberry-street were also in jeopardy between 2 and 3 o'clock on Saturday morning, by a fire kindled against the partition on the second floor. Officer COOMBS, of the Sixth Precinct, discovered the fire, and, arousing the occupants, with their assistance it was soon extinguished. The incendiary had placed a large bag of paper and some pieces of board against the partition in the hall-way and set fire to them.

abstract: The movement of troops in this vicinity excites universal interest, and intensifies the general anxiety to know something of the policy which it indicates. The Government has maintained the most complete secresy in regard to the destination of these troops, and the public is consequently left wholly to conjecture. The general impression, we think, is that they are destined for Texas.
lead_paragraph: The movement of troops in this vicinity excites universal interest, and intensifies the general anxiety to know something of the policy which it indicates. The Government has maintained the most complete secresy in regard to the destination of these troops, and the public is consequently left wholly to conjecture. The general impression, we think, is that they are destined for Texas. The main ground for this belief is the character of the force. It is not easy to sec what use could be made of Flying Artillery in any attempt to reinforce Forts Sumpter or Pickens; while in Texas it would be the arm most required. The Sappers and Miners included in the force will also be quite as useful in throwing up fortifications that may be needed in Texas, as in reinforcing either of the forts named.

abstract: The Albany Evening Journal says it "has no sympathy and but little patience with those who are daily goading the Administration into a premature expose of its policy." The great body of the American people are profoundly anxious to know what policy their Government proposes to adopt in regard to secession.
lead_paragraph: The Albany Evening Journal says it "has no sympathy and but little patience with those who are daily goading the Administration into a premature expose of its policy." The great body of the American people are profoundly anxious to know what policy their Government proposes to adopt in regard to secession. Perhaps this solicitude on their part is unreasonable, -- but at all events it is natural. The great business movements of the country, -- the prosperity of the millions of our people, -- the ability of thousands and hundreds of thousands to maintain themselves, depends, not so much upon the specific policy which may be adopted, as upon knowing in what direction the Government intends to act. The interests of commerce are especially involved in this peril. The trade of the country cannot proceed blindly. Men cannot enter upon the enormous transactions of foreign trade without some little knowledge of the future. It is not necessary that they should know what specific steps the Government proposes to take, -- but they must know in what direction it intends to move.

abstract: The associated artists of the Italian troupe, under the direction of Signor MUZIO, have returned to the City, and will commence a series of entertainments to-night at the Academy of Music in Fourteenth-street. VERDI's opera of the "Masquerade Ball" has been selected for the occasion, and will undoubtedly attract a fine audience. It is the only decided success we have had in opera since the production of "Il Trovatore." On Wednesday next "La Juive" is to be revived, with the superb mise-en-scene for which the opera is principally memorable. The present season will terminate with the week, the company being engaged to appear in Philadelphia on Monday next. We learn that the Boston season was eminently successful. Rumors of the most dazzling kind are afloat. One of them is to the effect that the associated artists have made twenty-five thousand dollars of profits.

abstract: Tha latest reports from Charleston, telegraphed on Saturday, taken in connection with the fact that telegraphic communication with the South has been cut off below Petersburgh, Va, render it extremely probable that actual war has at last been commenced by the Secessionists, and that the bombardment of Fort Sumpter is now proceeding.
lead_paragraph: Tha latest reports from Charleston, telegraphed on Saturday, taken in connection with the fact that telegraphic communication with the South has been cut off below Petersburgh, Va, render it extremely probable that actual war has at last been commenced by the Secessionists, and that the bombardment of Fort Sumpter is now proceeding. The information received in Charleston relative to the warlike movements here, created the greatest excitement there under the supposition that the object of the Administration was the reinforcement of the Fort; and though at last accounts the ultimatum of siege or surrender, mentioned in our previous dispatches, had not been sent to Major ANDERSON, his supplies have positively been cut off by order of Gen. BEAUREGARD -- and this was considered equivalent to a declaration of hostility.

abstract: The sudden activity of the Government in the preparation and dispatch of naval and military expeditions from this port have been the theme of general remark throughout the City during the last three or four days.
lead_paragraph: The sudden activity of the Government in the preparation and dispatch of naval and military expeditions from this port have been the theme of general remark throughout the City during the last three or four days. Considering the formidable character and extent of the movement, there has been a remarkable absence of excitement on the subject, and, so far as the public feeling has manifested itself, a strong sentiment of approbation is expressed on all hands that the Government have, after so long forbearance, undertaken in earnest to vindicate the laws of the country. A calm confidence pervades the public mind, that the measures now being adopted have for their object the protection of the country and its institutions from the assaults of traitors.

abstract: THE RESULT OF INTEMPERANCE. -- Coroner SCHIEMER held an inquest yesterday forenoon, upon the body of Mr. ARCHIBAED ANDREW, a native of Scotland, 53 years of age, who was drowned on Saturday afternoon. It appeared from the evidence that the deceased, who was a merchant at Newark, N.J., while intoxicated, made an attempt to walk on board the steamer Passaic, lying at the foot of Barclay-street, but staggering off the gang-plank, he was drowned. His remains were recovered....LAWRENCE HENRY, an frishman, aged 50 years, of intemperate habits, missing during the past three months, was found drowned yesterday morning, at the foot of Perry-street. North River. Coroner JACKMAN investigated the case, and the jury were of opinion that the deceased fell into the liver white under the influence of liquor. His remains were identified by means of his clothing.
lead_paragraph: THE RESULT OF INTEMPERANCE. -- Coroner SCHIEMER held an inquest yesterday forenoon, upon the body of Mr. ARCHIBAED ANDREW, a native of Scotland, 53 years of age, who was drowned on Saturday afternoon. abstract: The Palmetto Commonwealth is falling into disgrace among her confederate sisters. They find her too fiery even for their brimstone tastes. "The South Carolinians are a singular people," remarks the Mobile Mercury -- an observation more entitled to respect from its truth than from its novelty. "But they must not expect to have things entirely their own way, and will have to put up with what satisfies other people." This is a very domestic manner of talking -- language quite likely to be heard in any moderate household where there are seven sisters, one of them regarded as a "beauty," and therefore petted, while the six others are homely, and obliged to retrim last year's bonnets for this year's use. "JEMIMA ANNE is singular," they will say; "but she must put up with what satisfies other people."

abstract: The patriotic virtues of JOHN B. FLOYD have at length found a worthy eulogist in the person of a traitorous ex-diplomat, who has been handsomely paid by the National Government during the past four years, for his effective efforts to disgrace the American name and character at the Court Of VICTOR EMANUEL.
lead_paragraph: The patriotic virtues of JOHN B. FLOYD have at length found a worthy eulogist in the person of a traitorous ex-diplomat, who has been handsomely paid by the National Government during the past four years, for his effective efforts to disgrace the American name and character at the Court Of VICTOR EMANUEL. The ex-diplomat, having drawn his last quarter's salary under Mr. BUCHANAN, and paying Mr. LINCOLN the deserved compliment of believing that no such Minister as he felt himself to be could be permitted any longer to misrepresent the United States at the Court of Turin, patriotically resolved to make a merit of necessity, and resign before his successor was appointed. This done, Mr. DANIELS returned to the editorship of the Richmond Examiner, Mr. FLOYD's personal organ in the days when FLOYD was powerful and DANIELS an applicant for place. He returned to write the character of his former patron, and to record the services of the Ex-Secretary of Civil War, in the cause of treachery and treason.

abstract: The Sunday Courier publishes a startling narrative touching the actual gathering of a fleet of armed vessels off this coast bearing letters of marque from JEFFERSON DAVIS, whose object is to prey upon the commerce of the North, and particularly upon the incoming California steamers and their specie.
lead_paragraph: The Sunday Courier publishes a startling narrative touching the actual gathering of a fleet of armed vessels off this coast bearing letters of marque from JEFFERSON DAVIS, whose object is to prey upon the commerce of the North, and particularly upon the incoming California steamers and their specie. The story, with some elements of plausibility, such as the mention of names of men well known in this community, and the exhibition of certain letters from mysterious persons in Boston, was related by a Capt. WYATT alias MARSHALL, who professes to have been engaged to command one of these vessels without being made acquainted with their character. Among other facts mentioned, Capt. MERRITT, agent of the Board of Underwriters is said to have chartered his schooner, called the Ringola, to carry the parties from this port to Sandy Hook, where they met the privateers. As Capt. MERRITT knows nothing about the affair, and has not chartered his vessel for the purpose named, the whole story must have been a rather late first of April hoax.

abstract: The brig Julia E. Acry, of Thomaston, Maine, Capt. E.W. RYDER, arrived at this port yesterday from St. Thomas, W.I. The captain narrates the following as the experience of himself and son, at the hands of the people of Georgia. He arrived with his vessel at Eucio's Mills, Camden County, Ga., upon the first of last November, with a cargo of hay, brick, &c. Soon after his arrival, a colored man owned by Dr. BAILEY,and hired by a man named SCOTT, was sent on board by his master to sell some oars, and also engaged to do the washing for the captain and his son, J.B. RYDER, the second mate of the vessel.
lead_paragraph: The brig Julia E. Acry, of Thomaston, Maine, Capt. E.W. RYDER, arrived at this port yesterday from St. Thomas, W.I. The captain narrates the following as the experience of himself and son, at the hands of the people of Georgia. He arrived with his vessel at Eucio's Mills, Camden County, Ga., upon the first of last November, with a cargo of hay, brick, &c. Soon after his arrival, a colored man owned by Dr. BAILEY,and hired by a man named SCOTT, was sent on board by his master to sell some oars, and also engaged to do the washing for the captain and his son, J.B. RYDER, the second mate of the vessel.

abstract: An apparently half cracked individual, calling himself Capt. WYATT, has been hoaxing the public with an absurd narrative of the organizing of twenty vessels as a privateering fleet on this coast.
lead_paragraph: An apparently half cracked individual, calling himself Capt. WYATT, has been hoaxing the public with an absurd narrative of the organizing of twenty vessels as a privateering fleet on this coast. The new United States District Attorney has also had the "facts" mysteriously laid before him. WYATT, it seems, without giving his name, applied, two weeks ago, to charter the schooner Ringgold, belonging to Capt. ISRAEL MERRITT. He represented that he wished to intercept a vessel from Boston at Sandy Hook, of which he was Captain, and agreed to pay $100 for the vessel for three days. The brother of Capt. MERRITT states that WYATT brought on board three women and a little girl, an old man and some half dozen boys. The only baggage they had was an old trunk, a chicken coop with a few hens and some household rubbish of no possible value, and no provisions. They went down the bay with the party and remained at anchor in the Horse-shoe for two days and nights, the wind being to the eastward. During this time WYATT tried to induce Capt. MERRITT to go with them to Cape May, but he refused to do so.

abstract: We have now reached a point in our history which, whatever step may be taken, will be of momentous importance as a precedent for the future. Suppose we accede to the demands of the seceding States. We shall thus admit that our Government exists only by sufferance of its members, as each one may withdraw its allegiance at will. If this is to be our theory the sooner it is understood the better, as every person will give it due weight in his calculations for the future. No reliancewhatever will be placed on the Federal Government, as it will have shown itself incapable of maintaining its dignity, of enforcing its laws, or of protecting its subjects or property. A State may with impunity seize its forts and Navy-yards, its vessels engaged in the revenue and lighthouse service, with the threat that if any resistance be offered to the capture of those still retained, it will seize the merchant ships of the people of the other States in their ports, convert them into privateers and pirates, and sweep our commerce from the seas.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, John Cuff, indicted for grand larceny, was put to the bar for trial. It seems that the prisoner and the complainant, Michael Murray, were fellow-laborers at the Central Park.
lead_paragraph: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, John Cuff, indicted for grand larceny, was put to the bar for trial. It seems that the prisoner and the complainant, Michael Murray, were fellow-laborers at the Central Park. The latter alleged that while both were having a general jollification over three half-gallons of bees, the prisoner stole from him $41 in money and a a gold ring. For the defence it was attempted to be proved that the complainant's wife and the prisoner had had some negotiations relative to the marriage of the prisoner with the complainant's daughter, and that the money had been paid by the complainant to the prisoner as a sort of dowry to go with the bride, and that the old gentlemen, while in a state of "salubrity," had required for his money, and being told that Cuff had it, remarked that it was "all right."

abstract: Count CAVOUR has announced to the Italian Chamber of Deputies, that the Ministerial, programme remains unchanged. He said that the union of the temporal and spiritual power was the source of evil.

abstract: The Confederate States of the South are in need of a navy, and strong efforts are apparently being made by their friends in the North to supply the deficit.
lead_paragraph: The Confederate States of the South are in need of a navy, and strong efforts are apparently being made by their friends in the North to supply the deficit. Not many weeks ago it became public, or, at least, was publicly asserted, that a patriotic Alderman and shipbuilder had taken a contract for supplying forty gun-scows, wherewith to guard the mouths of the Mississippi in particular, and all secession harbors in general. But for some unexplained reasons, not necessary to discuss, the gun-scows had their destination changed while in process of being built; so that, even while secession journalists were writing complimentary notices of the "foresight" evinced by JEFFERSON DAVIS, and the "magnificent spirit of national enterprise" displayed by our immortal BOOLE, the contemplated scow-batteries passed into the hands of Street-cleaning Contractor HACKLEY, and instead of heroically discharging paixhans and columbiads against war-vessels of the United States, are to discharge nothing but mountains of filth and street manure at whatever dumping-grounds may be selected.

abstract: Our advices from Charleston and Washington are of exceeding importance. Telegraphic communication with the former city having been restored, our special correspondent there telegraphs that the preparations for the expected conflict are entirely completed, and that all vessels in the harbor have received a notification from Gen. BEAUREGARD to keep out of the range of fire between Fort Sumpter and Sullivan's Island, on which Fort Moultrie is situated.
lead_paragraph: Our advices from Charleston and Washington are of exceeding importance. Telegraphic communication with the former city having been restored, our special correspondent there telegraphs that the preparations for the expected conflict are entirely completed, and that all vessels in the harbor have received a notification from Gen. BEAUREGARD to keep out of the range of fire between Fort Sumpter and Sullivan's Island, on which Fort Moultrie is situated. As a further military necessity, a house situated near one of the batteries erected against the fort, supposed probably to interfere with its efficient working, had been blown up. The famous floating battery had also been brought into requisition, and was to be floated down last evening, and stationed at some point near Fort Sumpter, ready for action. The order, cutting off further communication between the fort and the city, was issued by Gen. BEAUREGARD on Sunday, and Major ANDERSON had been officially notified in regard to it. Requisition had been made for five thousand additional troops, and Companies were constantly arriving and being put in position. Meantime business in Charleston had been entirely suspended, and the most intense excitement prevailed.

abstract: method of obtaining access to the City Treasury has been discovered by some few contractors, who are working "the placer" with feverish activity and determination. The invention is no other than the introduction of a special bill before the Legislature "for the relief" of this man or the other, or "for the confirmation" of this or the other contract. Knowing, as we most painfully do, the ease with which claims against the City have been recovered during the past few years, it is but natural to suspect that claims requiring special legislative assistance to secure their payment, must be of the most flimsy character, to say the least. And while not in the least denying that under certain peculiar circumstances, quite within the reach of a vigorous imagination to conceive, a City contractor may actually suffer injustice through the defect of not having fulfilled some technical formality in relation to his contract, -- it is safe to warn our legislators that in ninety-nine out of every hundred of these "relief" cases brought before them, the claimants are much more deserving of the State Prison than of State aid.

abstract: We have now before us the text of the manifesto of the Czar, announcing to his subjects the emancipation of the serfs. His Majesty tells them that on ascending the throne he resolved in all sincerity to acquire the affections of his subjects of every rank and condition -- "from the warrior who nobly carries arms for the defence of his country, to the humble artisan engaged in works of industry; from the functionary who pursues the career of the highest employments of the State, to the laborer whose plow furrows the fields." His Majesty proceeds to glance at the patriarchalrelations which have hitherto existed between the peasants and their proprietors, and to show that as simplicity of manners has disappeared, the condition of the serfs has been unfavorably affected. He was convinced, therefore, that a great amelioration of their lot was a mission to which he was called by Divine Providence. The steps which have been taken in consulting the mobility, in forming the Committees, and in considering the various propositions, are successively detailed; and the mode of emancipation ultimately agreed to (the substance of which has been given in our columns) is described at length. The cooperation of the nobility is warmly spoken of in the manifesto. "Russia," says His Majesty, "will never forget that the noblesse, moved solely by their respect for the dignity of man and by the love of their neighbor, have spontaneously renounced the rights which the serfdom now abolished had given them, and have laid the foundations of a new future for the peasants." They are then called upon to carry out faithfully and conscientiously the regulations which have been deemed fittest for the great end in view.
lead_paragraph: We have now before us the text of the manifesto of the Czar, announcing to his subjects the emancipation of the serfs. His Majesty tells them that on ascending the throne he resolved in all sincerity to acquire the affections of his subjects of every rank and condition -- "from the warrior who nobly carries arms for the defence of his country, to the humble artisan engaged in works of industry; from the functionary who pursues the career of the highest employments of the State, to the laborer whose plow furrows the fields." His Majesty proceeds to glance at the patriarchalrelations which have hitherto existed between the peasants and their proprietors, and to show that as simplicity of manners has disappeared, the condition of the serfs has been unfavorably affected. He was convinced, therefore, that a great amelioration of their lot was a mission to which he was called by Divine Providence. The steps which have been taken in consulting the mobility, in forming the Committees, and in considering the various propositions, are successively detailed; and the mode of emancipation ultimately agreed to (the substance of which has been given in our columns) is described at length. The cooperation of the nobility is warmly spoken of in the manifesto. "Russia," says His Majesty, "will never forget that the noblesse, moved solely by their respect for the dignity of man and by the love of their neighbor, have spontaneously renounced the rights which the serfdom now abolished had given them, and have laid the foundations of a new future for the peasants." They are then called upon to carry out faithfully and conscientiously the regulations which have been deemed fittest for the great end in view.

abstract: An adjourned extraordinary meeting of the Atlantic Royal Steam Navigation Company was held yesterday, when the directors were authorized to raise L600,000 by the issue of preference shares. It is not proposed to raise the whole at once, but arrangements have already been made for placing at once a very large proportion of this preference stock; the rate of interest to be 7 per cent. It was stated that some modifications of the original contract had taken place, the principal feature being that the Company are to deliver mails at Newfoundland each voyage.

abstract: On yesterday, at noon, JERRY BRYANT, so long known to New-Yorkers, and indeed all over the United States, as a capital delineator of colored character, expired after a brief illness, while laboring under an attack of congestion of the brain. He was born in Chesterfield, Essex County, N.Y., and would have been 33 years of age next June. "A fellow of infinite wit" in his own line of public entertainments, few handled the bones more gracefully, or told a story, or asked a conundrum, or cracked a joke, or sang a melody with more effect. He leaves behind him a widow who is very respectably provided for. JERRY BRYANT had troops of friends in every grade of society; and if all those who have been amused by his talents were to attend his funeral, the cortege would prove one of the most extensive ever seen upon Manhattan Island. His funeral will take place from his late residence. No. 283 Elizabeth-street, on Wednesday, 10th inst., at 1 o'clock.

abstract: morning, about 11 o'clock, as Ex-Mayor TIEMANN was riding in a light wagon through Elm-street, near Police Head-quarters, his horse became frightened in consequence of the breaking of one of the shafts of the vehicle, and ran away at great speed. Near the corner of Howard-street the wagon came in contact with a lamp-post and Mr. TIEMANN was thrown ont by the concussion, falling heavily upon his left side. He was quickly taken into a neighboring drug-store where he received assistance, and afterwards was conveyed to his residence at Manhattanville. The extent of Mr. TIEMANN's injuries are unknown. He remained insensible for an hour after the occurrence, and his nervous system, doubtless, received a severe shock, but the physicians who attended him did not appear to think his life in danger.

abstract: James Alexander vs. Mary Ann Lundy, Robert L. Lundy, her husband, and Ruthella Lundy. The Lundys and the Alexanders, since their acquaintance with each other, have seldom reciprocated confidence or fellow-feeling. On the 18th of October, 1858, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander, and Mr. and Mrs. Lundy and family occupied a mansion together in the vicinity of Twenty-sixth-street.
lead_paragraph: James Alexander vs. Mary Ann Lundy, Robert L. Lundy, her husband, and Ruthella Lundy. -- The Lundys and the Alexanders, since their acquaintance with each other, have seldom reciprocated confidence or fellow-feeling. On the 18th of October, 1858, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander, and Mr. and Mrs. Lundy and family occupied a mansion together in the vicinity of Twenty-sixth-street. They had never had an open rupture and resort to areas, however, until the 18th of October, 1858, when their mutual animosities manifested themselves in quite a vigorous manner. On the morning of that day (time is quite immaterial) one of the female Lundys innocently and unsuspectingly was holding the exclusive possession of a small building in the rear of the lot, dreaming of nothing that subsequently was to develop itself. Now Mrs. Alexander, who resides on the second floor of the aforesaid premises, is the happy possessor of an earthen tureen, (politely speaking) to which vessel there was a cover of the same material. With this in hand she was proceeding slowly but surely to the aforesaid edifice in the rear of the yard, when opening the door and discovering a Lundy in possession, she was moved by some mysterious and inexplicable providence to dash the contents of her tureen in the face of the Lundy. This was the tocsin of warfare Clan Lundy and Clan Alexander rushed furiously upon one another, and were quite playful for some time. In this metes Mrs. Alexander's tureen was made to play a conspicuous part. It was the only weapon, with the exception of fists, that the evidence developed, and told fearfully in the hands of the irate Mrs. Alexander, while the cover in the hands of a Lundy also made its impression. The parties were finally pacified, and the result is that they have thrown themselves upon the country to have their rights adjusted by a jury of their countrymen. The jury; however, after hearing the case through, retired and rendered a verdict for the defendants.

abstract: GAN has vetoed the bill giving half a million of dollars to aid in constructing the Albany and Susquehannah Railroad. His objection is based solely on the ground that the bill grants public money for private purposes, and therefore requires a vote of two-thirds the members of both Houses. We believe the highest legal authorities of this State have decided that giving money to construct a public work, is not giving it for a private purpose, -- and does not therefore fall within this provision of the Constitution.

abstract: Thomas D. Carman, Executor , vs. Gorwood Plass et al. In this case one of the defendants guaranteed the payment of certain rent when it should fall due, by the other. The guarantee was written on the lease. The plaintiff brought his action against the defendants jointly. The defendants demurred, urging that they could not be properly joined, their contracts being separate.
lead_paragraph: Thomas D. Carman, Executor, &c., vs. Gorwood Plass et al. -- In this case one of the defendants guaranteed the payment of certain rent when it should fall due, by the other. The guarantee was written on the lease. The plaintiff brought his action against the defendants jointly. The defendants demurred, urging that they could not be properly joined, their contracts being separate. At Special Term of the Supreme Court, sitting in Brooklyn, the demurrer was sustained, and the complaint dismissed. The plaintiff appealed to the General Term of the Court, and there the judgment below was reversed, the Court holding that the order was appealable. The defendants then appealed to this Court, contending, first, that the older of judgment originally appealed from was not an appealable one; and, secondly, that the parties were not liable jointly on such a contract. The following are the points of the appellant respecting the last preposition:

abstract: The disunion dervishes of Virginia are taking on truly Oriental frenzies. They whirl around, they howl, contort their faces, tear their hair, attitudinize, hold red-hot things between their teeth, and rend themselves generally; they appeal wildly to Heaven, and then plunge wildly into whisky; now they exhibit themselves in the most shameless moral nudity, and now figure in coarse homespun garments. Such exhibitions were never before known outside of Turkey, and seldom even there.

abstract: Last night, the opening one of the new season, a brilliant audience was attracted to the Academy, and the opera "Un Ballo in Maschera" was received with even increased favor, owing, possibly, to the fact that it has won the high approval of the big-wigs of Boston. Criticism has been kindly to the work, and the public who "see" things oftentimes quicker than the critics, have settled it among themselves that it is a success. Most certainly it is the only work, with the exception of the "Trovatore," that has steadily drawn good houses from its commencement. The artists last night were in good voice, and secured several encores. They were well received by an audience evidently glad to see them back again.

abstract: THE VALUE OF AN ALDERMAN'S NOSE. In May, of last year, an Aldermanic fracas occurred in the vestibule of the City Hall, between Ex-Alderman WILSON, of the First Ward, and Alderman RUSSELL, of the Seventh the latter coming off with a scratched face and a nose wrung. For this indignity an action was brought against the offender in the Supreme Court, which he allowed to go by default. The case ...
lead_paragraph: THE VALUE OF AN ALDERMAN's NOSE. -- In May, of last year, an Aldermanic fracas occurred in the vestibule of the City Hall, between Ex-Alderman WILSON, of the First Ward, and Alderman RUSSELL, of the Seventh -- the latter coming off with a scratched face and a nose wrung. For this indignity an action was brought against the offender in the Supreme Court, which he allowed to go by default. The case came up on Monday night before the regular panel of the Sheriff's Jury, whose duty it is to assess damages on all cases which have gone by default -- and after a patient hearing of the evidence pro and con, and which was published in the TIMES at the time of the occurrence, the jury awarded Alderman RUSSELL the sum of $1,000, as compensation for the indignity perpetrated, and the damage done to his nasal protruberance. As there is no appeal from the verdict of a Sheriff's jury, Mr. WILSON will have to pay up the penalty. Many years since, but within the memory of those who would not care to be classed among the "oldest inhabitants" of the City, Dr. HART, then musical and theatrical critic of the Courier and Enquirer, chanced to offend Mr. WOOD, the singer, then performing with his wife at the Old Park Theatre. Coming together by accident in the lobby of the theatre, Mr. WOOD, after some words of crimination and recrimination, spat in Mr. HART's face, for which he was afterwards mulcted in the sum of $3,000, in a civil action, and the occurrence was the occasion of the celebrated "Wood riot," which was so disastrous to the Park Theatre. The inference to be drawn from the two verdicts is, that while a reporter's face is worth $3,600 and a riot, an Alderman's note is only worth $1,060 without the addition of the riot.

abstract: Our Washington dispatches this morning will be found to corroborate the statements made in yesterday's TIMES, that one motive of the Administration in the recent extensive naval and military movements was the necessity for the immediate supply of Port Sumpter with provisions. The steamship Baltic is now stated to be the particular vessel detailed for this duty. It will be recollected that she has on board, besides a large quantity of stores, a number of launches, yawls, &c., and the troops on board are intended to repel attacking parties, for which purpose they are supplied with boat howitzers. The intention of the Government is simply to furnish Major ANDERSON with provisions; but should this be resisted, and should it become necessary to use force, the men who fight their way into the Fort will remain there. The Government have, it is understood, fully notified the authorities at Charleston of their intentions, and the responsibility of inaugurating a war must remain with those who resist

abstract: The People in the relation of the Bank of the Commonwealth, appellants, vs. The Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments, City and County of New-York, respondents. -- In the year 1859, the Bank of the Commonwealth returned to the Commissioners of Taxes that its capital was $750,000, of which sum $103,000 was invested in stocks of the United State, and the Bank claimed that the sum so invested in United States stocks was exempt from taxation, and that the assessment should be made accordingly. The Commissioners decided against the claim of the Bank, and assessed it for the amount of its capital stock, after deducting the amount paid for real estate. The Bank removed the matter into the Supreme Court, by certiorari, where the decision of the Commissioners was affirmed both at Special and General Term. The Bank sow appeals to this Court, and the question is whether a Bank, which is taxable upon its capital as a nominal amount, can escape taxation by investing its money in stocks of the General Government.
lead_paragraph: The People in the relation of the Bank of the Commonwealth, appellants, vs. The Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments, City and County of New-York, respondents. -- In the year 1859, the Bank of the Commonwealth returned to the Commissioners of Taxes that its capital was $750,000, of which sum $103,000 was invested in stocks of the United State, and the Bank claimed that the sum so invested in United States stocks was exempt from taxation, and that the assessment should be made accordingly. The Bank removed the matter into the Supreme Court, by certiorari, where the decision of the Commissioners was affirmed both at Special and General Term. The Bank sow appeals to this Court, and the question is whether a Bank, which is taxable upon its capital as a nominal amount, can escape taxation by investing its money in stocks of the General Government.

abstract: Wm. Scott vs. Ocean Bank. -- The plaintiff, as alleged, was in the habit of remitting money drafts, &c., to the Ohio Life Insurance Company, which were passed to his credit as money. There was no evidence, as appears, of an agreement that they should be so credited until after collection. The plaintiff remitted a draft for $2,000, which reached the Trust Company here on the eve of its failure in 1857, the plaintiff being then its creditor to an amount exceeding $100,000. The draft was turned ever to the Ocean Bank as security to the Trust Company's liabilities to that institution. The Ocean Bank collected the money, and claim the right to retain it. This action was brought to recover it of that Bank, and the only question is, whether the business arrangements between the plaintiff and the Trust Company were such as would warrant the Trust Company in thus using his drafts, after crediting him with them, or in other words, whether by crediting him with the drafts, they then became the property of the Company to such an extent as gave them the right of transfer. The Ocean Bank claim that such was the case. The plaintiff claims that the Trust Company was his agent for the purpose of collection only, and that it could not have nor acquire property in his remittances for such a purpose. Case argued.
lead_paragraph: Wm. Scott vs. Ocean Bank. -- The plaintiff, as alleged, was in the habit of remitting money drafts, &c., to the Ohio Life Insurance Company, which were passed to his credit as money. abstract: The People ex rel. H.G. De Forest, vs. Robert Denniston, State Comptroller, and one other case. -- In 1840 the Legislature pledged the credit of the State, to the amount of $100,000, to the Long Island Railroad Company, in aid of the construction of their road. The act directed that the Comptroller deliver to the Treasurer of the Company certificates of stock to that extent, at 6 per cent., upon the production of the affidavits of five Directors of the Company, setting forth that $400,000 of the capital stock had actually been expended in the building of the road.
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel. H.G. abstract: BROOKLYN ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- A contented mind is a continual feast in morals and in music. Those who looked for "Linda" last night were regaled with the "Somnambula," and the disappointment occasioned by the same, was borne with all the fortitude which we have a right to expect in such a building in such a city, and from an audience accustomed to the contemplation of human nature in a white neck-tie. All things considered the attendance was good, and the appearance of the house brilliant and fashionable. Miss KELLOGG appeared as Amina -- the third role she has undertaken in public. Inasmuch as the opera was substituted at the last moment for another that could not be given in consequence of the indisposition of Signer FERRI, it was, we presume, played without rehearsal. Some allowance has to be made for all the artists, especially for the lady who is comparatively new in the part, having sung it only in Boston. Signor BRIGNOLI, in point of fact, needed a good deal of allowance, and Signor SUSINI's throat-trouble cried aloud for tender consideration. Miss KELLOGG sang the music of her part with decided skill, and acted naturally and spontaneously in all save the finale to the second act, which was, to our mind, fidgety and overwrought. We do not, however, regard Amina as one of the roles peculiarly fitted for the powers possessed by our New-York primadonna. It is true that an excellent method and a quick nervous facility in overcoming obstacles enable her to attack almost any kind of music with success. But it is clear that her style is dramatic, and that the quality of her voice lends itself better to largeness than to brilliancy. In Linda she is the equal of almost any artist we have ever had in the part, and the superior of the majority of those who have essayed it. We cannot say the same of her Amina, although we may gladly recognize in it the indications of a true artist.

abstract: CHARTER ELECTIONS. -- The Charter elections in Hudson County took place yesterday, and in most instances there was a strong contest for places in office. With the exception of two or three fights in Jersey City, the election passed off in a quiet manner. The number of votes cast in Jersey City was as follows: First Ward, 551; Second, 650; Third, 649; Fourth, 600; Fifth, 460; Sixth, 457. This is a falling off of about 1,000 votes from that of last Fall. Up to 11 o'clock last night only about one third of the tickets had been canvassed. It. was generally conceded, however, that CORNELIUS VAN VORST, (Rep.,) was reelected Mayor by about 500 majority. C.C. MARTINDALE, Democratic and American candidate for Recorder, was undoubtedly elected, and also ABRAHAM S. JEWEL for School Superintendent. One man was arrested for illegal voting. In Hoboken, JOHN R. JOHNSON, (Dem.,) was reelected Mayor.
lead_paragraph: CHARTER ELECTIONS. -- The Charter elections in Hudson County took place yesterday, and in most instances there was a strong contest for places in office. abstract: Virginia, up to a recent period, has been the leading State of the Union, so far as influencing the Government was concerned. She has given direction to the general current of our politics, has influenced the legislation and public policy of the country, to a greater degree than any other State. There can be no doubt that she still holds this commanding position towards the Slaveholding States. She has thus far resisted the attempt to coerce or surprise her into political subserviency to the Gulf States, -- nor do we believe it likely that she will ever consent to assume that position. But upon her course unquestionably depends that of Maryland, Kentucky, Tennessee, North Carolina, and all the other Slaveholding States which are yet loyal to the Union:

abstract: In these words that hoary Disunionist, EDMUND RUFFIN, now of South Carolina, blusteringly characterizes what he believes to be the spirit and policy of the Union States in regard to secession. It is astonishing how universally the idea of the cowardliness of those whom they now term their enemies prevails among the South Carolina and other fire-eating fanatics.
lead_paragraph: In these words that hoary Disunionist, EDMUND RUFFIN, now of South Carolina, blusteringly characterizes what he believes to be the spirit and policy of the Union States in regard to secession. It is astonishing how universally the idea of the cowardliness of those whom they now term their enemies prevails among the South Carolina and other fire-eating fanatics. Not only do they perpetually taunt the men of the North with the most abject poltroonery, but the Border Union States also, as Tennessee and Kentucky, and even the loyal men in their own midst, are accused of a pusillanimity as contemptible as the heroism they claim for themselves is sublime. They seem to think that not only the whole of the brains of the nation belong, as WIGFALL avers, to themselves, but that they also have the monopoly of that physical or metaphysical quality known as pluck. Extravagant as it may seem, it is actually the belief of ninetenths of the South Carolina fire-eaters today, that such is the terror of their name and their superhuman prowess in warlike exploit, that did but the "Rhett Guards," or the "Whippy-Swamp Avengers," or other company of scowling heroes, raise their dread ensign in Washington or New York, SCOTT and all his hirelings, SANFORD and his Abolition cohorts, would rush helter-skelter into the Potomac and the Hudson to escape their all-devouring blades. The braggadocio of their military and political leaders, and of their press, actually realizes the absurdest types of Spanish-American rhodomontade; while their contempt for the cowardice of those of their fellow-countrymen who, at the worst, are but guilty of an intellectual disagreement with them, knows no limit. It was long a solemn article in the creed of the jolly British tar that one Briton was as good as three Frenchmen, while every man in the corps d'armee of France, in turn, as devoutly believed that one Frenchman was equal to at least half a dozen Englishmen; and neither of these theories are altogether outside of the boards of reason, -- indeed, striking confirmations of the truth of them both can easily be found in the course of the interminable wars of England with France. But your genuine fire-eating Carolina blockhead -- though, unfortunately for him, history has as yet furnished no basis for his faith -- establishes no such modest equation between himself and the twenty-seven millions of other Americans yet to be found outside of the limits of South Carolina. Indeed, with him there seems to be virtually but two divisions of the human species -- Carolinians and cowards; and what one whale is to an infinite shoal of minnows, so is one of the former to an indefinite number of the latter.

abstract: It is not always a good plan to put too many ideas in a single work. HALEVY, like a good many other men who have tried end exhausted this theory, discovered his mistake. He made a success with artists, but fired over the heads of the public, and "La Juive" in consequence has had but a spasmodic career. Mr. MARETZEK produced it in this City during his Spring campaign last year, and obtained the applause of the critics. In a pecuniary point of view, the production was not a success. With a strange lack of judgment, Mr. ULLMANN subsequently went over the same ground, and the indiscretion was attended with ruin. Last evening the Opera was revived, and an overflowing house witnessed it with satisfaction. It is good for a single night, but is evidently not relished as a permanency. The performance under Mr. MUZIO's direction was excellent. Mme. COLSON gave an admirable impersonation of the heroine, and sang the music with rare dramatic intensity. Miss HINKLEY as the Princess, was a great improvement on the lady who preceded her in the role; Signor SUSINI as the Cardinal was admirable, and Signor STIGELLI, of course, all that could be desired. The Opera will be given to-night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

abstract: We trust the Legislature at Albany will not adjourn without making effective preparations for the fearful contingencies of the coming Summer. Wild and absurd as the project may seem, indications are not wanting that JEFFERSON DAVIS seriously contemplates an invasion of the Northern States, with a view mainly to the seizure of Washington. The possession of the Capital would give the new Confederacy a prodigious prestige in the eyes of the world, -- and would of itself, if successfully accomplished, decide the course of the Border Slaveholding States.

abstract: The newly developed policy of the Government commands the hearty and cordial approval of the great mass of the people, without distinction of party. We believe we are perfectly warranted in asserting that even here, in the City of New-York, where the pressure of war, if it comes at all, will be most grievously felt, there is a general and hearty concurrence in the wisdom and necessity of the measures taken by the Administration, to vindicate the authority and maintain the supremacy of the Government of the United States.

abstract: AFRICAN COLONIZATION SOCIETY. -- A meeting to consider the objects of the African Colonization Society was held in the Church of the Pilgrims Monday evening last, when addresses were made by Rev. A.A. CONSTANTINE, a returned missionary from Africa, and now Corresponding Secretary of the Society; Prof. ROBERT CAMPBELL, a recent explorer of the Yomba country; Rev. H.H. GARNETT, Rev. ASA D. SMITH, and others. The special object of this meeting was to raise money to send out Rev. Mr. GARNETT, with a select company, as missionaries to Yomba. The plan was approved of, and resolutions indorsing the enterprise were adopted.
