abstract: RUMORED PLOT TO SEIZE THE CAPITAL. The officers of the District Militia were yesterday ordered to have a meeting at 10 o'clock this morning, in consequence of information relative to a contemplated movement for the seizure of this city by the Secessionists under McCULLOUGH. Near midnight, however, orders were issued for the assembling of the militia at their armories this morning, and officers have been engaged summoning the men ever since 5 A.M.

abstract: Three million of dollars are allotted to the Banks of New-Orleans. This is a sad damper upon the enthusiasm of secession, so that for several days past we have had no jubilant telegrams from that city. An ominous quiet has prevailed. This is the first real taste of secession. The agreeable prelude, the great theft of the United States Mint, did not last long. More money was wanted. The new loan was created, but no anxious bidders crowded around the Treasury benches entreating for the privilege of subscribing to it, notwithstanding the telegraphs so ostentatiously sent over the country, repeating the announcement that it was all subscribed for at par. All these boastings were simply confessions that the loan could not be sold at all, and to divert public attention from this disagreeable fact. Not a cent could be had in open market, in which our Government can get millions at will. The South was never flush of money, and the few that possess it regard secession with a hatred, of which we at the North have a feeble conception. It can be had of them only by pressure. A second attempt of the kind can hardly be made, which shows the very limited tether of the new Government, and explains the great anxiety that Mr. DAVIS has manifested to postpone hostilities. He cannot move or maintain large bodies of troops for want of cash. This is the sine qua non of all operations, both civil and military. In these days, success is measured by the length of purse. War no longer depends upon personal prowess, but upon the number of ships a people can put afloat, and the number of soldiers they can clothe, feed and arm. A Government that has no other resource for these objects than forced loans is not far from its end.

abstract: Some of Mr. LINCOLN'S friends having heard that a conspiracy existed to assassinate him on his way to Washington, set on foot an investigation of the matter. For this purpose they employed a detective of great experience, who was engaged at Baltimore in the business some three weeks prior to Mr. LINCOLN'S expected arrival there, employing both men and women to assist him. Shortly after coming to Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: Some of Mr. LINCOLN'S friends having heard that a conspiracy existed to assassinate him on his way to Washington, set on foot an investigation of the matter. For this purpose they employed a detective of great experience, who was engaged at Baltimore in the business some three weeks prior to Mr. LINCOLN'S expected arrival there, employing both men and women to assist him. Shortly after coming to Baltimore, the detective discovered a combination of men banded together under a solemn oath to assassinate the President elect. The leader of the conspirators was an Italian refugee, a barber, well known in Baltimore, who assumed the name of Orsini, as indicative of the part he was to perform. The assistants employed by the detective, who, like himself, were strangers in Baltimore City, by assuming to be Secessionists from Louisiana and other seceding States, gained the confidence of some of the conspirators, and were entrusted with their plans. It was arranged in case Mr. LINCOLN should pass safely over the railroad to Baltimore, that the conspirators should mingle with the crowd which might surround his carriage, and by pretending to be his friends, be enabled to approach his person, when, upon a signal from their leader, some of them would shoot at Mr. LINCOLN with their pistols, and others would throw into his carriage hand grenades filled with detonating powder, similar to those used in the attempted assassination of the Emperor LOUIS NAPOLEON. It was intended that in the confusion which should result from this attack, the assailants should escape to a vessel which was waiting in the harbor to receive them, and be carried to Mobile, in the seceding State of Alabama.

abstract: Little else was talked of, yesterday, but the war news. On emerging from their homes, men eagerly sought the morning papers, in expectation of the startling intelligence which has so long been threatened from the South, and many expressed their disappointment that affairs in the secession line were so long in coming to a focus.
lead_paragraph: Little else was talked of, yesterday, but the war news. On emerging from their homes, men eagerly sought the morning papers, in expectation of the startling intelligence which has so long been threatened from the South, and many expressed their disappointment that affairs in the secession line were so long in coming to a focus. On the cars, in the ferry and steamboats, in the hotels and bar-rooms, knots of citizens gathered, and warmly discussed the movements of the Government, and particularly the probable character of the late expeditions, their destination, and the chances of success in provisioning or reinforcing Fort Sumpter. While there was here and there one who questioned the wisdom of the step, the mass of people expressed the most earnest wish for the success of the attempt, and nine out of ten men who said anything went in strongly for sustaining the Government of the country against all traitors, North or South.

abstract: BURGLARS CAUGHT IN A CLOTHING STORE. About 4 o'clock, yesterday morning, Officer MULDOON, of the Sixth Ward, observed two men inside of LEVI'S clothing store, No.114 Bowery, and believing them to be burglars, he obtained assistance for the purpose of arresting them. A search of the premises resulted in showing that an entrance had been effected to the store through the rear window, and the burglars were found in the out-house.
lead_paragraph: BURGLARS CAUGHT IN A CLOTHING STORE. -- About 4 o'clock, yesterday morning, Officer MULDOON, of the Sixth Ward, observed two men inside of LEVI'S clothing store, No.114 Bowery, and believing them to be burglars, he obtained assistance for the purpose of arresting them. A search of the premises resulted in showing that an entrance had been effected to the store through the rear window, and the burglars were found in the out-house. Yesterday forenoon they were taken before Justice OSBORN, when they gave the names of EDWIN FORREST and WILLIAM THORNTON. Both wore clothing which was identified as having been stolen from the store, and their pockets were filled with an assortment of fancy articles. It was also ascertained that the prisoners were guilty of another burglary on Saturday night last, at the clothing establishment No. 24 Bowery -- a quantity of the goods which they obtained by the operation having been found at their lodging place, No. 58 Cherry-street. They were imprisoned for trial on both complaints.

abstract: The capture of the ship Montauk in the month of December last by a Spanish frigate off the island of Cuba, with 1,140 negroes on board, is still freshly remembered. abstract: Business at the Custom-house moves forward with its accustomed regularity, and with only trifling interruption from any causes originating with the regulations of the new Tariff. The anticipations of trouble, even by the officers, appear not to have been realized, and every day the subordinates are getting more familiar with the provisions of the new law, and experiencing less embarrassment in executing them. The reports of confusion, or misunderstanding of the provisions of the Tariff have been greatly exaggerated.

abstract: Washington was thrown into the greatest state of excitement yesterday by the publication of a dispatch announcing that hostilities had actually commenced at Charleston; that a fierce battle was progressing, and that Major ANDERSON was likely soon to suffer defeat.
lead_paragraph: Washington was thrown into the greatest state of excitement yesterday by the publication of a dispatch announcing that hostilities had actually commenced at Charleston; that a fierce battle was progressing, and that Major ANDERSON was likely soon to suffer defeat. It was soon ascertained, however, to be a wicked hoax. The Cabinet was in session during the day, and the matter of the refusal of the authorities at Charleston to allow Lieut. TALBOT to return to Fort Sumpter was discussed. This action on the part of the Secessionists is considered almost unparalleled in its treachery, and any misfortunes which may occur in consequence of it they will be held fully accountable for. The plan which has been adopted by the Administration for provisioning Fort Sumpter, our correspondent informs us, meets the approval of many military men, who believe that it will be successful; while some are doubtful in reference to it. The President, however, considers it his duty to make the effort at all hazards, and if it fails, it remains to be decided what course shall then be pursued. The Southern Commissioners are still in Washington, but consider that they have been deceived by the Administration, and intend soon to leave for the South.

abstract: An important order has just been issued by the War Department. Formerly soldiers enlisted for the army were informed, when joining, to what branch of the service, cavalry, artillery, or infantry, they would be assigned. Henceforward they will be told nothing whatever about it. They will be enlisted "for five years unless sooner discharged," and the Government reserves to itself the right to make them horse or foot soldiers, artillerists or sappers and miners, as it may see fit.

abstract: There was no particular movement of the Government forces yesterday form this port, and the public interest continued to be occupied with the expedition which has already sailed -- as is now believed --for the relief of Major ANDERSON and his command. The telegraph was eagerly watched all day; and inquiries were constant, "What's the latest news?" Every hour seemed to increase the public anxiety to know the strength of the naval and military force sent South; the character of the respective commanders, the probable plan of operations when it arrives off Charleston; whether the Carolinians are likely to open on Fort Sumpter before succor reaches it, and the prospect of success or failure.

abstract: The People ex. rel. Jehia K. Hoyt vs. The Commissioners of Taxes of the City of New-York. -- Thiscase is familiar. The relator in 1860 resided in the Eighteenth Ward of the City of New York. He admitted, under oath, before the Tax Commissioners, that he owned personal property elsewhere than in this State, exceeding his debts and liabilities, to the extent of $4,000. He also stated that such property was located in the States of New-Jersey and Louisiana, in both of which States it was taxed. The Commissioners thereupon assessed the relator for the $4,000, and he applied for a remission, which was refused. He then took the matter before the Supreme Court, where the judgment of the Commissioners was affirmed, at both Special and General Terms. Appeal was then taken to this Court, and the only matter to be determined is the locality where personal property may legally be taxed, according to the laws of this State, and the general rule of law. The relator urges that personal property is taxable where it is located only; and that were it otherwise, the owner would be subjected to repeated taxation. His property is taxed where it is located, and should not be taxed here. On the other hand, the respondents contend that the rule of law is that personal property depends for its locality upon the residence of its owner, and that the assessment is not on the property, but upon the person in respect to the property in judgment of law, personal property follows the person, and can have no independent locality governed by the place where it is deposited or employed. It was further contended that the statute was too explicit to be misunderstood on this point. Decision reserved.
lead_paragraph: The People ex. rel. Jehia K. Hoyt vs. The Commissioners of Taxes of the City of New-York. -- Thiscase is familiar. He then took the matter before the Supreme Court, where the judgment of the Commissioners was affirmed, at both Special and General Terms. Appeal was then taken to this Court, and the only matter to be determined is the locality where personal property may legally be taxed, according to the laws of this State, and the general rule of law. The relator urges that personal property is taxable where it is located only; and that were it otherwise, the owner would be subjected to repeated taxation. His property is taxed where it is located, and should not be taxed here. On the other hand, the respondents contend that the rule of law is that personal property depends for its locality upon the residence of its owner, and that the assessment is not on the property, but upon the person in respect to the property in judgment of law, personal property follows the person, and can have no independent locality governed by the place where it is deposited or employed. It was further contended that the statute was too explicit to be misunderstood on this point. Decision reserved.

abstract: FEMALE BIBLE SOCIETY. -- The Anniversary of the New-York Female Auxiliary Bible Society drew together a large audience, mostly feminine, at the Bible House, yesterday. The exercises commenced at noon, and Rev. Dr. HOLDICH presided. Rev. Mr. MCNEIL read the Forty fifth Annual Report of the Association. It gives abundant evidence of the good work which the institution is achieving in the sphere to which it is confined. The Treasurer's exhibit indicated that the receipts during the past year were $5 754 53. There have been expended in the purchase of Bibles for distribution, $768 20, and $4,586 33 have been paid to the American Bible Society. To pay Bible-readers $400 have been retained. Rev. ALBERT HUNT, of Brooklyn; Rev. Dr. HOGE, of this City, and Rev. J.C. FLETCHER, the famous missionary to Brazil, delivered interesting addresses commending the good cause, urging its zealous prosecution and demonstrating the effective usefulness of such societies. At their conclusion, officers for the ensuing year were chosen: Mrs. DAVID CODWISE, First Directress; Mrs. WM. B. ASTOR, Second Directress; Mrs. JAMES BROWN, Third Directress; Mrs. JOHN WURTS, Recording Secretary; Miss. CORNELIA L. WESTERLO, Assistant Recording Secretary; Mrs. Dr. OLIN, Corresponding Secretary; Mrs. JACOB LE ROY, Treasurer, and the audience was dismissed with a benediction.

abstract: JOS. T. BUCKINGHAM, the Nestor of journalism, who died yesterday morning in Boston, at the rise old age of eighty-two and some months, was the son of NEHEMIAH TINKER, of Windham, Connecticut, a patriot who exhausted nearly his whole property in his contributions to the War of Independence. Mr. BUCKINGHAM -- who adopted this name, being that of his mother's family, by an act of the Massachusetts Legislature -- first commenced the business of life as a farmer's apprentice at Worthington, Mass., whither his family had removed after his father's death. Subsequently, at the age of sixteen, be entered a printing-office at Walpole, N.H., where he learned the craft of FRANKLIN, and began to educate himself for higher duties. After this Mr. BUCKINGHAM led for some years an unsettled life, now as editor of some evanescent publication, and again as promoter to a company of strolling comedians. In 1806 he commenced the Polyanthus, a monthly magazine, but it proved an annual and not perennial plant, dying at the end of a year. In 1809, nothing discouraged by this failure, Mr. BUCKINGHAM again commenced a monthly serial known as the Ordeal, of which but six issues ever saw the light. Subsequently, in 1817 he started, in partnership with SAM. L. KNAPP, The New-England Galaxy and Masmic Magazine, also a monthly, which did very well until the year 1828 when he sold it. Prior to this, however, in 1824, he published the first number of the Boston Courier, a singularly able and fearless paper under his management, which he continued to edit with remarkable vigor, ability and pungency, down to 1848. Mr. BUCKINGHAM, in 1837, also started the New England Magazine, which continued in existence for several years, and formed a nursery for some of the best talent in New-England. Of books from his pen we have several, chiefly Specimens of newspaper literature, Personal Memoirs and Recollections of Editorial Life. He was several times elected to the Massachusetts Assembly, and served four times as a State Senator. Full of peculiarities and whimsical or [???] all through his career, Mr. BUCKINGHAM wielded a trenchant and graphic pen, commanding respect; while by his many genial qualities and his generous appreciation of young literary talent, he had surrounded himself in his old age with a large circle of affectionate and attentive friends. Since his surrender of active editorial duties, he has lived in handsome retirement in the classic shades of Cambridge, Mass.

abstract: A gentleman who had occasion to visit the Marshal's office yesterday, on business, was a witness to a spicy scene between RYNDERS and an Irish-American citizen, familiarly known as PADDY BURNS. The conversation running upon the condition of the country, Marshal RYNDERS, in his peculiarly emphatic manner, denounced President LINCOLN and his constitutional advisers as a set of Abolition traitors, and gave forcible expression to his desire to be relieved of all direct or indirect connection with the "whole Black Republican crew."

abstract: The chartered steamer Coatzacoalcos, Capt. GRIFFIN, arrived at this port yesterday from Indianola, Texas, after a very pleasant passage. She left the bar at Pass Cavallo, Texas, on the 31st of March, touched at Key West on the 4th inst., and landed two companies of infantry at that place. Being unable to obtain water at Key West, the steamer then proceeded to Havana, and sailed thence on the afternoon of the 6th inst. She has experienced very heavy gales during the passage. The vessels left at Pass Cavallo were the steamships Empire City, which was to sail for New-York is eight days, and was awaiting the arrival of troops from the interior, and the Star of the West, which, was also waiting for troops.
lead_paragraph: The chartered steamer Coatzacoalcos, Capt. GRIFFIN, arrived at this port yesterday from Indianola, Texas, after a very pleasant passage. abstract: The terrible calamity of war is probably upon us! Our special dispatches from Charleston, which we publish in the order of their reception, indicate that the authorities there have assumed the bloody responsibility, and are about to inaugurate the most causeless and senseless struggle against right which the world has ever witnessed. Yesterday,
lead_paragraph: The terrible calamity of war is probably upon us! Our special dispatches from Charleston, which we publish in the order of their reception, indicate that the authorities there have assumed the bloody responsibility, and are about to inaugurate the most causeless and senseless struggle against right which the world has ever witnessed. Yesterday, it appears, a formal demand was made upon Major ANDERSON to surrender Fort Sumpter -- Ex-Senator CHESNUT, Col. CHISHOLM and an Aide of Gen. BEAUREGARD, constituting the Commission detailed for that purpose. The response of Major ANDERSON, as may well be supposed, was a positive refusal to accede to the demand. The events which will follow this refusal we are left to infer from a single word, which constitutes the closing dispatch of our correspondent, and which is probably all that he was permitted to telegraph. That word, however, is sufficiently expressive: --it is WAR! The fleet which recently left this port is by this time at or near the seat of action. An officer who visited Charleston yesterday from Sullivan's Island reported that three steamers were seen hovering off the coast, and two of these must have been the Powhatan and the Illinois, which were the first to leave here, on Sunday last.

abstract: Andrew Goss vs. Conrad Foy and John F. Cleary The plaintiff sued to recover the value of his stock of goods, alleging that the defendants entered his store and wrongfully seized and sold it.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Goss vs. Conrad Foy and John F. Cleary -- The plaintiff sued to recover the value of his stock of goods, alleging that the defendants entered his store and wrongfully seized and sold it. Upon the trial it appeared, that the defendant Foy had a judgment against the former owner of the establishment, in satisfaction of which he seized the stock in the store, notwithstanding a mortgage upon the goods, which had been given to secure advances.

abstract: It is often enough said now-a-days that if the people of certain States do not wish to remain in the Union, it would be highly impolite to force said States to stay in. Now, this, like most other truisms, is true only with exceptions and limitations. More than half of the present domain of the United Slates was annexed without the consent of its inhabitants; and the same considerations, increased a million fold, that induced its acquisition, now imperatively demand its retention. When Florida, for instance, was acquired by the United States, not only were the numerous Spanish settlers in that Province not consulted as to their wishes in the premises, but so much against their will was the annexation, that, when it did occur, many of them forsook forever the Flowery Land which their fathers had possessed for centuries. Florida was annexed, nevertheless, as a national necessity, because it was essential to the peace of our frontier and the protection of our Gulf commerce that we, and not a foreign power, should have control of the peninsula which commanded the Gulf, and which for centuries had been but a rendezvous for smugglers and phates.

abstract: James Harper et al vs. Royal Chamberlain et al. In this cause Mr. J.F. Walton yesterday morning obtained an order requiring the defendants to attend and be examined in advance of the trial, upon the issues raised by the answers. The cause itself has
lead_paragraph: James Harper et al vs. Royal Chamberlain et al. -- In this cause Mr. J.F. Walton yesterday morning obtained an order requiring the defendants to attend and be examined in advance of the trial, upon the issues raised by the answers. The cause itself has been often noticed in the TIMES. It is brought by the firm of Harper & Brothers against the Directors of the late New-York City Insurance Company, to hold them to a personal liability for a policy issued by that company to Messrs. Harper, on the ground that the capital of the company was fraudulently misrepresented and exaggerated to the plaintiffs to induce them to insure.

abstract: The Allocution of Pro NONO, delivered in Secret Consistory on the 18th ult., and the speech of Count CAVOUR, in the Chamber of Deputies, at Turin, on the 25th, are among those documents that cannot but he historical. There is something almost dramatic in the antithesis presented by these two men -- the one the representative of an institution long grown utterly spectral and obsolete, the other of emancipated and regenerated Italy. It needs but to compare the calm audacity and masterly moderation of CAVOUR's speech with the rabid though impotent drivel of the Secret Consistory, to imagine pretty accurately what the next six months will bring forth.
lead_paragraph: The Allocution of Pro NONO, delivered in Secret Consistory on the 18th ult., and the speech of Count CAVOUR, in the Chamber of Deputies, at Turin, on the 25th, are among those documents that cannot but he historical. There is something almost dramatic in the antithesis presented by these two men -- the one the representative of an institution long grown utterly spectral and obsolete, the other of emancipated and regenerated Italy. It needs but to compare the calm audacity and masterly moderation of CAVOUR's speech with the rabid though impotent drivel of the Secret Consistory, to imagine pretty accurately what the next six months will bring forth.

abstract: About 4 o'clock, yesterday morning, a Policeman of the Eleventh Precinct discovered a fire on the lower floor of the extensive chair factory, Nos. 186, 188 and 190 avenue C. The firemen quickly responded to the alarm, and immense quantities of water were thrown into the building, but the flames defied all efforts to extinguish them, in consequence of the very inflammable character of the material with which the premises were filled, and the entire stock, valued at $15,000, was consumed. The buildings were of brick, four stories in height, and were [???] destroyed -- the loss, at least, amounting to between $5,000 and $6,000. They were owned by Mr. JOHN F. BUTTERWORTH, who had them fully insured. J.W. MASON & Co., furniture dealers at No. 377 Pearlstreet, hired the premises and carried on a very exclusive chair manufacturing business therein, employing to utility workmen, each of whom is a looesr to the extent of $40 or $50 by the construction of their [???]. There was a more than ordinary quantity of stock in the building, which was insured as [???] -- the aggregate amount not being more than half its value; $2,000; St. Mark's, $2,000; Williamsburgh City, $2,000; and New-York Fire and Marine, $2,000.

abstract: The first dispatches from the seat of war were received in this city about 7 o'clock this evening. The excitement caused by the meagre intelligence was most intense. Bulletins were posted at the principal hotels, where immense crowds gathered to discuss the probable results. It is almost need- ...
lead_paragraph: The first dispatches from the seat of war were received in this city about 7 o'clock this evening. The excitement caused by the meagre intelligence was most intense. Bulletins were posted at the principal hotels, where immense crowds gathered to discuss the probable results. It is almost needless to say that while there was but one opinion as to the end, there was an infinite variety of conjectures as to the modus operandi. The public sentiment is very decided that in the war inaugurated to-day the Government will prove to be the victor.

abstract: Hostilities commenced at Charleston about 4 o'clock yesterday morning! The first two guns were fired from Fort Moultrie against Fort Sumpter, when Major ANDERSON immediately replied with three of his barbette guns, and the action soon became general, and continued until it became too dark to operate with certainty, when the firing ceased, to be commenced again at daylight this morning. The dispatches from Charleston, ...
lead_paragraph: Hostilities commenced at Charleston about 4 o'clock yesterday morning! The first two guns were fired from Fort Moultrie against Fort Sumpter, when Major ANDERSON immediately replied with three of his barbette guns, and the action soon became general, and continued until it became too dark to operate with certainty, when the firing ceased, to be commenced again at daylight this morning. The dispatches from Charleston, which we publish in the order of their reception, contain various absurd statements relative to the execution done by the batteries against Fort Sumpter, telegraphed probably on the authority of those interested in having the country believe that the fortress is to be immediately reduced. It is best to await intelligence from a more reliable source before accepting all the statements made. The only definite intelligence relative to the fleet of relief vessels sent from this port and from other points, is the statement that three steamers, two of which were the Harriet Lane and the Pawnee, had made their appearance off the harbor. The impression prevailed in Charleston that an attempt would be made during the night to reinforce Fort Sumpter by means of small boats. Another impression also prevailed -- which may be considered somewhat significant -- that Major ANDERSON, from the regularity and spirit of his replies to the iron hail poured in upon him, must have more men under his command than has been supposed.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Mr. GARVIN, prosecuting for the people, Angelina Blake, indicted for larceny of $66 worth of property from Anne Lewis (both parties being colored.) The evidence showed that the detention of the stolen articles (clothing) was under the mistaken idea among ignorant people, that they have a lien upon any property of a debtor upon which they can lay their hands. The complainant had left her clothes in the prisoner's possession, and subsequently claiming them was met with a refusal accompanied with a counter claim for board. Prosecution was then set on foot. The Jury of course acquitted, and the prisoner was discharged.

abstract: Miss KELLOGG'S best success so far has been made unquestionably in Linda di Chamounix, an opera which, on its production here last season, we referred to at length as the vehicle that had established the lady's position. It was repeated last evening to one of the most fashionable audiences we have ever seen in our handsome Fourteenth-street establishment, and the public verdict fully confirmed that previously rendered by the critics. In the second act, where prima donne not unfrequently make a comparative failure of situation which is full of natural pathos, Miss KELLOGG is all that correct taste and sensibility can require. Her acting, without being visibly studied, is full of good dramatic effects, and, what is better, never loses the grace and charm of maidenhood. Vocally regarded, the role of Linda is admirably adapted to the lady's quality of voice, and especially to her style of singing We may say briefly that, in all respects, the performance was eminently satisfactory, and merited all the applause that was bestowed on it. In the last act, Miss KELLOGG introduced a new polka-finale, written by Sig. MUZIO, a very charming and effective piece.

abstract: The alleged imperfections and imprudences of the Morrill Tariff, upon which an extra session has been defended, are found to be largely exaggerated, if not entirely unfounded. Mr. BARNEY assures me that he will find no difficulty in executing the law with his present force, and that its provisions are quite as explicit as such laws are usually made, and that the changes from the previous system are not so violent and general as is supposed. A gentleman from Maryland told me today that the new tariff was doing much to keep that State loyal. He represents the iron and coal interests of the State, and he thinks the same beneficial influences will be felt in Virginia and North Carolina, in both of which States the mining interests are fast becoming paramount.

abstract: Yesterday was a day of excitements. Rumors apparently well grounded concerning the progress of affairs at Charleston flitted through Wall-street, pervaded the thoroughfares and produced sensations of surprise, indignation and rejoicings, according to the nature of the mind to which they were brought. Dis- ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was a day of excitements. Rumors apparently well grounded concerning the progress of affairs at Charleston flitted through Wall-street, pervaded the thoroughfares and produced sensations of surprise, indignation and rejoicings, according to the nature of the mind to which they were brought. Dispatches were received stating that President DAVIS had, after consultation with his Cabinet, directed Gen. BEAUREGARD to allow unmolested passage of the Federal transports with their loads of supplies for Fort Sumpter, thereby obviating immediate hostilities; others that Maj. ANDERSON and Gen. BEAUREGARD were consulting together, and the probabilities were that the Fort would be surrendered so soon as its supplies were exhausted; and still others announcing that the war had actually begun. The first-mentioned dispatch was generally credited, and the feeling was almost universal that a great moral victory had been achieved by the United States Government.

abstract: The most remarkable feature of the political complications of the day is the forbearance of the Government of the United States. The history of the world furnishes no parallel to it.  Not a solitary instance can be found in which any nation, sensitive enough to feel an injury or an insult, and powerful enough to enforce respect, has submitted to a tithe of the outrages which have been perpetrated upon the Government of the United States with entire impunity. The evidence to this purport,though tedious in the frequency of cases, extends over no very protracted period of the national history. The period of nullification may in fact be considered as its era. Under the pretext of guaranteeing the security of its own peculiar social system, a settled system of treatment was devised and applied to a portion of the Union, entirely overriding the covenants of the Constitution, and defying the requirements of law. Of other instances at our service, it might be sufficient to cite the repudiation of that clause of the Constitution which prescribes the equality of citizenship. Citizens of Northern States, employed in traffic at the South, have been liable to arrest and imprisonment without any process of law whatever. If the opportunity to seize a free negro mariner, and of subsequently selling him to pay the expense of his imprisonment, were offered, no consideration of Federal obligation prevented the seizure or the sale.

abstract: held an inquest yesterday, at No. 40 Oliver-street, upon the body of DAVID PRICE, a boy 9 years of age, who was fatally injured on Thursday afternoon while passing through South-street. It appeared that a carman backed his cart across the sidewalk, close to the stoop of a building, and just as the lad was going by, the horse became alarmed, started suddenly back, and caught the lad between the tail of the cart and the steps, crushing him in a shocking manner. He was taken home, where he died soon afterwards. A verdict of accidental death was rendered.

abstract: The Disunion conspiracy, which has for the last twenty years been gnawing at the heart-strings of the great American Republic, has at last culminated in open war upon its glittering and resplendent flag. For the first time in the history of the United States, an organized attempt is made to destroy, by force of arms, the Government which the American People have formed for themselves -- to overthrow the glorious Constitution which has made us the envy of the world. The history of the world does not show so causeless an outrage. Amid all the rebellions against government which have stained the annals of civilized and Christian nations, not one can be found which had not more, provocation than that which yesterday opened a war at Charleston upon the forces and Government of the United States. Not a solitary act of oppression, -- not a single act of wrong, -- not the faintest possible trespass upon Southern rights can be urged in extenuation of this infamous rebellion. Whatever may be the result of the war which the South has now begun, it will stand on the pages of history, for all time to come, as the blackest and most dishonoring outbreak of irrational and ferocious passion, which has ever marked the checkered annals of national progress. Whatever the leaders of this conspiracy may believe, the civilized world will have but one opinion of their conduct; they will be greeted with the indignant scorn and execration of the world.

abstract: Mr. JOHN D. AUSTEN, a lawyer, residing at Boston Mass, left home about three weeks since, while laboring under an attack of insanity, and his friends were unable to learn anything of him beyond the fact that he had taken the train for New-York. A full description of his appearance, therefore, was forwarded to the detectives in this City, and his likeness was published last week in one of the illustrated papers in the hope that information respecting him might be obtained. Yesterday morning his body was found drowned in a brook near White Plains, and from the fact that his valuables were still in his pockets andno marks of violence were exhibited, it is thought that he committed suicide while out of his mind. He was about 37 years of age.

abstract: Through all our streets last evening at a late hour the news spread with electrical rapidity that the great contest had at length commenced ten thousand armed rebels in Charleston harbor and its environs commencing an assault on Fort Sumpter, defended by Maj. ANDERSON, of the United States Army, at the head of seventy or eighty men. Everywhere ...
lead_paragraph: Through all our streets last evening at a late hour the news spread with electrical rapidity that the great contest had at length commenced -- ten thousand armed rebels in Charleston harbor and its environs commencing an assault on Fort Sumpter, defended by Maj. ANDERSON, of the United States Army, at the head of seventy or eighty men. Everywhere the news was met as if a heavy burden of anxiety had been suddenly lifted from the public mind, the great majority of our citizens hailing the intelligence as the sure "beginning of the end" -- the one thing needful, though painful to be done, before the supremacy of the laws could be vindicated, and the prosperity of the country reestablished on the basis of a Government determined and strong enough to vindicate its power and enforce the respect due to its flag.

abstract: The reverberations from Charleston harbor have brought about what months of logic would have been impotent to effect the rapid condensation of public sentiment in the Free States. The North is now a unit. Party lines have shriveled, as landmarks disappear before the outpouring of volcanic lava. The crucial test of this is New York, City the spot most tainted by the Southern poison. Not the thick insulation which the commercial
lead_paragraph: The reverberations from Charleston harbor have brought about what months of logic would have been impotent to effect -- the rapid condensation of public sentiment in the Free States. The North is now a unit. Party lines have shriveled, as landmarks disappear before the outpouring of volcanic lava. The crucial test of this is New York, City the spot most tainted by the Southern poison. Not the thick insulation which the commercial spirit puts between the conscience and duty -- not the obliquity engendered by long years of the most perverse political education -- have been able to withstand the electric fire of loyal indignation evoked by the assassin-stroke aimed at the heart of the Republic. There are now no such ardent supporters of the Government as those who have been life-long Democrats. It is a fact full of omen, and one which persons imperfectly acquainted with the impulses that lie at the bottom of the popular heart could never have anticipated, that the very roughs of the City are aroused, and bring their passionate devotion to the cause of their country. One intense, inspiring sentiment of patriotism has fused all other passions in its fiery heat. Let the Administration now know that twenty millions of loyal freemen approve its act, and imperiously demand the vindication of the integrity and majesty of the Republic.

abstract: The good people of Brooklyn have shared with us all the anxiety, the excitement and the fears of the past week. Sunday is with them a day of rest, of moral culture, and of religious instruction, and one on which, for the better development of those attainments, they visit, one and all, the house of the Lord, and particularly that one of which Mr. BEECHER is the shepherd. Yesterday was no exception to the rule, only in that there was, if possible, a more dense mass of human beings packed within the walls of that sanctuary, and a more than ordinary curiosity on the part of strangers and a more than customary solemnity pervading the congregation. It was manifestly the belief of all there that the pastor would not fail to improve the occasion by preaching to the people of this age upon the necessities and the duties of the present trying hour, and that he would deal with so grand a subject in a manner befitting its character, its importance, and its iniversal occupation of the American mind.

abstract: ATTEMPTED SUICIDE. On Friday forenoon a young lady, about 20 years of age, jumped overboard from the boat Phoenix, on the Christopher-street Ferry. abstract: THE HOMICIDE OF THOMAS EAGEN, -- THOMAS EAGEN, the young Irishman who was stabbed on Monday night last, in an affray at the billiard saloon, No. 31 Baxter-street, kept by two Italians, brothers, named ANTONIO and JORALARMO MORELLO, died on Friday at the Hospital, in consequence of his injuries. The circumstances attending the case were made the subject of an investigation on Saturday before Coroner JACKMAN, when a state of affairs was shown differing materially from what the deceased had asserted in his ante-mortem deposition. Upon his testimony the man, JORALARMO, was charged with having given the fatal blow, and by the direction of the Coroner he was committed for trial. Several witnesses on Saturday, however concurred in stating-that the accused had nothing whatever to do with EAGEN, and that the blow was struck by ANTONIO. A verdict accordingly was rendered against the latter, who was imprisoned, and his brother was released. The accused, who is a very ill-looking man, about 45 years of age, denied the charge.

The Battalion will hold meetings every evening at the same place, when all who desire to join can be enrolled. The Battalionhas adopted the following Constitution:

abstract: It is by no means impossible, after all, that what seemed at first to be a national calamity, and which rendered yesterday a memorably dark day in the experience of every patriot, was after all a substantial and crowning advantage, anticipated and provided for in the plans of the Administration.
lead_paragraph: It is by no means impossible, after all, that what seemed at first to be a national calamity, and which rendered yesterday a memorably dark day in the experience of every patriot, was after all a substantial and crowning advantage, anticipated and provided for in the plans of the Administration. Its policy has been uniform and consistent -- to protect the property of the Government, and enforce its laws. It will yield nothing belonging to it unless dispossessed by superior force, but it will not weaken the reputation of its military arm, by a reckless waste of men or means in the maintenance or attempted recapture of any comparatively valueless position. This arm is wielded by that illustrious Chief and Patriot, whose forty years of active service have never known dishonor or defeat, who, in the disappearance of our great leaders, is providentially left to us, and under whose guidance, though we may not for the time be advised of his plans, we are always sure of being led to substantial success.

abstract: All Saturday naval and military officers were in the dullest mood imaginable. They all know that, firing once commenced, it was not in the power of man to prevent the surrender of Fort Sumpter, under the circumstances. Moreover, they knew, what had been decided by the Cabinet as long since as the 2d of April, that all hope of reenforcing Major ANDERSON, by force, had been given up; and that it was only the method suggested by a distinguished engineer -- that of strategetically putting in men and provisions, without going to war -- which was intended to be carried out, and which could succeed. But when news of the first hostile shot having been fired reached the City, the result was, in their minds, a foregone conclusion. At the commandants office in the Navy-yard, everybody was as nervously excited as though the promises were besieged. When a messenger came from the town, he was frequently to impressed by the embarrassing anxiety of the authorities before him, that he stood speechless for moments in their presence.
lead_paragraph: All Saturday naval and military officers were in the dullest mood imaginable. abstract: held an inquest yesterday upon the body of GEORGE TERKNOR, a native of this City, 27 years of age, whose death resulted from taking a dose of laudanum. The deceased was formerly a clerk in the shoe store of Messrs. BIGELOW & HOAGLAND, No. 44 Day-street, but failing health compelled him to give up business, and recently he had been very despondent in mind, frequently remarking that life was a burden to him. On Friday, during the absence of his wife from home he went to a drug-store and obtained laudanum and on her return she found him lying on the bed with the empty bottle beside him. He died early on Saturday morning. The jury rendered a verdict of "suicide with laudanum."

abstract: Whereas; The laws of the United States have been for some time past, and now are opposed, and the execution thereof obstructed in the States of South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama Florida, Mississippi, Louisiana and Texas, by combinations too powerful to be suppressed by
lead_paragraph: Whereas; The laws of the United States have been for some time past, and now are opposed, and the execution thereof obstructed in the States of South Carolina, Georgia, Alabama Florida, Mississippi, Louisiana and Texas, by combinations too powerful to be suppressed by the ordinary course of Judicial proceedings, or by the powers vested in the Marshals by law, -- now, therefore, I, ABRAHAM LINCOLN, President of the United States, in virtue of the power in me vested by the Constitution and the laws, have thought fit to call forth, and hereby do call forth, the militia of the several States of the Union to the aggregate number of seventy-five thousand, in order to suppress said combinations, and to cause the laws to be duly executed.

abstract: The curtain has fallen upon the first act of the great tragedy of the age. Fort Sumpter has been surrendered, and the Stars and Stripes of the American Republic give place to the felon flag of the Southern Confederates. The defence of the fortress did honor to the gallant commander by whom it was held, and vindicated the Government under which he served.

abstract: Fort Sumpter was surrendered to the authorities of the Confederate States on Saturday afternoon, after having been bombarded incessantly since about 4 o'clock on Friday morning. We gather this fact from the mass of confused dispatches which have reached us from Charleston, -- also the additional one that those of the United States vessels which, had arrived off the harbor -- four in number -- took no part in the engagement, and made no effort to relieve the beleaguered garrison. It appears, also, that previous to the surrender considerable damage had been suffered by the Fort. The wooden structures inside had all been set on fire by a hot shot fired from Fort Moultrie, and the horrors of a conflagration were thus added to the difficulties with which the scanty garrison were obliged to cope. Numerous explosions of bombs were also caused by the fire, it being found impossible to remove them in time. It seems almost incredible that no lives were lost during the bombardment, but such, appears to be the fact. Only four of Major ANDERSON's men were wounded, -- one of them, perhaps, mortally. The Major, after the capitulation, was for a short time a guest of Gen. BEAUREGARD in Charleston. The latest dispatches received from there last night, state that the steamer Isabel has been detailed to convey Major ANDERSON and his men to this City, and that she would leave at 11 o'clock last night. The United States vessels were still outside, and would probably remain to blockade the port.

abstract: In the Matter of George Mountjoy. -- Mountjoy was this morning brought into Court, in return to a writ of habeas corpus issued by the Chief Justice of this Court. It will be remembered that he was committed to the custody of the Sheriff by Justice INGRAHAM for refusing to testify to certain matters before the Grand Jury. It appears that he so refused on the ground that his answers would tend to criminate himself and disgrace him in public estimation, and that he was not obliged to answer under such circumstances. The Justice, however, after hearing Mr. Brady for the prisoner, refused to interfere with the action of Justice INGRAHAM, and remanded the prisoner to the custody of the Sheriff.

abstract: No event which has occurred within the recollection of the present generation, it is safe to assume, ever occasioned so profound and wide spread excitement as that which has pervaded all classes since the attack upon Fort Sumpter was announced. Beginning with Saturday morning, when the first general details of the alleged engagement were published, up to a very late hour of the Light, and throughout the day and evening of yesterday, the war was the absorbing topic among all classes of citizens. The newspaper offices, particularly in Printing House-square, were besteged from an early hour in the morning on Saturday for copies of the papers containing the latest news from Charleston. A mass meeting of respectable size congregated at each corner where bulletins were posted, and where they continued to devour each item of intelligence as it was received and posted up. The regular editions being exhausted the presses were kept inceseantly at work supplying fresh editions of Extras as each succeeding dispatch was received by telegraph -- the demand almost outrunning the supply.

abstract: The same unanimity which is everywhere manifested on the question of sustaining the Union and the honor of its flag, prevails among the City military. Our reporter last evening visited the headquarters of various corps and found them alive with martial spirit. At the Seventh Regiment Armory, the men assembled in great numbers. The Fourth Campany
lead_paragraph: The same unanimity which is everywhere manifested on the question of sustaining the Union and the honor of its flag, prevails among the City military. Our reporter last evening visited the headquarters of various corps and found them alive with martial spirit. At the Seventh Regiment Armory, the men assembled in great numbers. The Fourth Campany was drilling, and during the evening, Col. LEFFERTS, addressing its members, said that it was deemed best to keep a guard at the Armory hereafter, and called on all of that company who were willing to do guard duty that night to come forward. The whole company responded to the call, except four men, who, it was stated, would have volunteered had they not understood that they could not be allowed to go home to inform their families before entering on the duty. There was great applause. The Colonel then informed the Company that but twenty men would be required, and the Captain was directed to select them. Col. LEFFERTS and Quartermaster WINCHESTER subsequently acdressed the members of the Second Company, expressing their determination to stand by the Stars and Stripes, and their belief that the whole regiment would be ready as soon as called on to march to the support of the Government. They were loudly cheered, and when Col. LEFFERTS proposed three cheers for the Stars and Stripes, there was a storm of enthusiasm.

abstract: The incidents of the last two days will live in History. Not for fifty years has such a spectacle been seen as that glorious uprising of American loyalty which greeted the news that open war had been commenced upon the Constitution and Government of the United ...
lead_paragraph: The incidents of the last two days will live in History. Not for fifty years has such a spectacle been seen as that glorious uprising of American loyalty which greeted the news that open war had been commenced upon the Constitution and Government of the United States. The great heart of the American people beat with one high pulsation of courage, and of fervid love and devotion to the great Republic. Party dissensions were instantly hushed; political differences disappeared, and were as thoroughly forgotten as if they had never existed; party bonds flashed into nothingness in the glowing flame of patriotism; -- men ceased to think of themselves or their parties, -- they thought only of their country and of the dangers which menace its existence. Nothing for years has brought the hearts of all the people so close together, -- or so inspired them all with common hopes, and common fears, and a common aim, as the bombardment and surrender of an American fortress.

abstract: The Old Dominion has reached the crisis of her existence. She stands upon the very verge of her fate. She must choose instantly and forever between the American Union and the New Confederacy. She has lost what she has long been striving for, the ability to control the conduct and decide the policy of ...
lead_paragraph: The Old Dominion has reached the crisis of her existence. She stands upon the very verge of her fate. She must choose instantly and forever between the American Union and the New Confederacy. She has lost what she has long been striving for, the ability to control the conduct and decide the policy of either. South Carolina has snatched the decision from her hands, and plunged the Southern Confederacy into War with the United States. The Federal Government has accepted the issue, and it only remains for Virginia to decide on which side she will range herself in the coming contest. Her decision will be of momentous interest to the country and the world, -- but of infinitely greater importance to herself than to anybody else.

lead_paragraph: The art of suggesting evil acts while pretending to deprecate their execution, is one of the oldest and paltriest tricks in the portfolio of a, demagogue. It is easy to inflame men by reciting imaginary wrongs, while the same time keeping on the safe side of the law by adding a prayer for "Christian forbearance." This is the tone adopted in Mayor WOOD's Proclamation, to be found in another column -- the arch-agitator of our City so wording his address as to convey an impression abroad that our "dangerous classes" are highly excited and tumultuous; whereas, in fact, the only appearance of anything like a riot which our City has yet seen, had for its object to make the editor of the Herald hang the American flag yesterday from the windows of his office.

lead_paragraph: It was reported in Washington, yesterday morning, that martial law would be proclaimed in the District of Columbia, at noon. Such, it appears, was the President's intention, but he subsequently came to the conclusion, in view of the excellent order which everywhere prevailed, and the marked sympathy for the Government which was generally exhibited, that it would be an unnecessary measure, at least for the present. The excitement relative to the condition of affairs at the South continued, though considerably modified in intensity. The miliatary precautions against an attack from the Secessionist, are rapidly. approaching perfection, and should any such enterprise be attempted now, it could only meet with the most ignominious failure. There seems to be little doubt in Washington that Fort Pickens will soon be attacked. A dispatch has been received by the Government, giving the information that Gen. BEAUREGARD has been ordered by the Montgomery authorities to proceed to Pensacola, and it is believed that he will have charge of the operations there, as at Charleston.

abstract: With a view to test as fully as possible the state of public sentiment in the City, our reporters yesterday visited the various places where merchants, business men and politicians respectively congregate, to hear their remarks touching the all-engrossing subject of the hour. The experience of yesterday ...
lead_paragraph: With a view to test as fully as possible the state of public sentiment in the City, our reporters yesterday visited the various places where merchants, business men and politicians respectively congregate, to hear their remarks touching the all-engrossing subject of the hour. The experience of yesterday demonstrates beyond all possible cavil the existence of an overwhelming feeling of attachment and devotion to the Union, the Constitution and the laws, and that, too, among all classes of the community. So general has this expression of opinion become, that all opposing sentiments are hushed to silence in the presence of the rising, swelling enthusiasm of the whole people to sustain the Government of the United States, in this its hour of trial, against all enemies, from whatever quarter they may come. The proclamation of the President, calling for 75,000 militia, was hailed with acclamation; the calm dignity of its language, and its resolute and business like tone, excited expressions of admiration, and people were heard to say that not only 75,000, but 200,000 men would respond to the call of their country, whenever the President should require them.

abstract: The one event which marred the general satisfaction of our people, yesterday, was a sweeping and most intemperate denunciation of Major ANDERSON, in the Courier and Enquirer, for his surrender of Fort Sumter. That journal does not hesitate to stigmatize him as a, traitor to his ...
lead_paragraph: The one event which marred the general satisfaction of our people, yesterday, was a sweeping and most intemperate denunciation of Major ANDERSON, in the Courier and Enquirer, for his surrender of Fort Sumter. That journal does not hesitate to stigmatize him as a, traitor to his country, -- as having betrayed the fortress he was ordered to hold, -- and as having been actually consulting the interests and serving the purposes of the enemy whom he professed to be resisting.

lead_paragraph: Now that Fort Pickens is likely to be the scene of some military and naval strategy, it may not be out of place to give a statement of the available force in Florida at the command of the Federal Government, both for land and sea service. In a naval vessel, in war time, a certain portion of the crew are told off for disembarking, should circumstances render that cource necessary. One of our correspondents lately stated that 800 men, from the St. Louis, Sabine and Brooklyn, had been put down for going over to Pickens, at a signal from Lieut. SLEMMER. abstract: "A HOME GUARD. -- Many requests, both written and oral, have been addressed to the Board of Officers of the Seventh Regiment, that they will find it consistent with their duty to remain in this City and contribute to its protection during the troublous times that are upon us. This wish is undoubtedly shared by all property-owners in New-York. * * Probably the very best disposition that could be made of the whole First Division, (numbering about 5,000 men,) in a military point of view, would be to place it and keep it on a war footing in this City. * * As a measure of security to the Federal Government, and to the lives and property of our citizens, it is hoped that the whole, or the principal portion of the First Division, will remain in New-York. Even those persons who are most anxious to prosecute a war with the South will, upon reflection, acquiesce in the propriety of this arrangement."
lead_paragraph: "A HOME GUARD. -- Many requests, both written and oral, have been addressed to the Board of Officers of the Seventh Regiment, that they will find it consistent with their duty to remain in this City and contribute to its protection during the troublous times that are upon us. Even those persons who are most anxious to prosecute a war with the South will, upon reflection, acquiesce in the propriety of this arrangement."

abstract: Shortly after 1 o'clock, on Monday morning, a fire was discovered in the Mission Chapel connected with the Calvary Episcopal Church, (Dr. HAWKS',) located in East Twenty-third-street, near Third-avenue, and known as the Church of St. James the Lesser. An alarm was raised, but the fire had made rapid progress ere the firemen arrived, and it was impossible to subdue the flames until the interior of the edifice was burned out. Services had been held in the Church on Sunday morning and afternoon, at which the Rector, Rev. JAMES TERRY, officiated, but the building was not opened in the evening. The Sexton closed the premises at 5 o'clock in the afternoon, leaving everything perfectly safe as he believed, and as yet the cause of the fire is sot positively known. The flames, however, must have broken out near the organ, in the rear part of the church, and resulted either from carelessness or through the act of an incendiary. The church was built about a year ago, and cost $15,000. It was 40 feet wide by 100 in depth, constructed of brick, with brown-stone trimmings, in the Gothic style of archictecture. The damage amounts to about $10,000, covered by insurance or $18,000, in the following companies: $6,000 in the Arctic, $6,000 in ihe Howard, $3,000 in the Brevoort, and $3,000 in the Commerce. The organ was worth $2,500. It belonged to Mr. JAMES A. BURTIS, who had an insurance of $1,500 upon it.

abstract: James K. Place and Ephraim B. Place, Respondents vs. William S. McIlvain et al., impleaded, , Appellants. This was an appeal from an order denying a motion for a new trial and also from a judgment entered on a verdict. The following are the facts of the case.
lead_paragraph: James K. Place and Ephraim B. Place, Respondents vs. William S. McIlvain et al., impleaded, &c., Appellants. -- This was an appeal from an order denying a motion for a new trial and also from a judgment entered on a verdict. The following are the facts of the case. The respondents brought their action upon a promissory note against the appellants as indorsers thereon. The defence was that the latter were discharged by as extension of time given to the maker. The cause was tried before Judge INGRAHAM without a jury by consent. Judgment for the amount, with interest, was rendered in favor of the respondents, which judgment was reversed on appeal, and a new trial ordered. On the second trial, before Judge Hilton, the appellant's counsel produced in evidence an agreed state of facts submitted on the former trial by the respective counsel, contained in Judge INGRAHAM's minutes, which statement the Court permitted to be varied by other evidence, to which ruling the appellants excepted.

abstract: There is a woman in the public eye, whose name had all along been associated, in our mind, with the 'Yankee,' 'Quack,' and 'Humbug.' But it is so no longer, and we desire to wrest her name from all such suspicious associations in all other minds. Whatever no- tions we may have of womanly delicacy and propriety, we will all admit that woman alone is the Nurse the GOOD Nurse the BEST Nurse.
lead_paragraph: There is a woman in the public eye, whose name had all along been associated, in our mind, with the 'Yankee,' 'Quack,' and 'Humbug.' But it is so no longer, and we desire to wrest her name from all such suspicious associations in all other minds. Whatever no- tions we may have of womanly delicacy and propriety, we will all admit that woman alone is the Nurse -- the GOOD Nurse -- the BEST Nurse. Whether we shall have female physicians or not is a question which most be decided by time and principle, and not as a matter of taste. Pride, prejudice, caprice and custom may as well behave themselves, for if there is really a want, there will also be a supply -- if there be a 'calling,' there will be a 'coming.' Nature and Human Society are always self-supplying, and though Art and Fashion may hinder, they cannot prevent.

abstract: of the last few days has produced some very sudden and very remarkable conversions among our newspaper neighbors. The old Harlequin of the Herald is among them. He was brought to a realizing sense of his losing condition by a deputation from the street below, who expressed the opinion that his personal comfort would be promoted by his hoisting the American Flag. He seemed to feel the force of the suggestion, but didn't happen to have such an article in his establishment. He had heard of it, but had never sailed under it. One was procured, however, after some delay, and for lack of a flag-staff, hung out of the window. Yesterday's Herald was devoted mainly to proving that it had always frowned upon secession, and that, if it's advice had been taken, the Southern rebels would have been crushed out long ago. The joke was pretty broad, -- but nobody laughed. The fact is the old Harlequin is about "played out." People are beginning to take too serious views of public affairs, to render his damnable contortions amusing. Incitements to rebellion, patronage of treason, systematic slander and defamation of the country, are very good jokes until they take effect. People then begin to think of the responsibility of the reckless scoundrels who deal in them.

abstract: One of the best acts passed by the Legislature, during its present session, is that providing for a Commission of twenty-four rep- resentative citizens, who are to draw up a new City Charter, for submission to the popular vote at the municipal election of next December.
lead_paragraph: One of the best acts passed by the Legislature, during its present session, is that providing for a Commission of twenty-four rep- resentative citizens, who are to draw up a new City Charter, for submission to the popular vote at the municipal election of next December. Of the Commissioners appointed, the great majority are every way eligible and trustworthy, one or two City log-rollers being thrown in -- possibly to aid the balance of the Commissioners, by the light of their experience, in finding out the weak and assailable points of the present Charter. In this capacity they may be of eminent service, and we trust that the Commissioners will liberally avail themselves of all such knowledge.

lead_paragraph: Conrad Wheber, Antheny Gessmonn and Christion Linherr. -- This was a motion for a receiver and injuction. The complaint alleges that the plaintiff and defendant Gessmann had formerly been partners; that their partnership had been dissolved in May last, and that Gessmann retained the partnership property; also that Gessmann has sold goods, consigned to him by the plaintiff for sale on commission, and received proceeds thereof; that on February last, Gessmann made an assignment to the defendant Linherr, in favor of his creditors, giving preference to a large amount, and that the assessment of partnership property and of the proceeds of consigned goods was fraudulent as against the plaintiff.

abstract: A few weeks since, 'Arry Jennings, keeper of the dog-fighting and rat-baiting establishment, No.22 White-street, was arrested and held to bail on a charge of being proprietor of a disorderly place, the resort of dissolute persons, subversive of public morals, and a nuisance to the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks since, 'Arry Jennings, keeper of the dog-fighting and rat-baiting establishment, No.22 White-street, was arrested and held to bail on a charge of being proprietor of a disorderly place, the resort of dissolute persons, subversive of public morals, and a nuisance to the neighborhood. The accused was held to answer at the General Sessions, but the complaint has never been brought to trial, and meanwhile, having given bail for his appearance, he has continued his reprehensible but profitable pursuit. Recently additional complaints have been made against Jennings, and Capt. Petty, of the Fifth Ward, on Monday nightmare a "descent" upon his place, arresting him as well as four men, named George Sabert, Geo. Erben, Jas. Dodge and William Bass, who were caught in the act of assisting at a rat-bait, and about thirty others, who were witnessing the sport. The prisoners were held for examination.

abstract: Riley Loomis et al. vs. Nicholas Decker. -- This is an appeal from a judgment of the Marine Court. The action was brought for goods sold and delivered to the defendant in 1852, on a credit of eight months. All the allegations in the complaint are admitted, the defendant relying solely upon the statute of limitations as a defence. At the commencement of the action a new bill was rendered by the defendant, upon which the defendant wrote plaintiffs a letter, in which it appears he promised to make it all satisfactory. It was contended that upon this letter there was sufficient to take the case out of the statute. The Court so held, and rendered judgment for plaintiffs. As to whether these words were sufficient to take the case out of the statute is the only question to be argued on this appeal. The Court reserves its decision.
lead_paragraph: Riley Loomis et al. vs. Nicholas Decker. -- This is an appeal from a judgment of the Marine Court. The action was brought for goods sold and delivered to the defendant in 1852, on a credit of eight months. As to whether these words were sufficient to take the case out of the statute is the only question to be argued on this appeal. The Court reserves its decision.

abstract: A rumor prevailed in Washington, yesterday, that Fort Pickens had been attacked, but it could not be traced to any responsible source, and was undoubtedly untrue. The event, however, will probably be not much longer delayed. The Cabinet is almost constantly in session, deliberating upon the grave questions which have been called up by the attack upon the Government, and in deciding upon the plans of operations presented to them by the military and naval authorities. Much anxiety prevails in Washington as to the course which Virginia is likely to pursue in the present crisis, and opinions appear to be pretty equally divided, that the Convention will decide to secede immediately, and that it will vote to keep the State on the side of the old Union. It is quite generally believed, however, that should the Convention vote to secede, the people will reject its action. Virginia, it is thought, has too many interests at stake which would be jeopardized by a war against the Government, which secession would oblige her to engage in at once. The Convention was in secret session yesterday, and the result of the debate is not yet known.

abstract: The COTTON market opened on the week with but little inquiry, and some difficulty was experienced in maintaining quotations. Itrallied, however, on Thursday, under the influence of the American advices brought by the Etna. The sales for the week foot up 46,000 bales, of which 6,000 were taken by speculators, and 6,500 for export. The market closed firm, at the quotations of last Friday.

abstract: Some doubts have been expressed regarding the reliability of the widely-circulated statements to the effect-that a famine was prevailing in parts of Mississippi. We are permitted to publish the appended extracts from a private letter received in this City, a few days since. It is dated at a town in Hinds County, and would indicate that scarcity prevailed in that vicinity at least.

abstract: From the progress of the inventive arts, the chances of war among nations possessing an equal amount of courage and endurance are almost exactly measured by the amount of money a belligerent can command. Money is equivalent to numerical superiority in men, in ship, in means of locomotion and subsistence, and in the perfection and completeness of instruments of destruction.
lead_paragraph: From the progress of the inventive arts, the chances of war among nations possessing an equal amount of courage and endurance are almost exactly measured by the amount of money a belligerent can command. Money is equivalent to numerical superiority in men, in ship, in means of locomotion and subsistence, and in the perfection and completeness of instruments of destruction. Success is no longer an attribute of a particular nationality, or the fortune of a particular General, or a matter of accident, but depends upon mass, and the skill with which this is wielded. The combatant excelling in these two conditions must in the end win, no matter what reverses it may at first suffer from want of preparation, or training, or habitude.

abstract: There is undoubtedly a strong secession feeling in Maryland, but it is clearly overborne by the Union sentiment which pervades the State. Maryland has not one single interest in common with South Carolina, which is the ringleader of this rebellion, or with any of the other States which she has succeeded in dragging into her foul conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: There is undoubtedly a strong secession feeling in Maryland, -- but it is clearly overborne by the Union sentiment which pervades the State. Maryland has not one single interest in common with South Carolina, which is the ringleader of this rebellion, or with any of the other States which she has succeeded in dragging into her foul conspiracy. If she were to link her fortunes with the new Confederacy, her interests could receive neither care nor protection, -- she would be utterly powerless to control their policy and would sink into rapid and steady decay. Her thinking men are fully conscious of these facts, and have, from the beginning, resolutely and effectively resisted the machinations which the Secessionists have brought to bear upon her.

abstract: The intelligence from Charleston is to the effect that Major ANDERSON went on board the steamer Baltic late on Monday afternoon from the steamer Isabel, off Charleston Bar, and that the Baltic was on her way to New-York. A handsome salute was fired by the fleet when Major ANDERSON was transferred to the Baltic. If this can be relied on, the defender of Fort Sumter and the entire command will probably arrive here some time this evening, or early to-morrow morning. It is understood that a fitting reception both by the military and the people will be extended to him. The steamer's landing is at the foot of Canal-street, though the troops, and perhaps the Major himself, will be landed at Fort Columbus, Governor's Island. The severe easterly storm of yesterday will somewhat prolong their trip to New-York.

abstract: Notwithstanding the rain, a large concourse of ladies and gentlemen assembled at the Armory of the Seventh Regiment, last evening, to witness the semi-monthly Battalion drill. The splendid movements of the soldiers were witnessed with additional interest, in view of the fact that they may be shortly called into active service. In the room of each Company, at the Armory, is a scroll for the signatures of such members of the Company as desire to volunteer their services to the Federal Government whenever wanted. A large majority of the members have already signed the papers, and there is little doubt that the Seventh Regiment will be a unit in responding to the call of their country whenever their services are needed.

abstract: the telegraphic dispatches of the "Special Correspondent" of the Tribune, at Montgomery, announced some weeks since that if Rhode Island should reelect Gov. SPRAGUE, that State would at once pronounce for the new Confederacy. Gov. SPRAGUE has been reelected, and represents the conservative sentiment of the State. He received the entire Democratic vote, and a very considerable vote from conservative Republicans, who feared that the policy of the Administration might involve the country in a sectional war. But he does not pronounce for the Montgomery Constitution, nor give the slightest countenance to the treasonable rebellion which threatens the overthrow of the Government. On the contrary he was among the first of our Northern Governors to tender to the Government the military services of his State. Rhode Island rallies nobly and unanimously to the defence of the Stars and Stripes, and Gov. SPRAGUE announces his determination to command his troops in person.

abstract: Government at Montgomery has no intention of omitting opportunities of inflicting damages upon the North. We have it announced that letters-of-marque and reprisal are already issued, and that privateers will be found in abundance to avail themselves of this license to pillage the shipping of Northern owners. Adventurers who may be tempted to this speculation may as well understand, however, that the business has certain risks from which ordinary and more legitimate pursuits are exempt. These letters-of-marque will have no validity, and obtain no recognition from the maritime Powers. They issue from a Government which is unacknowledged by any foreign State, and the authority of which is disputed by the constitutional Government of the entire Union. Any skipper, therefore, who ventures to trade upon no sounder warrant than these, exposes himself to the penalties of piracy; and, in fact, might quite as safely proceed upon his cruise without any papers at all. And from the execution of those penalties escape will not be had as cheaply as from the pains attached to slave-trading, and other violations of international law.

abstract: The war feeling in Brooklyn, and in fact throughout Long Island, is rapidly reaching that point when something must be done; in a word, the people are spoiling for a fight. Recruiting offices have been opened at different points, and those in charge expect to be able to fill up a Regiment at an early day. The regular State militia are drilling constantly in the State and City armory, and also evenings in the streets. The Regiments are rapidly filling up.

abstract: The gentlemen who gathered before the American Standard office, in Jersey City, on Tuesday night threatened that if the Stars and Stripes were not displayed during yesterday they would assemble at night and demolish the office. During yesterday a large number of the most influential citizens waited upon the editor and proprietor, and endeavored to prevail upon them to display the flag, but they in all cases refused to comply. A riot being anticipated, the Mayor sent a communication to the Chief of Police, yesterday afternoon, ordering them out.
lead_paragraph: The gentlemen who gathered before the American Standard office, in Jersey City, on Tuesday night threatened that if the Stars and Stripes were not displayed during yesterday they would assemble at night and demolish the office. During yesterday a large number of the most influential citizens waited upon the editor and proprietor, and endeavored to prevail upon them to display the flag, but they in all cases refused to comply. A riot being anticipated, the Mayor sent a communication to the Chief of Police, yesterday afternoon, ordering them out.

abstract: We are in receipt of very many letters from subscribers in the City, complaining that the TIMES does not reach them until a very late hour, and that copies cannot be procured at the news-stands. We can only urge in excuse that the recent increase in our circulation has been far more rapid than we were prepared for, -- and that we have frequently been unable to supply the demand until a very late hour in the morning. We have taken measures which will, we trust, obviate the difficulty hereafter.
