abstract: The friends of Hon. ROGER A. PRYOR of Virginia, should look sharp after that gentleman and have him immediately taken care of. The hydropathic treatment would probably best suit his case, the water being as near congelation as possible, and copiously applied to his head and the upper part of his spine. An emollient vegetarian diet should also be enforced against him, with plenty of soda in the bread, and nothing heating or inflammable in the broths or other tepid drinks prepared for his principal meal. With these precautions adopted, we indulge good hope that Mr. PRYOR may yet be restored to the ranks of reasonable men -- his intellect in its normal state, undoubtedly possessing certain sharp and glittering qualities which we cannot patiently see dimmed and destroyed without making an effort for their preservation.

abstract: It is shrewdly suspected by many who profess to be familiar with Mayor WOOD'S mode of doing business, that the County of New-York is about being saddled with a sum of sixty or seventy thousand dollars, in compensation for injuries to be inflicted on a small and unremunerative daily paper, owned by His Honor's brother, and heretofore published exclusively in His Honor's interest. This piece of newspaper property has been long in the market vainly seeking a purchaser -- now offered to this man and then to that -- placed at the disposal of all factions or fractions of factions "for a song;" and yet clinging to its present unhappy owner with the tenacity ascribed to a widow's curse.
lead_paragraph: It is shrewdly suspected by many who profess to be familiar with Mayor WOOD'S mode of doing business, that the County of New-York is about being saddled with a sum of sixty or seventy thousand dollars, in compensation for injuries to be inflicted on a small and unremunerative daily paper, owned by His Honor's brother, and heretofore published exclusively in His Honor's interest. This piece of newspaper property has been long in the market vainly seeking a purchaser -- now offered to this man and then to that -- placed at the disposal of all factions or fractions of factions "for a song;" and yet clinging to its present unhappy owner with the tenacity ascribed to a widow's curse.

abstract: The demonstrations of Monday last, which produced so salutary an effect upon the Herald, and compelled that establishment to hang out the Banner of the Union, were continued yesterday. The people, excited by the events of the hour, and their numbersaugmented by thousands, appeared in Printing-House Square about noon, with the design of asking "a decent regard to the opinions of mankind" on the part of the Day Book, whose publication-office is in the neighborhood of Tammany. Eight or ten thousand persons gathered before this establishment, and by shouts and outcries requested that they should "hoist the American Ensign" upon their bare and defiant flagstaff. A Committee of three persons entered the place, and requested the proprietor to respect the sentiments of the people so far as to hoist the Stars and Stripes. Before the Committee had time to report progress, a splendid new American ensign, 20 by 30 feet, was hoisted on the NEW-YORK TIMES building, instantly attracting the notice of the surging multitude below, who greeted the flag with loud and repeated cheers. Immediately succeeded a volley of loud groans for the Day Book, which had refused to hoist the Stars and Stripes. The Sunday Times borrowed an American flag from Tammany, and lowered it from their window, which was greeted with an outburst of huzzas. Seeing the increasing excitement, a change came over the proprietor, and a person was dispatched to purchase a flag. In a few moments the Day Book ran up the old flag to the top of their staff. The sight of its starry folds flying over the secession concern caused tremendous cheering.

abstract: It has been the misfortune of Government, throughout its contest with the seceding States, to have acted upon a policy purely negative in dealing with a party acting on a thoroughly positive one, and straining every nerve to accomplish its objects, before we could understand their full designs, or defeat them when discovered. Mr. BUCHANAN'S Cabinet was in league with the traitors, and purposely disarmed our forts, and scattered our army and fleet. Mr. LINCOLN was forced by his position to assume the parental attitude, and entreat the erring States to return.

abstract: The mystery which has enveloped the naval expedition to Charleston is at last somewhat cleared up by our Washington correspondent. The supposition that it was simply a feint, to draw the attention of the Government of the Confederate States from more important points, proves to be incorrect. The purpose was to provision Fort Sumter by means of boats, and the steam-tugs were provided to tow them into the harbor. Why the attempt was not made is not yet explained, but it was probably in consequence of some misunderstanding caused by the failure of Lieut. TALBOT to reach Fort Sumter with dispatches from the Government. The stories about a misunderstanding between the Administration and Gen. SCOTT cre entirely untrue.
lead_paragraph: The mystery which has enveloped the naval expedition to Charleston is at last somewhat cleared up by our Washington correspondent. abstract: Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS' bid to Virginia is a master-stroke of policy. He says to her, "Secede, make me Despot, and I will make your capital the seat of my Government." The State will very probably catch at the gilded bait. Mr. DAVIS well knows that he cannot carry on a campaign in the seceding States. His army, wherever placed, would soon starve, if collected in masses. All his dominions are barren of food. Great distress already prevails for the want of it among all classes. The only grain raised by them is corn. Some pork is grown, but no beef. The alternatives presented to him, consequently, are, to disband; to supply himself by purchase; or to move his forces to a theatre where food can be seized, so as to make war support war. Soldiers must live, and when hungry they are not very scrupulous as to the party who feeds them. The great crop of Virginia is wheat. The central and western counties raise a large amount of excellent beef. Towards this favored land, so well fitted for military operations, Mr. DAVIS, in the lack of cash, casts his longing eyes; and he tells its people if they will make him King he will transfer his army to their soil, and fight their battles!
lead_paragraph: Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS' bid to Virginia is a master-stroke of policy. He says to her, "Secede, make me Despot, and I will make your capital the seat of my Government." abstract: A telegram from Montgomery announces that JEFFERSON DAVIS "sees" the proclamation of President LINCOLN, and "goes seventy-five thousand better." We speak in language appropriate to the game of brag -- this being the game which the Southern Confederates seem at present intent on playing. To drop metaphor, however, it will be seen from a telegram in another column, that JEFFERSON DAVIS to-day issues a call for an additional force of "one hundred and fifty thousand men," as a reply to President LINCOLN'S requisition on the various loyal States for a volunteer force of half that amount. This is clearly a game of brag, and nothing more, the traitors transferring to public affairs the familiar strategy of the gambling house.

abstract: The public mind of old Virginia is to-day boiling like one of the ocean's great whirlpools; or rather, I should say, rushing like the Gulf Stream's torrent; for it has ceased to meet in jarring conflict, resulting in a round of policy without progress, but is dashing onward to action decided, open and irrevocable. What that action is, I need not repeat; I have already signified it clearly enough in the TIMES.
lead_paragraph: From Our Special Correspondent.

Two of
lead_paragraph: CONCERTS. -- The sound of the drum is not the only music with which the City is rejoiced just now. To-day and tonight we are promised no fewer than four concerts. First in musical importance is the third subscription soirce of the Orion Society at Irving Hall -- a superb entertainment, with full orchestra, chorus, , and a programme equal to the best that the Philharmonic Society has given us this season. Two of the best conductors in the City officiate on the occasion -- Mr. ANCHUTZ and Mr. CARL BERGMANN. In addition to this important concert, we direct attention to Mr. APTOMMAS' Matinee, (Dodworth's,) at which Miss ROWCROFT and Mr. SATTER will assist; to Mr. LOUIS DACHAEUR'S, (Dodworth's,) where the programme is partly sacred and partly secular; and to a Literary and Musical Soiree by Miss C.S. WORRALL, who is happily gifted with the power to sing, play and recite, at Clinton Hall.

abstract: A roll like that of a drum -- like that which will reverberate this afternoon through the streets of New-York, has passed over the City. A gathering enthusiasm, unparalleled since the early days of the Revolution, thrills through the stores, startles Wall-street, and palpitates in the banks. Every gun fired at Fort Sumter has found an echo here, which instead of fading into a mere voice, like the classic nymph, has started up in the shape of brawny men and bristling bayonets.
lead_paragraph: A roll like that of a drum -- like that which will reverberate this afternoon through the streets of New-York, has passed over the City. A gathering enthusiasm, unparalleled since the early days of the Revolution, thrills through the stores, startles Wall-street, and palpitates in the banks. abstract: The patriotism of the loyal States is at last aroused, our people gradually realizing that an attack on the National Government is no longer confined to the bombast of Southern speeches, but has become an active and embodied principle, dominant in seven of the extreme Southern States, and struggling for impious ascendency in all.
lead_paragraph: The patriotism of the loyal States is at last aroused, our people gradually realizing that an attack on the National Government is no longer confined to the bombast of Southern speeches, but has become an active and embodied principle, dominant in seven of the extreme Southern States, and struggling for impious ascendency in all. Naturally, and as a tribute of honest respect to our late brethren, we were slow to suspect them of deliberate treason -- reluctant to let the idea get lodgment in our minds, that any considerable portion of American citizens could be brought to unite in so foul and causeless a conspiracy. Great latitude was allowed in estimating the fiery expressions of Cotton State stump eloquence, -- the loyal States feeling conscious of their strength, and reposing in complacent, and even amused, security, while listening to the bluster and braggadocio in which certain blatant captains of the "Gulf Squadron" have lived and moved and had their being for the past ten or a dozen years.

abstract: The patriotic enthusiasm that has swept this City with a whirlwind of Union demonstrations, continued unabated yesterday. The universal display of the American colors in every available locality; the parading of the Boston troops through the streets, on their way to Washington; the busy preparations of the Seventh Regiment; the flocking of crowds to the numerous recruiting stations; the arrival of Major ANDERSON and the veterans of Fort Sumter; the running to and fro of military men; the resonance of martial music; the reception and discussion of the war bulletins from the South, made the occasion one of the most exciting in the annals of New-York City. Below we give succinct details of the various demonstrations:
lead_paragraph: The patriotic enthusiasm that has swept this City with a whirlwind of Union demonstrations, continued unabated yesterday. abstract: Gen. JAMES A. McDOUGALL has been declared United States Senator for California, for the next six years. Do you remember Senator DOUGLAS' prophecy, as he punched the ribs of BURLINGAME just before the last election? "Won't it be a splendid sight, BURLINGAME, to see McDOUGALL returned from California, BAKER from Oregon, and DOUGLAS and Uncle Abe all at Washington on together?" But, don't you, like our folks, "holler before you're out of the woods."
lead_paragraph: From Our Own Correspondent.

abstract: -- Some school-boys in Le Roy, a few days ago, took the liberty of making a target of the school-house, not knowing that Mr. Olmstead, the teacher, was in the building. The shot went through the door, and some of them lodged in Mr. Olmstead's face and neck. He did not sustain any serious injuries.
lead_paragraph: -- Some school-boys in Le Roy, a few days ago, took the liberty of making a target of the school-house, not knowing that Mr. Olmstead, the teacher, was in the building. abstract: one of the men on board the ship Witchcraft at the time she was lost, states that the lights on Hatteras and Body Island were both in sight, the ship heading northwest, the wind from northeast. By an observation of a star had some time before, the Captain judged himself north of the place where she struck. It was 4 A.M., and the watch had been called to 'bout ship, and were hauling up the mainsail at the time. In half an-hour she was in pieces, having listed off shore, the heavy sea had a full break on her. Mr. BLISS started to swim for the beach, the boats being all stove, and succeeded in reaching it after having drifted two miles to the southward. The whole number on board when leaving Callao was 31, of which 17 came ashore, including MOSES SMITH, of Pembroke, Mass., a seaman who died from exhaustion, and was buried on the beach. Of those known to be lost, are Capt. JOHN HAYES, wife and child, late of the British ship John Phillips, who had sold his vessel in Australia. It is believed that either Capt. HAYES or his wife has a father in this city. The chief mate, PITTS; second mate, CASS; WM. CADIH, steward; SMITH, cook; MOSES SMITH, seaman, are also among the lost. Of the fourteen missing, some were killed by the falling spars.

abstract: Proclamation by Edwin D. Morgan, Governor of the State of New-York: The President of the United States, by proclamation and through the Secretary of War, by formal requisition, has called upon this State for a quota of seventeen Regiments, of seven hundred and eighty men each, to be immediately detached from the Militia of this State, to serve as Infantry or Riflemen for a period of three months, unless sooner discharged.

abstract: Sweet & Faulkner, Appellants, vs. D.N. Barney, Respondent. -- This case was next called and argued. The United States Express Company undertook to deliver to the People's Bank a certain package of money. They delivered it to the messenger of the Bank, from whom it was stolen. The Court below held that the Express Company was not liable, as the delivery was sufficient. This is the point of appeal, the appellants claiming that the delivery was not sufficient. The respondents urge that the delivery was in accordance with custom, and that to be express forwarders was not to be common carriers.
lead_paragraph: Sweet & Faulkner, Appellants, vs. D.N. Barney, Respondent. -- This case was next called and argued. The United States Express Company undertook to deliver to the People's Bank a certain package of money. They delivered it to the messenger of the Bank, from whom it was stolen. The Court below held that the Express Company was not liable, as the delivery was sufficient. This is the point of appeal, the appellants claiming that the delivery was not sufficient. The respondents urge that the delivery was in accordance with custom, and that to be express forwarders was not to be common carriers.

abstract: Gov. LETCHER, of Virginia, yesterday commenced active opposition to the operations of the Government, by obstructing the entrance to Norfolk Harbor, by sinking boats, so that the vessels-of-war now at the Gosport Navy-yard cannot be taken out. The news was brought to Baltimore by the captain of a steamer which arrived from Norfolk yesterday.
lead_paragraph: Gov. LETCHER, of Virginia, yesterday commenced active opposition to the operations of the Government, by obstructing the entrance to Norfolk Harbor, by sinking boats, so that the vessels-of-war now at the Gosport Navy-yard cannot be taken out. The news was brought to Baltimore by the captain of a steamer which arrived from Norfolk yesterday. He also reports that the Custom house had been broken into, and a large quantity of arms seized. The Revenue cutter at Norfolk had also been boarded, and the guns taken off. Gov. LETCHER has issued a proclamation, in which he recognizes the independence of the Confederate States, and says that the President has no power to call for any extraordinary force to make war on a foreign Power. There happens to be a slight difference of opinion, however, between President LINCOLN and Gov. LETCHER, as to the independence of the Confederate States having been yet achieved.

abstract: Capt. PEARSON, of a Norfolk steamer, arrived in this city this morning.. He reports that the main entrance to the harbor of Norfolk has been obstructed by the sinking of small boats by order of Gov. LETCHER. Capt. PEARSON says that he was compelled to go over the flats, and states that the object is to prevent the Government vessels leaving as ordered.

abstract: [General Orders, No. 20.] The Brigadier General Commanding is happy to congratulate the troops under his command, on the brilliant success which has crowned their gallantry, privations and hardships, by the reduction of the stronghhold in the harbor of Charleston. This feat of arms has been accomplished after a severe cannonading of about thirty-three hours, in which all the troops have indicated, by their daring and bravery, that our cause must and shall triumph.

abstract: Abraham Laggett, Respondent, vs. The Bank of Sing Sing, Appeliant. -- The assignor of the plaintiff was one of the charter members of the Bank of Sing Sing Association. Section 3 of the articles of Association provided: "No share or shares shall be transferable on which any call for an installment of capital, or any interest on such installment, shall remain unpaid, nor unless the stockholder making the transfer shall previously discharge all debts due by him or her to said Association, or shall have remaining capital stock untransferred sufficient to cover and secure the amount that he or she may owe to said Association." Subsequently the assignor made an assignment of his share of stock to the plaintiff; and at the time such assignment was made, the bank held his note for $1,900, which had not matured. The Referee and the Court below held that as the note had not matured at the time of notice of assignment, the Bank had no lien upon the stock assigned, as security for the amount.
lead_paragraph: Abraham Laggett, Respondent, vs. The Bank of Sing Sing, Appeliant. -- The assignor of the plaintiff was one of the charter members of the Bank of Sing Sing Association. Subsequently the assignor made an assignment of his share of stock to the plaintiff; and at the time such assignment was made, the bank held his note for $1,900, which had not matured. The Referee and the Court below held that as the note had not matured at the time of notice of assignment, the Bank had no lien upon the stock assigned, as security for the amount.

abstract: REMARKABLE SUICIDE OF AN UNHAPPY WOMAN. -- Mrs. SUSAN REEK, an Englishwoman, 40 years of age, was found dead in bed yesterday morning, at the house No. 424 Third avenue, under circumstances of melancholy interest. Very nearly ten months ago she obtained a divorce from her husband, in the Court of Common Pleas, upon the ground of ill-treatment, and during the subsequent period she has lived at the house of Mr. SPRINGSTED, in Third-avenue, with whose family she was on terms of intimacy. Since obtaining the divorce she has at times exhibited much objection, in consequence of her unhappy domestic affairs; and still entertaining feelings of love for her former husband, a short time since she proposed to him that they should again live together. To this he would not assent, as he had formed an illigal relationship with a woman in New-Haven, and Mrs. REEK was rendered still more miserable by the refusal. Finally she conceived the idea of ending her troubles, in this life at least, by poisoning herself, and the result has shown that her preparations for the purpose were made with great deliberation. Last Friday she informed Mr. SPRINGSTED's family that it was her intention to take the train for New-Haven, in order to see Mr. REEK and win him back to herself, but that on Tuesday she would be home again. The poor woman, however, did not do as she had said. Retiring to her room she replaced her ordinary dress with a bridal robe of pure white, with under-clothing to match; then, having arranged her toilet with great care, she drank two ounces of laudanum, lay down with composed limbs and folded hands and expired, her features retaining the placidity of sleep. Yesterday her protracted absence alarmed the family, and, suspecting the truth of the matter, the door of her room was forced open only to find the conjecture verified. Coroner GAMBLE was notified to hold an inquest in the case, and a post mortem examination by Dr. WOOSTER BEACH resulted in showing that death had been produced by laudanum, and that life had been extinct nearly a week. Upon the table in the room of deceased the following note was found:

Since obtaining the divorce she has at times exhibited much objection, in consequence of her unhappy domestic affairs; and still entertaining feelings of love for her former husband, a short time since she proposed to him that they should again live together. To this he would not assent, as he had formed an illigal relationship with a woman in New-Haven, and Mrs. REEK was rendered still more miserable by the refusal. Finally she conceived the idea of ending her troubles, in this life at least, by poisoning herself, and the result has shown that her preparations for the purpose were made with great deliberation. Last Friday she informed Mr. SPRINGSTED's family that it was her intention to take the train for New-Haven, in order to see Mr. REEK and win him back to herself, but that on Tuesday she would be home again. The poor woman, however, did not do as she had said. Retiring to her room she replaced her ordinary dress with a bridal robe of pure white, with under-clothing to match; then, having arranged her toilet with great care, she drank two ounces of laudanum, lay down with composed limbs and folded hands and expired, her features retaining the placidity of sleep. Yesterday her protracted absence alarmed the family, and, suspecting the truth of the matter, the door of her room was forced open only to find the conjecture verified. Coroner GAMBLE was notified to hold an inquest in the case, and a post mortem examination by Dr. WOOSTER BEACH resulted in showing that death had been produced by laudanum, and that life had been extinct nearly a week. abstract: Men never realize the rapidity with which a revolution moves. Three months ago a person would have been regarded as a madman who had predicted the present state of affairs, which are but the logical and inevitable sequences of premises as pronounced as are the events now before us.
lead_paragraph: Men never realize the rapidity with which a revolution moves. Three months ago a person would have been regarded as a madman who had predicted the present state of affairs, which are but the logical and inevitable sequences of premises as pronounced as are the events now before us. It was perhaps too much to expect that the Administration, recently installed in Washington, and having hardly a thought of duties differing from official routine, should match in energy and promptitude, and in a proper appreciation of the crisis, a party that for twenty years has been maturing its plans, that for eight years past has administered nearly every department at Washington for their direct promotion, and had corrupted its officials and the army and navy to such an extent as to remove, apparently, every obstacle to its schemes -- the capture of our National Capital, and the subversion of our Government. The plan had long been well matured.

abstract: Hunt vs. Mootrie. -- This is an appeal from the decision of the General Term affirming the decision of the Surrogate in the matter of the probate of the will of Benjamin F. Hunt, deceased. It appears that the deceased at the time of executing the will in question, was a resident of Charleston, S.C. The will was executed with all those formalities requisite to admit it to probate in this State, except that it lacked as is claimed one essential, the testator did not inform the subser-bling witnesses of the fact that such was his will, but simply acknowledged the signature and seat at the foot of the instrument to be his band and seal. The witnesses, it appears, had no knowledge of the fact that they were witnesses to testator's will, except from certain vague information which they received from another person who was cognizant of the fast. It is not disputed that the laws of South Carolina were not fully complied with. But that being only the testator's domicil, and the State of New-York his residence, the the question arises, whether the law of the domicil is to prevail, or whether, his residence being in the State of New-York, the statute of this State was sufficiently complied with, which declares that the testator shall declare in the presence of his subscribing witnesses the instrument to be his last will and testament. The Court, after hearing quite an elaborate argument by counsel, in which the questions of domicil and residence were thoroughly discussed, reserved its decision.
lead_paragraph: Hunt vs. Mootrie. -- This is an appeal from the decision of the General Term affirming the decision of the Surrogate in the matter of the probate of the will of Benjamin F. abstract: The steamship Baltic, Capt. FLETCHER, which left Charleston Bar at 8 P.M. on the 8th inst., came up to the City and anchored off the Battery at 1 P. M., to-day. She had flying from her mainmast head the flag which lately waved over Fort Sumter, and at her foremast-head the flag which was hauled down when Fort Moultrie was evacuated.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Baltic, Capt. FLETCHER, which left Charleston Bar at 8 P.M. on the 8th inst., came up to the City and anchored off the Battery at 1 P. M., to-day. She had flying from her mainmast head the flag which lately waved over Fort Sumter, and at her foremast-head the flag which was hauled down when Fort Moultrie was evacuated. The Harriet Lane, Capt. FAUNCE, for New-York, also the Pawnee, with her troops, and the Pocahontas, fur Norfolk, sailed in company with the Baltic. The Powhatan was not, nor had she been, at Charleston. The Pawnee did not arrive at Charleston Bar until after the surrender. During the bombardment the fleet remained off the Bar, the wind blowing a gale from the Southeast, rendering the fleet useless to Fort Sumter.

abstract: Too much praise cannot be given to the conduct of the Metropolitan Police in the present emergency. In all scenes of excitement they appear as if summoned by magic, not harshly exerting their authority to disperse the crowd, but rather allaying the stormy passions around them by their unvarying good humor, coupled with a clear determination and ability to do their duty.
lead_paragraph: Too much praise cannot be given to the conduct of the Metropolitan Police in the present emergency. In all scenes of excitement they appear as if summoned by magic, not harshly exerting their authority to disperse the crowd, but rather allaying the stormy passions around them by their unvarying good humor, coupled with a clear determination and ability to do their duty. Even those journals heretofore most vehement in causelessly reviling them, have been compelled to demand their aid and acknowledge their efficiency -- the very men most prominently identified with opposition to their organization having been the first to need and receive their protection when threatened by the just indignation of a loyal and high-spirited people.

abstract: The Naugatuck Transportation Company vs. The Schooner George Gillmer. This was a libel filed by the owners of the steamboat Ansonia to recover about $800, the amount of the damages occasioned to her by a collision with the schooner, which occurred about noon on the 19th of May, 1858. The steamboat
lead_paragraph: The Naugatuck Transportation Company vs. The Schooner George Gillmer. This was a libel filed by the owners of the steamboat Ansonia to recover about $800, the amount of the damages occasioned to her by a collision with the schooner, which occurred about noon on the 19th of May, 1858. The steamboat was on her accustomed course between Bridgeport and New-York, and the schooner was bound from Madison, Conn., to New-York. The collision took place near Hunt's Point. As the steamer came round that point her master saw the schooner on the south side of the channel, in the wind. She came round on her starboard tack close hauled, heading north north-east. The wind was east by north or east north-east. As to the amount of wind there was great conflict of testimony. The libelant claiming that it was a working breeze, the claimants insisting that it was light and baffling, and so feeble that they had to use sweeps to help her round in tacking. The libel alleged that after the steamer had passed Hunt's Point a sloop was observed coming down, which, by a sudden tack, compelled the steamboat to keep to starboard; that she blew her whistle to call the attention of the schooner to her position, and seeing that there was danger of a collision stopped her engine and backed as soon as possible; that the schooner kept on till she was close to the steamboat when she tacked, but almost immediately shifted her helm and came into the steamboat on her larboard side.

abstract: This gallant officer arrived, with his command in this City yesterday, and was received with a hearty and enthusiastic welcome. Thousands and tens of thousands of our citizens crowded the streets through which he passed, and lingered for hours in the vicinity of his hotel, eager to see him and assure him of the universal applause which greets his gallant and noble defence of the Stars and Strives.
lead_paragraph: This gallant officer arrived, with his command in this City yesterday, and was received with a hearty and enthusiastic welcome. Thousands and tens of thousands of our citizens crowded the streets through which he passed, and lingered for hours in the vicinity of his hotel, eager to see him and assure him of the universal applause which greets his gallant and noble defence of the Stars and Strives. He was visited during the day by great numbers of our citizens, and in the evening twenty or thirty of our most prominent merchants and bankers called to pay their respects.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors held an adjourned meeting yesterday, at 12 M., and immediately went into Committee of the Whole to act upon the law passed by the Legislature on the 15th inst., authorizing them to select a location and erect a suitable building for a Court-house Mr. ELY presided, and, after much discussion, in which Messrs. PURDY, BLUNT, DAVIS and TWEED took part, a resolution was finally adopted, selecting as the most suitable location that portion of the Park extending from the present "new Court-house" on Chambers-street to Broadway. The Common Council will be at once required to cede the land, This done, the Supervisors will advertise for plans and appoint the Commissioners authorized by the act.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors held an adjourned meeting yesterday, at 12 M., and immediately went into Committee of the Whole to act upon the law passed by the Legislature on the 15th inst., authorizing them to select a location and erect a suitable building for a Court-house Mr. ELY presided, and, after much discussion, in which Messrs. The Common Council will be at once required to cede the land, This done, the Supervisors will advertise for plans and appoint the Commissioners authorized by the act.

abstract: On Wednesday afternoon a party of fighting-men from this City left, by the different ferries, for Staten Island, with a view to doing a "gentle little mill," on the smiling sward in the pleasant village of New-Brighton. There were some one hundred and fifty in this party, and the beaming countenances of the whole told with what a relish they were anticipating the morning "feast." The village of Brighton, not boasting a St. Nicholas or a Fifth avenue in the way of a hostelrie, only a few who were lucky enough to be in possession of the "ducats" were enabled to secure beds and bedding. The rest crouched down on mother earth in humble imitation of the other surrounding cattle. Thus the night was passed until early daybreak, when a general bustle was observable, not unlike a camp at early reveille. The principals to this proposed sanguinary encounter were NED TOUPEY and OWEN GEICHAN -- two well-known knights of the fistic arena.

abstract: Yesterday was presented in our streets a spectacle that must continue memorable through generations yet unborn - the 19th of April, a day already famous in our history, having acquired a new and stronger claim on national recollection and gratitude. Amidst unparalleled enthusiasm the volunteer soldiers of New-England and New-York struck hands in our streets on their march to the rescue of the National Capital. And beautiful the streets looked, with bannered parapets, peopled roofs, windows thronged with sympathetic beauty, and sidewalks densely packed with multitudes of excited and applauding citizens.

abstract: The secession of Virginia has cleared the skies. A treacherous enemy has deserted our ranks, who, while she remained, was incessant in her efforts to encourage the rebellion, to shield its outrages, and to arm the traitors, with an assurance that she would join them at the right moment in overthrowing a Government which she has been embarrassing to the utmost of her power by a feigned loyalty. She has now elected to make her soil the battle field. She could not have done us a better service.

abstract: Albert Blackman and twenty-three others vs. The ship Staghound. -- This was a libel filed to recover wages alleged to be due the libelants as seamen on the ship. They shipped at Hong Kong for a voyage thence to a port or ports in China, and thence to Cuba. The vessel set sail about Dec. 1, 1859, from Hong Kong, and went to Swatow, and there took on board a cargo of some 400 coolies, with which she sailed for Cuba. She is a vessel of about 1,600 tons, and had a crew of thirty-four men, with three mates and two quartermasters and a carpenter. On the 31st of March she arrived in Angier Roads, and on that day a difficulty occurred on board. For some fifty hours, while working up the Roads the men had been kept at work without much sleep, but the evidence showed that this was necessary in the working of the ship. During the 31st, however, the men had rested. About 8 o'clock P.M. the first mate who had been ashore, was below. The third mate had had his shoulder dislocated, and the Captain was in feeble health. The mate was called up by a noise of the men, and found all the crew standing on or near the starboard bridge. He ordered them forward, and Hussey, the second mate, a son of the Captain, stepped forward to enforce the order, when he was stabbed by Morris, one of the crew, with a sheath-knife, in the abdomen, from which wound he died some days after. The first mate stepped up to Morris also, but was also stabbed by him in the breast, though not dangerously. He then went to the cabin and got a pistol, and coming out told the men that he would shoot the first one who came aft. Morris stepped out and told him to "fire and be d -- d," on which the mate fired, but missed Morris, hitting one of the crew. The Captain by this time had crawled on deck and threatened to shoot any man who should try to come aft. He was greeted, with a storm or abuse from Morris. He then ordered a boat to be manned to go for a surgeon. None of the crew, obeyed, or answered to a subsequent call for volunteers to man the boat, and the carpenter and quartermasters with the third mate to steer, with his one arm, went to the British man-of-war Odin for a surgeon and for assistance. Nothing further was done with the crew that night. Next morning they were ordered to wash the decks, but refused to do any duty. They were reasoned with by their officers and by the officers of the Odin, who came on board, but still refused duty, and with the assistance of marines from the Odin they were put in irons. On the 3d of April, a Dutch man-of-war came up from Batavia and the men were mustered and again urged to return to their duty, but would not, even refusing to help got up the anchor. It was weighed, however, with the help of the Coolies, and the ship towed to Batavia, where she arrived on April 8, and on the next day the second mate died of his wound.
lead_paragraph: Albert Blackman and twenty-three others vs. The ship Staghound. -- This was a libel filed to recover wages alleged to be due the libelants as seamen on the ship. The vessel set sail about Dec. 1, 1859, from Hong Kong, and went to Swatow, and there took on board a cargo of some 400 coolies, with which she sailed for Cuba. She is a vessel of about 1,600 tons, and had a crew of thirty-four men, with three mates and two quartermasters and a carpenter. During the 31st, however, the men had rested. About 8 o'clock P.M. the first mate who had been ashore, was below. The third mate had had his shoulder dislocated, and the Captain was in feeble health. The mate was called up by a noise of the men, and found all the crew standing on or near the starboard bridge. The first mate stepped up to Morris also, but was also stabbed by him in the breast, though not dangerously. He then went to the cabin and got a pistol, and coming out told the men that he would shoot the first one who came aft. Morris stepped out and told him to "fire and be d -- d," on which the mate fired, but missed Morris, hitting one of the crew. The Captain by this time had crawled on deck and threatened to shoot any man who should try to come aft. He was greeted, with a storm or abuse from Morris. He then ordered a boat to be manned to go for a surgeon. None of the crew, obeyed, or answered to a subsequent call for volunteers to man the boat, and the carpenter and quartermasters with the third mate to steer, with his one arm, went to the British man-of-war Odin for a surgeon and for assistance. Nothing further was done with the crew that night. Next morning they were ordered to wash the decks, but refused to do any duty. abstract: The New-Orleans papers profess to have information from Vera Cruz to the effect that the Mexican Government is disposed to cease diplomatic relations with the United States, substituting intimate and friendly arrangements with the rebel leaders at Montgomery. To this end, we are told, the present vacant mission at Washington will not be filled; and we are invited to believe that an envoy with offers of recognition will soon visit the Confederate capital. Not content with stating the facts, assuming them to be such, these correspondents oblige us with a synopsis of the reasoning which has decided this preference. The Liberal Government, they assert, was so profoundly disgusted with the vote of Northern Senators against the McLane Treaty that they naturally regard the Administration at Washington as unfriendly; and turn for sympathy to that of Montgomery, whose members on the occasion of the same vote, behaved so entirely to the satisfaction of Senor JUAREZ and his Cabinet. And therefore this new aspect of Mexican diplomacy.

abstract: Yesterday was an important day in the history of the impending conflict. The Massachusetts and Pennsylvania troops, on their way to defend the capital of the Republic against the threatened attack of traitors, were assailed by a mob in Baltimore and were compelled to fight their way through that city. They did it gallantly, however, and are now at the capital.

abstract: The nerve-brain and heart of the American people are quivering with patriotic ardor, not unmixed with dire apprehensions of the horrors of war. We have prayed much that the cup might pass by -- but God rules, and it is inevitable. Over all our dear, blessed land, hangs the portentous war-cloud, with its lurid lining, which has been rent but to burst upon as -- but as surely as the sun dispels the morning mist, so surely will the darkened sky be cleared again; and from out the din and smoke of battle will be revealed to the whole world the glorious form of Liberty, with Justice and Peace in her right hand. Then let us meet it right, honestly, courageously, manfully -- if we would have success crowned with glory. This is not the land of conscription, but of Freemen.

abstract: Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, in his proclamation inviting applications for letters of marque and reprisal against Northern commerce, has hung out the true flag of the Confederates. Nothing more was needed to secure for the Southern movement the scorn and indignation of the civilized world. If there had been any doubt before of the attitude of commercial men in this country and of the commercial interest throughout the world towards the new Confederacy, this proclamation would have ended it. Under any circumstances, privateering has become an odious, indeed an infamous weapon of warfare. The whole tendency of modern civilization has been towards an amelioration of the laws of war. It is universally felt that the destruction of private property, in case of war, is a relic of barbarism, and that hostilities ought to be restricted to the public forces of the hostile powers. And although this principle has not yet secured recognition as part of the code of international law, the practice of nations has been towards its adoption. During the Crimean war each nation prohibited its subjects from accepting letters of marque, and privateering was formally discarded by Great Britain as a weapon of war.
lead_paragraph: Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, in his proclamation inviting applications for letters of marque and reprisal against Northern commerce, has hung out the true flag of the Confederates. Nothing more was needed to secure for the Southern movement the scorn and indignation of the civilized world. If there had been any doubt before of the attitude of commercial men in this country and of the commercial interest throughout the world towards the new Confederacy, this proclamation would have ended it. Under any circumstances, privateering has become an odious, indeed an infamous weapon of warfare. The whole tendency of modern civilization has been towards an amelioration of the laws of war. It is universally felt that the destruction of private property, in case of war, is a relic of barbarism, and that hostilities ought to be restricted to the public forces of the hostile powers. And although this principle has not yet secured recognition as part of the code of international law, the practice of nations has been towards its adoption. During the Crimean war each nation prohibited its subjects from accepting letters of marque, and privateering was formally discarded by Great Britain as a weapon of war.

abstract: Yesterday was a sad, and yet triumphant day for New-York. It was sad that a thousand of our noblest citizens should be so suddenly called away from their homes perhaps to death to defend the Constitution and the laws. It was a triumphant vindication of the loyalty of our citizens' thus promptly volunteering to the hardships of a soldier's life. Never before were the people roused to such a pitch of patriotic enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was a sad, and yet triumphant day for New-York. It was sad that a thousand of our noblest citizens should be so suddenly called away from their homes perhaps to death to defend the Constitution and the laws. It was a triumphant vindication of the loyalty of our citizens' thus promptly volunteering to the hardships of a soldier's life. Never before were the people roused to such a pitch of patriotic enthusiasm. There have been gala days, and funeral pageants, and military shows, and complimentary receptions, and triumphal processions that filled the streets with crowds of curious, wondering, sympathetic people, but never has there been developed such a universal, heart-felt, deep-rooted, genuine enthusiasm. The American colors were prominent everywhere -- on housetops, on flagstaffs, on horses attached to all kinds of vehicles, on ropes stretched across the streets, on the masts of shipping in the harbor, on breastpins, on the lappets of coats, on the fronts of men's hats -- on all sides the glorious old red, white and blue waved in the joyous breeze and dazzled the eye with their bright colors. The awful solemnity of civil war came pressing home to our people who had sons and brothers and fathers just departing, perhaps never toreturn. The news of the difficulties in Baltimore, the struggle of the troops with the rabble, the reported death of many, the rumors of an attack on the Capital, the tearing up of railroad tracks, and all the attendant horrors of internecine warfare, struck terror into many a stout heart, while the tears of kind-hearted women flowed copiously as a rain-storm. The excitement was heightened to a great degree by the announcement of the fact that the Sixth, Twelfth and Seventy-first Regiments had likewise been ordered to leave for the seat of war this afternoon. Appended are the details of the various movements:

abstract: By the train last night from Philadelphia between sixty and seventy persons -- men, women and children -- reached this City, who were compelled to leave Virginia, on account of entertaining Union sentiments. A majority of these persons are from Norfolk and Richmond, where some of them leave considerable property, which they now consider worthless to them. They represent that there are a great many Union people in Virginia, but they are overawed by the Secessionists, who, maddened by liquor, are ready to execute summary punishment upon all who differ with them. New-England men are particularly obnoxious to the rebels, and it is not considered safe for any Northern man to remain there.

abstract: The attitude which the Government of the United States holds towards the traitorous combination that seeks its destruction is now thoroughly understood. It is the majesty of Law dealing with the foulest crime in History. Nothing is now more obvious than that the question of Slavery is wholly detached from the issue.
lead_paragraph: The attitude which the Government of the United States holds towards the traitorous combination that seeks its destruction is now thoroughly understood. It is the majesty of Law dealing with the foulest crime in History. Nothing is now more obvious than that the question of Slavery is wholly detached from the issue. On this head there is a phrase in the Presidential proclamation which merits attention. The President states that, in reassessing the forts, places and property of the Union, "the utmost care will be observed to avoid any destruction of or interference with the rights of property." There can be no mistaking the purpose of this paragraph. It is intended to assure the great mass of the people in the South that Slavery has nothing to do with this controversy, -- that it is no part of the purpose of the Government to interfere with it in any way, or to disturb the existing social relations of the Southern States.

abstract: I sailed in the good ship Mary Whitridge, W.A. CRUSY, Commander, from Hong-Kong on the 18th of January, and arrived here yesterday, after an unprecedented passage of 33 days. We bring but two days' later dates than those transmitted by the English Overland mail which left on the 15th, and which I forward, though the papers contain no additional news of importance.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Thursday, Feb. 28, 1861.

abstract: A most cruel rumor was put in circulation last evening that the Seventh Regiment had lost fifty men in attempting to force their way through Baltimore. No one can tell how many hearts were wrung with anguish on reading this utterly unfounded and cruel invention. We know the difficulty of avoiding error in the confusion and uncertainty of the Telegraph, but it is certainly due to the feelings of our citizens not to torture them by the hasty and reckless publication of such reports.

abstract: Whenever we meet resistance to the vindi- cation of the law. If in Maryland, then Maryland must pay the penalty. We may accept the act at Baltimore as that of a mob, for which neither the city nor the State authorities should be censured. But if they are found in league with traitors, then they must share their fate.
lead_paragraph: Whenever we meet resistance to the vindi- cation of the law. If in Maryland, then Maryland must pay the penalty. We may accept the act at Baltimore as that of a mob, for which neither the city nor the State authorities should be censured. But if they are found in league with traitors, then they must share their fate. If they are incapable of preserving order, we must supply the necessary force. If they refuse us a passage through the State, we will carve one for ourselves. The American Flag is its own warrant to march wherever it will. It symbolizes order, law and might; and the man who assails it, or obstructs its march in the vindication of law, must pay the instant forfeit of his life.

abstract: Lieut. JONES is now at the Carlisle Barracks. He states that hearing yesterday that 600 Virginians were approaching by the Winchester road to seize the arsenal, they put piles of powder in straw in all the buildings, and waited quietly the approach of the picket guard, who gave the alarm, when the garrison set on fire the out-houses, carpenter shop, and powder fuses, and then began to retreat.

abstract: The first word the nation has to say to Maryland, (for it is not too late yet,) is, We want to be your friends. We want you to be true to us, and, as there is a God in heaven, we will be true to you. Some, claiming to represent you, talk of an "armed neutrality." We spit upon the term!
lead_paragraph: The first word the nation has to say to Maryland, (for it is not too late yet,) is, We want to be your friends. We want you to be true to us, and, as there is a God in heaven, we will be true to you. Some, claiming to represent you, talk of an "armed neutrality." We spit upon the term! There is no "armed neutrality" written on our programme, fellow-citizens of Maryland! We know that you, by the oldest, sacredest moral and political obligations ever binding men together, are bound to us, in behalf of our common right of way to the Capital of the nation. We want first, in continuing the exercise of this right, to speak to you as one brother speaks to another, in friendship, in confidence, mutually dependent, mutually obligated. Our first word, even after yesterday's proceedings, and even after Friday's corpses in the streets of Baltimore -- the corpses of Northern young men treacherously murdered by sneaking cowards -- is a heartfelt wish for fraternal love.
headline: {'main': 'Two Words to Maryland!', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Two Words to Maryland!', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: pamphlet containing the articles on this subject which appealed in the NEW-YORK TIMES, and watch, it will be remembered, we called special attention to at the time of their publication in that journal. In their collectes form they deserve a wide circulation, not only for their thorough treatment of the points immediately under discussion, but also for the amount of information incidentally furnished. * * * * Meantime we once more commend there essays to those cagaged in "trade and commerce," and also to those who are anxious to discover in what way order may come out of the existing confusion, prosperity spring no from the temporary depression. Passion, fanaticism, and mad ambition may continue and increase the disturbance that verge the country -- for a while longer. But we incline to think the careful perusal of these papers will produce something stronger than the hope, that the natural laws of trade, forces and interests not to be thwarted to there irresistible operation, will bring to naught the taken of reckless politicians, explode the impracticable schemes of fanciful political economists, and give us peace for conflict, activity for stagnation to business, and a Union altogether the cluser from experiences of the evils of dissolution, -- Boston Transcript.

abstract: It may be averred, without the hazard of contradiction, that no individual in his day and generation devoted more time, whether as a deputy in the Convention that formed the Constitution of the United States, as a member of the State Convention that ratified it, as a member of the Congress that organized the Government, and took action on the proposed amendments to the Constitution, to say nothing of the contributions of his pen with HAMILTON and JAY, in those celebrated letters styled "The Federalist." I say let it be remembered by the rising generation especially that that individual was JAMES MADISON, of Virginia.
lead_paragraph: It may be averred, without the hazard of contradiction, that no individual in his day and generation devoted more time, whether as a deputy in the Convention that formed the Constitution of the United States, as a member of the State Convention that ratified it, as a member of the Congress that organized the Government, and took action on the proposed amendments to the Constitution, to say nothing of the contributions of his pen with HAMILTON and JAY, in those celebrated letters styled "The Federalist." I say let it be remembered by the rising generation especially that that individual was JAMES MADISON, of Virginia.

abstract: Business has been partially suspended to-day. At 2 o'clock P.M. merchants were generally closing their stores, with a view to a full attendance of the commercial classes at the great Union meeting. abstract: The Empire City, yesterday, spoke in tones of thunder for the Union, the Constitution and the enforcement of the laws. The largest meeting, without exception, that was ever held on this continent, and the most enthusiastic, was that which came together at Union-square and in the vicinity yesterday -- for the hundred thousand and unnumbered thousands more who responded to the call were too numerous to find standing room within the limits of the Square itself. Into the adjoining thoroughfares the crowds overflowed, and Broadway from Fourteenth-street almost to the Battery was a surging mass of human beings all the afternoon. The stores were closed, and everywhere, on house-tops and mastheads, and on men's hats and next their hearts, and even in ladies bonnets were the Stars and Stripes, -- the emblem of a Union which the people have declared "must and shall be preserved." They who of late, and not without some show of reason, have upbraided Americans for the seeming apathy with which they first heard how that flag had been dishonored, should have seen the demonstration of yesterday. Union-square was a red, white and blue wonder. Countless little flags were hung from windows or waved by ladies and children who looked forth from them. Not only the adjacent hotels, -- the Clarendon, the Everett. the Union Place, the Monument House, -- displayed national colors in profusion, but from nearly every private house, from Spingler Institute and from the Church of the Puritans, the flag of our Union waved proudly.

abstract: The news that war has already begun creates an excitement beggaring anything ever before known amongst us; while the circumstances under which the terrible game opens unite all classes of men in the determination to sustain the Government. For the occasion, party is dropped and a zeal to stand for order and the honor of the country is the absorbing sentiment.

abstract: The Empire City never before saw such an immense consourse of people as gathered yesterday at Union-square, to respond to the call for a Union meeting. Our most experienced reporters have never had occasion to estimate the numbers of so large an assemblage, and the lightning calculator could hardly do justice to the subject.
lead_paragraph: The Empire City never before saw such an immense consourse of people as gathered yesterday at Union-square, to respond to the call for a Union meeting. Our most experienced reporters have never had occasion to estimate the numbers of so large an assemblage, and the lightning calculator could hardly do justice to the subject. To say that there were a hundred thousand people there is to fall far below the mark. The Square and the streets adjoining were thronged, and the whole City was alive with people all the afternoon. Nearly every house was decked with national emblems, and the enthusiasm was unbounded. Five stands had been erected, and from them stirring speeches were made by Gen. Dix, Daniel S. Dickinson, Mayor Wood, Wm. M. Evarts, Moses H. Grinnell, Wm. F. Havemeyer, Henry J. Raymond, Ex-Governor Hunt, Senator Baker, Ex-Governor Fish, Richard O'Gorman, John Cochrane, D.D. Field, Judge Pierrepont, Theodore Tilton, Chauncey Schaffer, and a host of others. A letter from Archbishop HUGHES, breathing fervent Union sentiments, was read, and all the speakers were for sustaining the Government fully. The Volunteer Companies were parading in great force all day. Major ANDERSON was present at the great meeting, and the wildest cheering greeted him wherever he appeared. The occasion was one to mark an era in the history of New-York.

abstract: The pirates directed by JEFFERSON DAVIS at Northern commerce will naturally pounce on the richest prize within their reach; and that unquestionably is the treasure which thrice-monthly passes from San Francisco to New-York. The Companies to whom this wealth is intrusted have no intention of letting the golden fleece fall into piratical hands without a struggle.
lead_paragraph: The pirates directed by JEFFERSON DAVIS at Northern commerce will naturally pounce on the richest prize within their reach; and that unquestionably is the treasure which thrice-monthly passes from San Francisco to New-York. The Companies to whom this wealth is intrusted have no intention of letting the golden fleece fall into piratical hands without a struggle. They are, accordingly, taking all necessary defensive measures, so as to render the chances of success sufficiently desperate to discourage the attempt. The Pacific Mail Steamship Company, besides supplying their vessels abundantly with small arms, including revolvers, muskets and cutlasses, and ammunition, each steamer will carry at least two heavy carronade or twelve-pound cannon. Instructions have also been dispatched some time since to thoroughly sheath the bows of each ship with iron, so as to enable them, without injury to themselves, to run down and sink any pirate or privateer which might attempt their capture. As they are all fast vessels, they would prove in this way most formidable in an encounter on the usually calm Pacific, where sailing vessels could not so well manage to escape. Their engines are also provided with hot water, pipe and hose, which, with the large number of well-armed California and Oregon passengers always on board, would enable them to repel any boarding party.

abstract: It is shocking to hear from our blood-thirsty cotemporaries in Richmond and Montgomery, and particularly in South Carolina, that the "vagabonds, fools and cowards, who are being scraped up by LINCOLN in the purlieus of Wall-street and the Five Points," for the defence of the liberties of the country, are to be cut off from all the ordinary amenities of war,...
lead_paragraph: It is shocking to hear from our blood-thirsty cotemporaries in Richmond and Montgomery, and particularly in South Carolina, that the "vagabonds, fools and cowards, who are being scraped up by LINCOLN in the purlieus of Wall-street and the Five Points," for the defence of the liberties of the country, are to be cut off from all the ordinary amenities of war, and all the chivalrous courtesies of the modern battle-field; they are to be butchered, it seems, (when caught,) after the manner of wild beasts, and tortured after the style of insurrectionary slaves. No quarter is to be given them in defeat; no pity shown them in death; and even when they shall have fought their last battle, and slept their last sleep, the chivalry will hack their flesh from their bones, and the ghouls will devour it.

lead_paragraph: There is good sense in the old Roman max- im that we should read much and not many things, but we can both read many things in Mr. PUTNAM'S book, and read it much to great profit and advan- tage. The eras between which this volume is in- tended to embrace every date of interest in the the history of civilization and progress, are those of the creation of the world and the inauguration of LINCOLN; and, from the high character of the work which Mr. PUTNAM has made the basis of his own, and the evident diligence and care which he has bestowed in adapting it to the use of the American public, we have no doubt that The World's Progress is as reliable in its statement of facts as it is clear and systematic in their arrangement.

abstract: The meeting held yesterday in support of the Government and the Laws, was the largest and most influential popular demonstration ever known in this City. The vast area around Union-square was crowded with the citizens of New-York, -- men of all ranks and professions, -- assembled to proclaim their unanimous and unalterable determination to resist, at all hazards and to the last extremity, the attempt made by traitors and rebels to overthrow the Government under which we live. The enthusiasm was unbounded.

abstract: On the 14th of November last, Mr. A.H. STEPHENS, Vice-President, and now a leading spirit genius of the Southern Confederacy, delivered a speech in the Hall of Representatives, at the seat of Government in Georgia, in favor of the maintenance of the Union. This speech, so truthful and appropriate, and delivered in a spirit so earnest and sincere, elicited universal admiration, and was published by us in full.
lead_paragraph: On the 14th of November last, Mr. A.H. STEPHENS, Vice-President, and now a leading spirit genius of the Southern Confederacy, delivered a speech in the Hall of Representatives, at the seat of Government in Georgia, in favor of the maintenance of the Union. This speech, so truthful and appropriate, and delivered in a spirit so earnest and sincere, elicited universal admiration, and was published by us in full. We now return to it for the purpose, now that the crisis of a civil war is upon us, of justifying to ourselves and before the world, the righteousness of our cause, and our duty to maintain it, and proving from the lips of its very chief wantonness of the rebellion unprovoked by a single act of Government. We want no more eloquent advocate of our cause, which is worthy of the sacrifice of a hundred thousand lives in its defence. Mr. STEPHENS' speech was a reply to one of Mr. TOOMBS, delivered the day previous, in favor of secession. After some preliminary remarks, Mr. STEPHENS proceeded as follows:

abstract: For a long time after "the Swedish Nightingale's" visit to the United States, numbers of world-be refined musical cognoscenti withheld their admiration and patronage from every new vocal candidate, because she could not sing like JENNY LIND. In like manner we hear of numbers wailing and refusing to be comforted because the...
lead_paragraph: For a long time after "the Swedish Nightingale's" visit to the United States, numbers of world-be refined musical cognoscenti withheld their admiration and patronage from every new vocal candidate, because she could not sing like JENNY LIND. In like manner we hear of numbers wailing and refusing to be comforted because the present exhibition is not as the others have been -- quite forgetting that all that may be very true, and yet a very wide margin indeed be left to give visitors their full two shillings' worth. It is only the most vulgar of minds which require that any given work or collection of art be everything or nothing. As regards the claim of this year's exhibition to patronage, we can only say that there is probably not one who reads us who has not scores of times paid the usual twenty-five cents to see one-twenty-fifth part of as much attractiveness, and yet departed perfectly satisfied. The real trouble is not so much the want of merit as the amiable admission of a heavy proportion of crude trash not worth the canvas which it covers. Here is the absurdity. Why fill six galleries with nearly six hundred pictures, when three hundred would have attracted more admiration? When we hear that numbers were actually refused a place among the scarecrow canaille of the latter three hundred, we tremble at the audacity which must inspire some of the white-washing candidates for a place in the temple of American art. Hanging Committees should remember that in this country their judgments involve great responsibility -- more than is determined by popular pen "criticism," and inconceivably more than is established by the very fluctuating and unreliable standard of market rates. If they will not hold quackery and impudent ignorance in check who can do it? And when an institution which boasts among its Members, Academicians and Council, the first art-names in the country, suffers a single wretched effort to find place on its walls, that effort will always be a permanent blemish on its fame and judgment.

abstract: We give elsewhere copious extracts from the speech of Hon. A.H. STEPHENS, VicePresident of the Confederated States, in the Hall of the House of Representatives of Georgia, on the 14th of November last, and after the result of the Presidential election was fully known.
lead_paragraph: We give elsewhere copious extracts from the speech of Hon. A.H. STEPHENS, VicePresident of the Confederated States, in the Hall of the House of Representatives of Georgia, on the 14th of November last, and after the result of the Presidential election was fully known. It is for the perpetuation of that Government -- that model of political mechanism, under whose fostering protection a progress unexampled in the world's history has been achieved, that the whole North are rushing to arms. Its blessings could have been painted by no more masterly hand. It is to society, says Mr. STEPHENS, what the vital air is to human life. It is our political Eden. The crime and the penalty of raising our hand against it, Mr. STEPHENS matches to the Temptation and the Fall, "whence came death into the world, and all our woe."

abstract: The telegraph this morning announces that the negroes of Kent County, Maryland, have already commenced the work of insurrection in that State by "burning the houses of the whites;" while the local journals, both in North and South Carolina, and elsewhere, have lately given accounts of innumerable instances of dangerous insubordination, manifested both in this and other even more ominous ways. To expect that the heat of the conflagration that now enwraps the South would not pierce even through the thick skull of the Blacks, is of a peace with the inconceivable delusions that possess those madmen. It may be that these are but the fiery initials of a chapter of horrors from whose contemplation the mind shrinks aghast.

abstract: "A NEGRO ASTRIDE THE STATUE OF WASHINGTON!" -- A telegram of yesterday from Richmond told us that "the Secessionists celebrated the passage of the Act of Secession by the Convention, by placing a negro astride the statue of Washington in the Capitol," as a type of the new order of things. A more appropriate emblem could not have been devised. "A negro astride the statue of WASHINGTON" exactly expresses modern Virginia, where the breeding of slaves for sale engrosses the greater part of the capital, and is the chief source of revenue of the people. WASHINGTON, who with all the political Fathers, bore testimony against the brutalities of the institution, has had his memory insulted and his effigy subjected to the most disgusting indignities. Think of "a negro astride the statue of the venerated WASHINGTON!" This exceeds the malice of those who cast the ashes of WICKLIFFE into the Severn. The alleged custom of the Japanese, of trampling under their feet the cross, which symbolizes our religion, is not hall so shocking. In this they are true to their education and traditions. But the rite at Richmond shows the depth of infamy to which in two short generations the countrymen of WASHINGTON, his own flesh and blood almost, have fallen. "A negro astride the statue of WASHINGTON!" Let this be engraved on her escutcheon, for it is the ipitome of her new life.

Think of "a negro astride the statue of the venerated WASHINGTON!" This exceeds the malice of those who cast the ashes of WICKLIFFE into the Severn. The alleged custom of the Japanese, of trampling under their feet the cross, which symbolizes our religion, is not hall so shocking. In this they are true to their education and traditions. But the rite at Richmond shows the depth of infamy to which in two short generations the countrymen of WASHINGTON, his own flesh and blood almost, have fallen. "A negro astride the statue of WASHINGTON!" Let this be engraved on her escutcheon, for it is the ipitome of her new life.

abstract: AND THE SOUTH. -- This is the title of a valuable and interesting article, just published, containing a series of exhaustive pamphlet that have appeared recently in the New-York TIMES, and which have attracted much attention. They prove secession from the commerce, or industries, or the influence of the North, to be an impossibility -- that in every point of view the South must be the loser, and if successful in dividing the country, it must accept a condition of hopeless inferiority -- that division upon any political boundary is impossible, as in at least one-half of Southern territory the slave is not the predominant interest. The article on the Geographical question of Secession is illustrated by a very instructive map, elegantly drawn in crayon, showing by different degrees of shade, and also by figures, the proportion of slavss to whites in every county in the Southern States. The whole question of Secession -- its locality, climate, soil -- with its different degrees of intensity, which always correspond to the depth of shading, is thus shown at a glance. -- Buffalo Express.

abstract: A gentleman who left Washington at half past four o'clock on Saturday morning, informs us that the general belief in that city in the best informed circles, was that JEFFERSON DAVIS was on his way North--at the head of a considerable force, which he was augmenting on the way.
lead_paragraph: A gentleman who left Washington at half past four o'clock on Saturday morning, informs us that the general belief in that city in the best informed circles, was that JEFFERSON DAVIS was on his way North--at the head of a considerable force, which he was augmenting on the way. As all communication by telegraph with the South has been cut off, it was impossible to procure any positive information on this subject; but it was considered beyond dispute that he was en route for the Capital and not very far from it at the present time.

abstract: We have intelligence from Pensacola to April 8. The number of State troops then concentrated there was 3,000 and more were rapidly arriving. Six batbatteries bearing on Fort Pickens were completed, and others were in progress. Five sloops-of war lay near by Pickens-the Sabine, Brooklyn, Wyandotte ard St.Louis. Another arrived Saturday night, the 7th, name not known. The troops anticipated a fight in fifteen or twenty days.

abstract: It is almost impossible to get reliable information from any point below Philadelphia. All telegraphic and railroad communication with Baltimore has been cut off, and what intelligence does reach us comes by roundabout channels and through suspicious authorities.
lead_paragraph: It is almost impossible to get reliable information from any point below Philadelphia. All telegraphic and railroad communication with Baltimore has been cut off, and what intelligence does reach us comes by roundabout channels and through suspicious authorities. It is necessary, therefore, in reading the newspaper reports from the seat of war, to make due allowance for the very great difficulties which the journalist encounters, and to weigh with caution and consideration the accounts that may be published.

abstract: Col. DURYEA, the accomplished disciplinarian to whom the Seventh Regiment is so largely indebted for the efficiency of its organization, is placing in the field a splendid band of chosen men. His regiment is about ready to go into quarters on one of the Government islands. Gen. SANFORD has written to the Secretary of War on the subject, and the order from head-quarters is expected speedily. A great many old members of the Seventh Regiment are attached to the command, forming a nucleus of the best drilled men in the world, around which the volunteers who appreciate the advantage of entering the school of the soldier with men who have been soldiers, and of going into action under commanders who have been tried, are gathering in great numbers. In the Regiment there are such men as Major MANSFIELD DAVIES, Capt. ROBERT S. DUMONT, Capt. YOUNG, Capt. JAS L. WAUGH, Capt. H.D. HULL and Capt. H.E. DAVIES. Many gentlemen of this City have contributed largely for the support of the Regiment, and Col. DURYEA is constantly receiving sums appropriated to the object. Yesterday JAS. K. PELL sent turn $500. Judge DAVISS has presented $100 to the commands, and others smaller amounts. Capt. YOUNG has collected $950 for the corps. The men and their families will be well cared for. The drill-rooms are at No 632 Broadway, and the head quarters of the Regiment at Lafayette Hall. The uniform is that of the Imperial French Zouaves.

abstract: Mr. LINCOLN was elected as partisan. On taking office the country was divided into two great political factions. He commenced his official duties by following the precedent of rewarding his friends and punishing his foes.
lead_paragraph: Mr. LINCOLN was elected as partisan. On taking office the country was divided into two great political factions. He commenced his official duties by following the precedent of rewarding his friends and punishing his foes. We admit that numerous changes were required, and that Secessionists, who had foisted themselves in great numbers into every department of service, as spies upon Government, and traitors, should be expelled from their places. Still, notwithstanding the extraordinary number of unfaithful officers, and the consequent changes required, it must be confessed that the Administration has presented the lamentable spectacle of wasting precious days and weeks, in deciding upon partisan claims to office, at the very moment that all its energies should have been directed to the state of the country, and to meet the unexampled efforts of the Secessionists and traitors plotting its destruction.
headline: {'main': 'No More Partisanship.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'No More Partisanship.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The great campaign is fairly opened; and everything now depends on the vigor and energy with which we strike the first blows. The next sixty days should break the backbone of Secession by crushing it in Virginia. We have fortunately secured Fort Monroe beyond the possibility of capture. It is an admirable point as a base of operations, and a large force should be concentrated within it.
lead_paragraph: The great campaign is fairly opened; and everything now depends on the vigor and energy with which we strike the first blows. The next sixty days should break the backbone of Secession by crushing it in Virginia. We have fortunately secured Fort Monroe beyond the possibility of capture. It is an admirable point as a base of operations, and a large force should be concentrated within it. Another large army should be concentrated at Washington, and the two should, at the earliest moment, form a junction at Richmond. At that point we can dictate terms to Secession as well as if we were at Montgomery. If we are forced to extreme measures, the example made of Virginia would strike terror into every Southern State. An overpowering force at Washington would completely overawe secession in Maryland, which probably infects only a small portion of the population. With Washington properly reinforced, we should at once open a path through Baltimore, and aid the local authorities with a sufficient force to keep it open. As we stated yesterday, the law should be felt wherever it is resisted. The issue presented is to test the strength of the law against rebellion.
headline: {'main': 'The Opening of the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Opening of the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There are thousands of women in the City eager to do something in aid of the great cause which fills all hearts and enlists a11 thought. Something should be done at once to enable them to organize their efforts.
lead_paragraph: There are thousands of women in the City eager to do something in aid of the great cause which fills all hearts and enlists a11 thought. Something should be done at once to enable them to organize their efforts. We know of several who are anxious to go to the seat of the impending war, to act as nurses of the sick and wounded. If proper hospital arrangements can be made at Washington, scores and hundreds of the noblest of our women will gladly offer their services in this work of humanity and patriotism. The Committee of Twenty-one, appointed at the great Union meeting on Saturday, will do well to give this matter their immediate attention. Let them appoint a sub-committee to take the subject in hand at once.

abstract: During the first quarter of the year 1861, ending on the 1st inst., the City Inspector has reported 5,167 deaths in New-York. The weekly average has been, in January, 397; in February, 392; in March, 403. For the whole 13 weeks, there has been an average of 567 deaths each day. The mortality for the quarter shows a decrease of 1,038, or 16.7 per cent as compared with the first quarter of the year 1860.
lead_paragraph: During the first quarter of the year 1861, ending on the 1st inst., the City Inspector has reported 5,167 deaths in New-York. abstract: CHILD RUN OVER AND KILLED. -- CHARLES MURPHY, a dirt-carman, while racing his horse through Rivington-street, on Saturday afternoon, ran over and killed CATHARINE LACE, a child four years of age, whose parents reside at No. 347 Rivington-street. MURPHY whipped-up his horse and attempted to escape, but was pursued by a number of enraged citizens, and finally captured and taken to the Station-house, where he was locked up. Coroner JACKMAN was notified and will hold an inquest upon the body of the child to-day.
