Coroner JACKMAN was notified and will hold an inquest upon the body of the child to-day.

abstract: It is time now to stop, for the present at least, all wordly argument about the relative power or courage of antagonistic States and sections-of patriots or their foes. The events of the last three months laugh to scorn a11 reason; while the very omnipotence of our proofs and arguments tends to weaken us in the vigor of our action. It was abundantly
lead_paragraph: It is time now to stop, for the present at least, all wordly argument about the relative power or courage of antagonistic States and sections-of patriots or their foes. The events of the last three months laugh to scorn a11 reason; while the very omnipotence of our proofs and arguments tends to weaken us in the vigor of our action. It was abundantly proved during the late Italian Revolution, that things were not being conducted according to Vattel, nor with a proper respect to the inalienable rights of Kings; but the Garibaldian volcano swept out the most potent constitutional arguments, and the revolution succeeded in spite of the most unanswerable arguments of the impossibility of its success. The Issue here, also, is now brought to a field where words, and rhetoric, and chop logic, and statistics, are of but little avail; and where victory will assuredly ultimately be to that side (whichever it may be) which has the most accomplished leaders and generals, the largest and best disciplined army, the most scientific enginery of destruction, and which can bring its force to boar most rapidly and effectively on the weak points of the enemy; which has the sinews of war in the greatest abundance, which is inspired by the noblest motives, and which has justice (always in the end triumphant) on its side.

abstract: In a conflict like the present, wherein the entire community has deep and common interest, all classes are ready to make sacrifices.
lead_paragraph: In a conflict like the present, wherein the entire community has deep and common interest, all classes are ready to make sacrifices. The desire to do so takes a variety of forms, some practical, and others merely significant; but nothing save proper guidance is needed to bring the patriotism of every class to the aid of the country. Hundreds of thousands, with whom the course is practicable, will join the army, and assist sword in hand in the national defence. This is the service of honor and the service of danger. The immediate rewards of victory will inure to these. But the great bulk of the people find it less easy to forsake family and business, or to enter upon a course in which vigorous health and bodily strength are indispensable; and this class must content itself by promoting the enlistment of those in whose way no such obstacles interpose. How can this be done?

abstract: Ex Judge JAMES R. WHITING, who, until recently, has been an ultra advocate of Southern rights, and who is one of the wealthy citizens of this City, thus declares himself: "I have just given an outfit to a young man who is desirous of fighting for his country, and will do the same by others; and if I were not myself crippled by rheumatism, I would enlist in any regiment that would accept me. I will go yet, if the worst comes to the worst, and fight as long as I can go. I have worked for the South for years, and been hooted for so doing on many a public occasion. I was with them in sympathy now, until I read of their trampling my country's flag in the dust; then my blood rose. The first gun against Sumter made it boil. I will give every cent of my property to aid the Government; for what do I want of property -- what, in the name of God, is the value of property without a country." Such are the exact words of the Judge, who is a white-headed man of 60, and whose property comprises some of the most extensive buildings and valuable lots in Broadway, and such is the universal sentiment of our people.
lead_paragraph: Ex Judge JAMES R. abstract: The grand military ovation which attended the departure of the Seventh Regiment on Friday, was repeated yesterday, with greatly added enthusiasm, on the occasion of the sailing of the Sixth, Twelfth and Seventy-first Regiments, New-York State Militia, and the Massachusetts and Rhode Island troops. Early in the morning the people were astir, and from 8 to 12 o'clock, continued to pour in a continuous stream towards Broadway. By 10 o'clock every available spot where a human being could stand, was occupied, throughout its entire length, and from near Canal-street to Grace Church, not only the sidewalks, but the whole of the street, was densely thronged. Every window, door, stoop, balcony and house-top, were alive with human beings, of every age, sex and condition, awaiting the marching of the Regiments, which, it was known, would depart during the day for the seat of Government, or other destination where their services might be required.

abstract: left this City on Friday evening for Providence, when off Throge's Point, took fire in her deck load of cotton, which, but for the timely assistance rendered by the steam tug E. Griffen, which was on her way from Mamaroneck to this City with two barges in tow, would no doubt have been entirely destroyed. The tug was ran alongside the steamer and all hands set to work with a will, throwing overboard some of the burning cotton and placing a portion on the barges, thus removing the fire. The Petrie was then taken in tow and brought back to the City.

abstract: Direct communication with Baltimore and Washington being cut off, it is impossible to state with certainty the condition of affairs at either point; but with regard to Baltimore, the most exciting rumors reach us. Persons who arrived at...
lead_paragraph: Direct communication with Baltimore and Washington being cut off, it is impossible to state with certainty the condition of affairs at either point; but with regard to Baltimore, the most exciting rumors reach us. Persons who arrived at Harrisburgh yesterday, having left Baltimore at 8 o'clock in the morning, report that at that hour nothing unusual was going on; but others, who came through later, represent the most alarming condition of affairs as existing there. All law and order were set at defiance, and the city appeared to be altogether in the hands of the Secessionists. It was rumored, among other things, that a demand had been made for the surrender of Fort McHenry, coupled with a threat to attack it, and that the commander of the fort replied that he should, if attacked, defend the fort and fire upon the city. A gentleman who reached this City last evening reports Chat cannonading had been heard in the direction of Baltimore; and still later dispatches from Harrisburgh state that rumors prevailed there to the effect that Fort McHenry was shelling the city. How much truth there may be in these rumors it is impossible now to determine.

abstract: The parties whom we meationed in Friday's issue as having been defeated in their purpose on Staten Island, managed to bring the matter to a issue on Saturday morning at 3 o'clock. Finding it almost...
lead_paragraph: The parties whom we meationed in Friday's issue as having been defeated in their purpose on Staten Island, managed to bring the matter to a issue on Saturday morning at 3 o'clock. Finding it almost impossible to select a place in the vicinity of this City, where they would be undisturbed by the police, the parties concluded the best way to settle the controversy was to go into a room and finish it. Consequently a select few assembled at a well-known sporting house in the east side of the town at the hour named, when the belligerents TOUGHEY and LEIGHAN soon took the floor. The battle was for $100 aside. The seconds, referee and other necessary parties having been chosen, "Time" was called, and the men went at it. Upon the start, TOUGHEY, who is the tallest, but the lightest of the two, exhibited extraordinary skill, not only as a sparrer but as a tactician. His hits were well planned and most resolutely delivered. The superior strength and prowess of his adversary was however against him, and in every round TOUGHEY was thrown heavily on the board flooring. After fighting for one hour and a half the seconds of TOUGHEY gave in for him. The fight was what is termed a game one, and both men were badly battered. It is thought a renewal of the battle will be had on turf at an early day.

abstract: For the first time since their construction, there is a prospect of all our first-class steam frigates, except one being in commission at once, and at home. They have all done some duty, but at dif
lead_paragraph: For the first time since their construction, there is a prospect of all our first-class steam frigates, except one being in commission at once, and at home. They have all done some duty, but at different times. The Niagara first went to sea on the Atlantic cable expedition; the Roanoke and Coolrado as alternate flag ships of the Home Fleet; the Merrimack to the Pacific; the Minnesota to China, and the Wabash to the Mediterranean. The Niagara is now almost due here from the East. Of course, under existing circumstances, she will not be put out of commission. The Wabash is rapidly fitting out at the Brooklyn Navy-yard; the Minnesota at Boston, (where the Colorado has been in a state of readiness for months,) and the Merrimack at Norfolk. The latter, however, needs more repairs than could be completed in a short time. The Roanoke would only require a few weeks to put her in sea-going trim.

abstract: (Min.) some weeks ago for the murder of her husband, by administering arsenic, and it is now believed that she was the same person who, on the 8th of November, 1849, poisoned Alex, D. Simpson, her husband, in the town of Fayetteville, N.C. In that case arsenic was the agent employed, and after the death of Simpson his wife was arrested, but succeeded in escaping to Charleston, and thence to Havana, where she remained until May, 1850. She returned to Fayetteville on the 7th of November following, surrendering herself for trial, and was acquitted. On the trial of Mrs. Balansky at St. Paul, she stated that she had resided at Fayetteville, N.C., where her husband died. The Christian names of the two women were identical, and many circumstances in St. Paul subsequent to her execution, have been called to mind, which tend to the belief that she and Mrs. Simpson were the same person.

abstract: Postmaster General BLAIR has received a very interesting letter from Mr. WM. A. BRYAN, the special agent of the Department, who was sent hence to reopen the Post-office at Pensacola, closed some months ago by order of Mr. HOLT, in consequence of the violation of Lieut. SLEMMER's dispatches. Mr. BRYAN having business at Montgomery, Ala., stopped there, and had an interview with Mr. REAGAN, the Postmaster-General of the "Confederate States," to whom he frankly stated the purpose of his journey to Pensacola, and asked his assistance and cooperation in the business in hand.

On reaching Havre de Grace they were...
lead_paragraph: We have recived authentic intelligence by passengers from Washington up to 6 0'clock on Saturday evening. Rev. H.M. FIELD, of this City, went from Wilmington yesterday morning to Havre de Grace, on a special train which the Superintendent of the read had run, in order to attend to the rebuilding of the bridges between Hare de Grace and Baltimore. On reaching Havre de Grace they were met by two gentlemen, friends of the Superintendent, who had come to warn him not to cross the river, as his life would be in peril. They stated that bands of armed men were stationed at the points where the bridge had been burned, for the purpose of preventing their being repaired, and that no one would be allowed to make any attempt to rebuild them. Some laborers had been down on the road towards Baltimore, but had been compelled to return.

abstract: Our whole community are aroused. The ladies are making clothes for the Union Guards, who are ready to march. The surrounding towns are in a blaze of excitement, our citizens contributing money, . and the young men are rallying for the Union. The students in the College have formed themselves in a Company, and are daily drilling in the armory. They are ready to march at a moments notice.

abstract: Gen.KEIM and Staff have been ordered here from Washington, to take charge of the troops here. He left Washington this morning, and arrived to-night, traveling eighteen miles from Baltimore in a carriage; Judge WILMOT accompanying him. He found five bridges destroyed on the Northern Central Road, ten miles from Baltimore. Intense excitement prevails in that city. SHERMAN'S battery, also the battery of the Reading Artillery, (four pieces,) reached here at midnight.

abstract: Telegraphic communication with Washington is still an impossibility, but we receive gratifying assurances through other channels that the Capital may now be considered safe against the assault of any force which is likely to be brought against it. The number of troops now there must be at least ten thousand, and will probably be twenty thousand within twenty-four hours.

abstract: It has been our duty heretofore to call public attention to the condition and reliability of the Army and Navy, and to point out the fatal consequences to be apprehended from infidelity and treachery on the part of those intrusted with command.
lead_paragraph: It has been our duty heretofore to call public attention to the condition and reliability of the Army and Navy, and to point out the fatal consequences to be apprehended from infidelity and treachery on the part of those intrusted with command. The country has already had sad experience in this respect, and it would be difficult to exaggerate the importance of circumspection. For not only numerous Southern officers of distinction, but three or four who were born north of Mason and Dixon's line have proven faithless, in consequence of having formed matrimonial alliances in the South.

abstract: The ship Julia. E. Tyler, Capt. LAURY, twenty-one hours from Hampton Roads, arrived here last evening about 6 o'clock. Capt. LAURY reports that the pilot who came down from Norfolk to take the ship to sea, told him that Norfolk and the Portsmouth Navy-yard were on fire. Capt. LAURY had seen the flames in that direction distinctly before the pilot arrived. The Captain could tell nothing further. The Tyler left the. Capes on Sunday afternoon.

abstract: The steamers James Adger, Marion, Roanoke, Chesapeake, Monticello and Parkersburgh, yesterday still remained at the Pier with steam up, so as to be ready at any moment's notice. The steamship Montgomery which arrived Sunday evening from Savannah, has also been chartered by the United States Government. The steamship Jno. P. King is also to be put in order for service at once, in anticipation of Government employment. This vessel has been rebuilt, and is every way as strong and serviceable as any steamer in port. She is capable of carrying 12 guns on deck. She proved herself very fast on her trial trip, and would no doubt make an excellent man-of-war for blockading purposes.

abstract: FELLOW-CITIZENS: The iron hail at Fort Sumter rattles on every Northern breast. It has shot away the last vestige of national and personal forbearance. A loaf of bread on its way to a starving man was split in two by a shot from his brother. You might saturate the Cotton States with all the turpentine of North Carolina; you might throw upon them the vast pine forests of Georgia, then bury the Gulf storms' sharp.
lead_paragraph: FELLOW-CITIZENS: The iron hail at Fort Sumter rattles on every Northern breast. It has shot away the last vestige of national and personal forbearance. A loaf of bread on its way to a starving man was split in two by a shot from his brother. You might saturate the Cotton States with all the turpentine of North Carolina; you might throw upon them the vast pine forests of Georgia, then bury the Gulf storms' sharpest lightening into the combustible mass, and you would not redden the Southern horizon with so angry a glow as flashed along the Northern heart when the flames of Fort Sumter reached it. To-day, bewildered America, with her torn flag and her broken charter, looks for you to guard the one and restore the other. How Europe stares and liberty shudders, as from State after State that flag falls, and the dream breaks. Hereafter Southern history will be as bare as the pole from which the sundered pennant sinks, and treason parts with the last rag that concealed its hideousness.

abstract: In consequence of the notice in the TIMES of yesterday morning, a very large number of ladies met at the residence of Mrs. H.J. RAYMOND, No. 50 Ninth-street, at 12 o'clock, for the purpose of organizing an association to prepare lint and bandages for the wounded in the coming war. Not less than two or three hundred ladies were present, all of them deeply interested in the object of the meeting, and many of them from out of the City. Dr. ROBERT NELSON and Dr. HORACE GREEN, who were present, made some interesting and valuable explanations as to the proper method of preparing the desired articles.

abstract: The tone of the English and French journals, brought by yesterday's steamer, furnishes a curious reflex of the aspect of American affairs a month ago. That period which was the date of their latest American advices has, by the events of the past ten days, become so separated from the "situation" which the drama has now assumed, that it is difficult to realize how narrow is the chronologic interval between us and then.
lead_paragraph: The tone of the English and French journals, brought by yesterday's steamer, furnishes a curious reflex of the aspect of American affairs a month ago. That period which was the date of their latest American advices has, by the events of the past ten days, become so separated from the "situation" which the drama has now assumed, that it is difficult to realize how narrow is the chronologic interval between us and then. It is quite a mental experience to be transported back to the time when Mr. LINCOLN was laboring under "embarrasments" as to the evacuation of Fort Sumter, troubled respecting what to do next, and unconsciously permitting the clutch of the midnight murderer to approach nearer and nearer the throat of the nation, while he valiantly pursued the Utopian theory of Presidential duty.

abstract: We are unwilling to believe that Maryland is given over hopelessly to the rebellion, or that Gov. HICKS has abandoned his devotion to the Union and the Constitution. He has done too much for both, he stood up too boldly against the tremendous pressure which ...
lead_paragraph: We are unwilling to believe that Maryland is given over hopelessly to the rebellion, or that Gov. HICKS has abandoned his devotion to the Union and the Constitution. He has done too much for both, he stood up too boldly against the tremendous pressure which the conspirators brought to bear upon him; and his noble fidelity to his own convictions of duty was of too much service to the Union to permit us hastily to denounce him for having apparently yielded to the domination of a Baltimore mob. There is, beyond all question, a very strong element of rebellion in Maryland and Baltimore. It embraces the whole of that immense body of vagabonds and lawless scoundrels who have kept that city in terror so long. The attack upon the Massachusetts troops was, in our opinion, the act of the mob, -- not the prearranged action of a party. The passions it aroused swept the city like a whirlwind, and the Union sentiment disappeared before it. But we do not consider this by any means decisive of the position which Maryland will finally assume in this great contest. We cannot believe that she will be so blind to her own interest as to plant herself in the path of the mighty North, rushing to the rescue of the Union. At present her attitude is that of rebellion. But she does not in the least diminish the certainty that the Union will be triumphant against rebellion. Her accession to the rebels, while it widens the field, narrows the issue. The nearer the contest comes to us, the better can we deal with it, and the more certain is our success.

abstract: The British Press has swung round again. At the outset of the secession movement, its sympathies, (if such cold-blooded speculations deserve the name,) were with the American Government. It saw no good reason for destroying a Union which had made the American people so prosperous, and purchased so largely of British goods.
lead_paragraph: The British Press has swung round again. At the outset of the secession movement, its sympathies, (if such cold-blooded speculations deserve the name,) were with the American Government. It saw no good reason for destroying a Union which had made the American people so prosperous, and purchased so largely of British goods. British trade had increased largely under the stimulus of good government in the United States, -- therefore these organs of British opinion were opposed to its destruction.

abstract: A meeting of the Exempt Firemen took place last night at Firemen's Hall, Mercer-street. It was a crowded meeting of the most enthusiastic stamp. The principal speakers were Messrs. P.W. ENGS, MORRIS FRANKLIN, ZOPHAR MILLS, J.W. PURSER, and WILSON SMALL. They aroused the patriotism of their hearers to a pitch that could not find its vent without frequent starting to the feet, and the raising of cheer upon cheer for the Union. CARLISLE NORWOOD was the President, JOHN T. ROLLINS the Secretary. Resolutions were adopted by acclamation which pledge the Exempts to do active duty during the absence of the members of the Department.

abstract: Measured by intensity offeeling and a proper appreciation of the crisis, the President and the Cabinet at Washington are far behind the people. They are like a person just aroused from sleep, and in a state of dreamy halfconsciousness.
lead_paragraph: Measured by intensity offeeling and a proper appreciation of the crisis, the President and the Cabinet at Washington are far behind the people. They are like a person just aroused from sleep, and in a state of dreamy halfconsciousness. They have not yet, for the first time, accepted the logic of facts as palpable as noonday. From the first, Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS has been aiming at the capture of Washington, when he would very likely hang the whole of them could he catch them, while they have been deluding themselves that he was only playing a part, and would some day, perhaps, form one of their number, as he did of the Cabinet of Mr. PIERCE.

abstract: To-day New-York City, besides being the headquarters of the regular Army of the United States, will be also the head-quarters of the Department of the East. Major General JOHN E. WOOL, of the staff, the next in rank to General SCOTT himself, arrived here yesterday, will remove his quarters to this City from Troy.
lead_paragraph: To-day New-York City, besides being the headquarters of the regular Army of the United States, will be also the head-quarters of the Department of the East. Major General JOHN E. WOOL, of the staff, the next in rank to General SCOTT himself, arrived here yesterday, will remove his quarters to this City from Troy. Henceforward, therefore, all orders and instructions directing the movements of regulars located in the country east of the Mississippi River, will be issued from Major WOOL'S office here. The following are the present forts and barracks in this Department, and the regiments of which detachments garrison them:

abstract: Burnham Benson vs. The New-Jersey Railroad Transportation Company. -- The plaintiff in this case on the 12th of July, 1858, purchased of the defendants a ticket which entitled him to a passage upon their road, from New-York City to Philadelphia. He purchased the ticket about half-past eleven o'clock A.M., and a train started at 12 o'clock on that day, which would arrive in Philadelphia at 4 P.M.; and he bought his ticket with a view of going in this train. He now alleges, however, that the defendants refused to allow him to enter the cars on that day, at that hour, and consequently he was obliged to take another train, and suffered a loss in his business to the extent of $500.

abstract: The brigantine Toronto, the vessel on board of which the 8,000 kegs of gunpowder was seized on Sunday, by Surveyor HART, it seems cleared from this port in December last, for New-Orleans. In a gale of wind she lost her mast, and was obliged to put into St. Thomas in distress, where she was refitted as best she could be, the Captain not having the means to repair, and she returned to this City. The peculiar circumstances of the case led to the discovery of the nature of her cargo, and to its seizure. In December last no particular notice would have been taken of the shipment. The vessel is in custody, and the powder was sent to the Naval Magazine.

abstract: The most imperative step now to be taken is the instant blockade of Southern ports. Unless this be done, in a month's time swarms of pirates will issue from them directed against our Commercial Marine. Such a course has been held in terrorem over us from the outset. The rebels well know what we
lead_paragraph: The most imperative step now to be taken is the instant blockade of Southern ports. Unless this be done, in a month's time swarms of pirates will issue from them directed against our Commercial Marine. Such a course has been held in terrorem over us from the outset. The rebels well know what we have at stake, and for a long time believed the fear of loss would keep us perfectly quiet and inactive. They forgot that patriotism was still alive in the human heart. No class of men have more heartily responded to the great call than merchants, and Government should take effective measures that they be not harmed.

abstract: Six Companies of Infantry and Riflemen, in command of Col. E.M. BRYAN, came down from Albany by the last evening train, arriving about 10 o'clock P.M. They are six hundred strong, and are almost wholly from among the business men and mechanics of Albany. They were escorted from the depot by a detachment of Police, and were headed by a company of Albany firemen. They did not receive the order to march until Sunday. An excellent supper awaited them at the Astor House, when, about 12 o'clock, they re-formed and marched on board of the steamer James Adger. They sail early this morning.

abstract: YARD AT NORFOLK. -- The destruction of the ships and Navy-yard at Norfolk is a great loss, and a national disgrace. It is inconceivable to us, if an attack was anticipated, why a suitable tow-boat, with steam, always up, had not been maintained constantly in readioess for the emergency. Neither can we see why the ships were not defended, even at the cost of the destruction of the towns of Portsmouth and Norfolk. We are told, that on application of the inhabitants to the Commander, as to what he intended to do, he replied that he should act simply on the defensive.

abstract: In reply to an interpolation in the Chamber on the Roman question, Count CAVOQE said the Italian Government could only employ moral measures, and cannot act against Rome as a conqueror. He admitted
lead_paragraph: In reply to an interpolation in the Chamber on the Roman question, Count CAVOQE said the Italian Government could only employ moral measures, and cannot act against Rome as a conqueror. He admitted that the solution of the Neapolitan difficulty was bound up in the Roman question, and hoped the antagonism of the Church would soon cease. He said the Government would energetically suppress any disturbances in Naples, and the most efficacious means would be taken for the solution of the Roman question. The Chamber finally adopted the following almost unanimously:

abstract: Capt. COLLINS, of the schooner O.H. Lee, from York River, arrived this morning, bringing as passengers Mr. E.W. EVANS, lady and family, G.F. SOUTHWELL and lady, JAMES CROSS and family, and several others, who were compelled to leave Williamsburgh for expressing themselves favorable to the Union. They were given but few hours to get ready to leave, the feeling was so bitter against them. The schooner was boarded by Lieut. COSNAHAN and Sergeant TALIAFERO, with a boat's crew of six men, for the purpose of seizing her, but finding her papers all right, and the Captain being a favorite man, she was given a passport and allowed to proceed.

abstract: the war -- the act of most importance thus far, and that to which Washington probably owes, and will owe, its safety -- is undoubtedly the brilliant coup of Capt. JONES at Harper's Ferry. Treason was systematically at work in Virginia, incited, planned and carried out by such men as WISE, MASON and HUNTER, with the complicity of Gov. LETCHER, all the time that the decoy Convention was plotting over plans of adjustment, "ultimatums," and schemes to lull the suspicions and delay the preparations of the North to guard against danger. A leading feature of the conspiracy was the theft of Harper's Ferry, as a means of arming the ten thousand men who were to concentrate there, and by the Baltimore and Ohio railway, attack Washington in the rear. The masterly movement of Capt. JONES effectually defeated this well-laid scheme. The traitors are at Harper's Ferry, without arms, and consequently unable to carry out their part of the programme. Meantime the great North has "shaken the dew drops from its mane," and while the traitors are gnashing their teeth in disappointment, the Northern, hosts are moving in a steady phalanx, to the defence of the Federal Capital. All honor to the wise foresight and decision of Capt. JONES, the first real hero of the war.
lead_paragraph: the war -- the act of most importance thus far, and that to which Washington probably owes, and will owe, its safety -- is undoubtedly the brilliant coup of Capt. JONES at Harper's Ferry. Treason was systematically at work in Virginia, incited, planned and carried out by such men as WISE, MASON and HUNTER, with the complicity of Gov. LETCHER, all the time that the decoy Convention was plotting over plans of adjustment, "ultimatums," and schemes to lull the suspicions and delay the preparations of the North to guard against danger. A leading feature of the conspiracy was the theft of Harper's Ferry, as a means of arming the ten thousand men who were to concentrate there, and by the Baltimore and Ohio railway, attack Washington in the rear. The masterly movement of Capt. JONES effectually defeated this well-laid scheme. The traitors are at Harper's Ferry, without arms, and consequently unable to carry out their part of the programme. Meantime the great North has "shaken the dew drops from its mane," and while the traitors are gnashing their teeth in disappointment, the Northern, hosts are moving in a steady phalanx, to the defence of the Federal Capital. All honor to the wise foresight and decision of Capt. JONES, the first real hero of the war.

abstract: The City of Mew-York yesterday saw another of those dans which are to be memorable in history. The Eighth Regiments, Col. LYON, and the Sixty-ninth, Col. CORCORAN, commanding, embarked for the seat of war, the two commands numbering nearly or quite three thousand men. As on previous occasions of the departure of troops, the whole City turned out to bid them Godspeed in defence of the Government, and rendered the whole line of their march through Broadway and the side streets through which they approached their respective steamers, aperfect ovation.

abstract: We learn from undoubted authority that the Seventh Regiment which left Philadelphia in the Boston and came up the Chesapeake, arrived at Annapolis on Tuesday. They were met there by a remonstrance from Gov. HICKS against their landing as was also the Massachusetts regiment which arrived at the same time. Both regiments landed upon the grounds belonging to the United States and remained there, awaiting orders from Washington, at the time the messenger left.

abstract: The Journal St. Petersburgh gives the following version of the renewal of disturbance at Warsaw Great crowds of people having assembled before the castle were dispersed by force. The conflict was renewed several times. Ten persons were killed, and as many wounded. Five soldiers were killed, and forty-five persons were arrested. Other accounts say the number of victims was larger even than stated in the original telegram. Renewal of disturbances expected. The troops at Warsaw number 32,000 men.

abstract: Mr. STEPHENS, Vice-President of the Southern Confederacy, the ablest exponent of its principles, in his recent speech published by
lead_paragraph: Mr. STEPHENS, Vice-President of the Southern Confederacy, the ablest exponent of its principles, in his recent speech published by us on the 27th ult., tells us that the basis of Southern civilization is negro Slavery -- that to confirm its status was the immediate cause of the recent rupture and the present revolution. He goes on to trace the change in the public sentiment of the South from the conviction universally entertained by the founders of our Government, who looked confidently forward to the final disappearance of Slavery under the workings of the benign principles which they inaugurated. All their notions about the evils or false economy of the system, he further tells us, were due either to ignorance or mistaken philanthropy, and have been fully exploded by the material prosperity and moral elevation of the South. All who adhere to the doctrines of JEFFERSON and his compeers, are fanatics with whom the South for the future desire neither part nor lot. For the purpose of testing the correctness of his assumption of the superior value of Slavery to freedom, we propose to institute a brief historical parallel between the progress of the two sections whose institutions so widely differ as to have parted them asunder, confining ourselves in this article to the relative increase in numbers and political power.
headline: {'main': 'An Historical Contrast.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'An Historical Contrast.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We have seen a gentleman who left Savannah on Thursday last, in the steamer Montgomery, after having spent several weeks in that city. He says that the public feeling there is excited to the intensest pitch. It was the universal expectation that JEFFERSON DAVIS would place himself immediately at the head of the Southern Army and march for Washington. It was the universal belief that Washington would be in the hands of the Secessionists within twenty days. Troops were constantly drilled in the city, and a regiment was expected from the interior.

abstract: By gentlemen who have arrived in this City, having left Washington as late as Sunday morning, and through dispatches from Havre de Grace, Harrisburgh and Philadelphia, we arrive at
lead_paragraph: By gentlemen who have arrived in this City, having left Washington as late as Sunday morning, and through dispatches from Havre de Grace, Harrisburgh and Philadelphia, we arrive at a tolerable idea of the condition of affairs at the National Capital. There are now stationed there, it is believed, a sufficient number of troops to defend it against any attacks possible to be made. A body of Virginia troops was said to be threatening it from the vicinity of Arlington Heights, but not in sufficient force to create any alarm. The Seventh Regiment of New-York is now probably there, as a dispatch states that they had left Annapolis, at which point they were last previously heard from. The reports which were flying about yesterday, to the effect that the Seventh had had a terrible battle with the Secessionist forces at Annapolis, were the sheerest canards.

abstract: South Carolina has shown a great deal of pluck in her efforts to prepare for war. She has sent to Europe, according to report, and bought rifled cannon. The North are at least
lead_paragraph: South Carolina has shown a great deal of pluck in her efforts to prepare for war. She has sent to Europe, according to report, and bought rifled cannon. The North are at least her equal in will and courage. We have one thousand fold her money and means to buy in Europe the best munitions of war. The nation that brings into the field the most destructive artillery and rifles will win the day. Witness the campaign of LOUIS NAPOLEON in Italy.

abstract: True to the programme marked out by us some days ago, Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS has transferred his head-quarters to Richmond. Virginia is his chosen battle-ground. He is
lead_paragraph: True to the programme marked out by us some days ago, Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS has transferred his head-quarters to Richmond. Virginia is his chosen battle-ground. He is either there or soon will be. The celerity of his movements proves how well-concerted are his plans, and how prompt he is in their execution. Richmond is 1,000 miles from Montgomery. So far North, by magic, almost, has the Confederated Government transported itself. We do not complain. In Virginia we can deal a hundred blows at once at the hydra-headed monster.

abstract: declared that it was sweet and glorious to [???] for one's country, and described with me' [???] aphoric rapture the sublime spectacle of a Nation with all its sails spread for the Ocean of War. What poet or historian. ever conceived or witnessed so mighty a spectacle as that which is now proceeding, in our midst. The hurried partings with which, the air reverberates, the "God-bless-yous" which hangon so many lips, the cheerful alacrity with which men forget themselves in the one perception of a patriotic duty, are the themselves the sufficient poem and glorious, history of a brave, loyal and virtuous people. One cannot ride in [a] public conveyance, or visit a private friend, without suffocating with suppressed pride and emotion, at that which he hears and sees around him.

abstract: The steamer Florida, which arrived from Savannah this forenoon, brought a large number of passengers, among them many business men ,and fam
lead_paragraph: The steamer Florida, which arrived from Savannah this forenoon, brought a large number of passengers, among them many business men ,and families, who were but too glad to escape from the place. All business is said to be at an end both there and in Charleston. They were throwing up sand batteries at Tybee, evidently expecting an attack from the sea. Troops in large numbers continued to occupy Charleston, and there was a general belief that a fleet would soon appear off the port to attack the place. The steamer Isabel has been taken and fitted up as a man-of-war. The old tug-boat Huntress had been converted into an armed revenue cutter; they also have a small steamer called the Everglade running about the harbor. The Nashville had been detained at Charleston, and the Florida only escaped by adopting a ruse.

abstract: An enthusiastic meeting was held in Bloomfield, N.J., on Tuesday evening last, to endeavor to fill up a company for the contingent which the State is required to furnish, and to raise money to provide for the families of those who volunteered. Addresses were made by Rev. Mr. NEWLIN, pastor of the Presbyterian Church, by Rev. GEO. DUFFIELD, of Philadelphia, Col. HENRY J. MILLS, and by Mr. AMZI DODD. The latter, as Chairman of the Committee appointed for that purpose, reported a series of exceedingly comprehensive resolutions, which were adopted unanimously. Within fifteen minutes after the adjournment of the meeting $1,000 were subscribed toward the volunteer fund, and pledges were given for the payment of any amount which might be called for. Quite a number enrolled their names as volunteers.
lead_paragraph: An enthusiastic meeting was held in Bloomfield, N.J., on Tuesday evening last, to endeavor to fill up a company for the contingent which the State is required to furnish, and to raise money to provide for the families of those who volunteered. abstract: The navigation of the Potomac had not been obstructed in any way up to Monday evening last, and several vessels had passed in both directions. The commander at Fort Washington brought every vessel to, and examined into their character before allowing them to proceed. The Government steamer Anacastra came up on Monday night and reported all clear on the river.

abstract: The ladies are preparing vigorously and in good season for the care of the wounded in the coming war. The Committee appointed on Monday at Mr. RAYMOND'S residence, met yesterday at the Chapel of Dr. POTTS' Church.
lead_paragraph: The ladies are preparing vigorously and in good season for the care of the wounded in the coming war. The Committee appointed on Monday at Mr. RAYMOND'S residence, met yesterday at the Chapel of Dr. POTTS' Church. Mr. WILLARD PARKER, the President,explained to the very large number of ladies present, the manner in which the Association proposed to labor for the accomplishment of its object viz.: the preparation of lint, bandages, wrappers and other articles which will be needed by the wounded. A room in the Society Library has been offered for their use. At this room cotton and linen-cloth and other material will be given out to ladies who may desire to work in this cause. Some one will be present to explain the manner of making the articles needed, and when made they will be returned to this room, properly backed in boxes and placed at the disposal of the surgical and hospital authorities. The room at the Society Library will be ready to day.

abstract: Robert M. Wilson vs. H.B. Foote et al.-- This was a motion to vacate an order of arrest, the action having been brought on a promissory note against both maker and indorser. The plaintiff alleges is his affidavit that he performed certain work and labor for the defendants, for which he took their note, the defendants, as alleged, at the time representing themselves to be men of means, whereas, it is alleged, that they were wholly insolvent and carried on a quick business as doctors in this City. The defendant. Foote, however, was discharged on the ground of his exemption from arrest, being an alleged assistant surgeon to the Second Regiment, then awaiting marching orders. The motion, however, as to the other defendant was laid over until Saturday, to enable him to put in for her affidavits.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Mr. Garvin prosecuting for the people, Charles Herring was put to the bar on four indictments for rapes and one for robbery. The prisoner was charged with a series of most disgusting outrages on little girls, decoyed from Broadway into out-of-the-way halls and yards. From one of these girls it seems that the prisoner took a dollar bill by force. In order to avoid the publicity into which the misfortune of the little girls would be brought by the prisoner's trial on the charges of rape, his plea of guilty on the charge of robbery was taken, and he was sent to State Prison for ten years.

abstract: In every great crisis, the human heart demands a leader that incarnates its ideas, its emotions and its aims. Till such a leader appears, everything is disorder, disaster and defeat.
lead_paragraph: In every great crisis, the human heart demands a leader that incarnates its ideas, its emotions and its aims. Till such a leader appears, everything is disorder, disaster and defeat. The moment he takes the helm, order, promptitude and confidence follow as the necessary result. When we see such results, we know that a hero leads. No such hero at present directs affairs. The experience of our Government for months past has been a series of defeats. It has been one continued retreat. Its path is marked by the wrecks of property destroyed. It has thus far only urged war upon itself. It confidingly enters into compacts with traitors who seek them merely to gain time better to strike a fatal blow. Stung to the quick by the disgraces we have suffered, by the disasters sustained, by the treachery which threatens the annihilation of all order, law, and property, and by the insults heaped upon our National banner, the people have sprung to arms, and demand satisfaction for wounded honor and for violation of laws, which must be vindicated, or we may at once bid farewell to society, to government, and to property, and sink into barbarism.
headline: {'main': 'Wanted A Leader!', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Wanted A Leader!', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: And there are in New-York, Boston, Philadelphia and vicinity ten thousand skilled men, with tools and working drawings at hand, to make them. Gun-boats of all sizes, from 120 to 400 tons; corvettes, frigates, transports, everything, anything, are immediately demanded by the exigencies of the times.
lead_paragraph: And there are in New-York, Boston, Philadelphia and vicinity ten thousand skilled men, with tools and working drawings at hand, to make them. Gun-boats of all sizes, from 120 to 400 tons; corvettes, frigates, transports, everything, anything, are immediately demanded by the exigencies of the times. Why are they not demanded by Government? Up to yesterday afternoon the Government had invited no tenders, made no proposals, solicited no advice, and given no orders, not so much as for a donkey-engine, to either of the great engineering, establishments of this City, nor, as it was believed, to those of Philadelphia.

abstract: The Twenty fifth Albany Regiment yesterday forenoon marched from the Battery, where they had been encamped for the night, to the Armory, corner of White and Elm streets, and took dinner. They were warmly cheered as they marched through Broadway. After refreshing themselves, the Regiment was again formed, and marched to Pier No. 1, North River, where a steamtug was provided to take them on board of the Parkersburg, which was anchored in the stream. They were loudly cheered as they embarked, and the neighboring steamers and vessels gave the usual salutes. The Regiment numbers some 600 men, and are composed of the picked military of Albany. The vessel goes provided with light artillery and howitzers for protection against attack by sea or on land. This Regiment will reach Annapolis in forty-eight hours from New-York. The Chesapeake carried large quantities of supplies to Fort Monroe. She also went under convoy of the United States brig Perry.

abstract: expanding qualities rumor in these exciting times was well illustrated yesterday. The TIMES' correspondent having arrived from Washington, announced in our noon extra, yesterday, that he had good reason to believe that the Seventh Regiment had marched over to the Capital from Annapolis, during Monday night. Within an hour, our correspondent was quoted by name, as having stated to various parties that he saw the Regiment in question a few miles out from Washington. Of course, there was no foundation for this exaggerated statement.

abstract: Burnham Benson vs. The New-Jersey Transportation Company. -- This case was reported in the TIMES on the 23d inst. The action was brought to recover damages for not carrying the plaintiff to Philadelphia by the 12 o'clock train, at which time he presented himself at the depot to go, but the defendants refused to carry him. He purchased his ticket with a view of going on this particular train, and by reason of his not going, he alleges that he suffered damages. The Jury, being unable to agree upon a verdict, were discharged.

abstract: Since the Davis rebellion has assumed its present threatening aspect, we have constantly, urged the absolute necessity of the greatest promptness of action on the part of those who control the national campaign.
lead_paragraph: Since the Davis rebellion has assumed its present threatening aspect, we have constantly, urged the absolute necessity of the greatest promptness of action on the part of those who control the national campaign. We have based our urgent demands in this behalf chiefly on the ground that a decisive blow struck now, while the rebel forces are yet unorganized, will be the means of saving many thousands of lives, and will prevent the traitors from acquiring hereafter any strength by unity of action. Nor, in the pursuance of this course, have we given utterance simply to individual opinions. There is not a town or hamlet in any of the loyal States, which has not organized its military force, and asked, nay, entreated, that its active aid might be accepted in the support of the national flag.

abstract: We have intelligence from the National Capital up to 3 o'clock, on Tuesday afternoon, through a New-York merchant who reached Harrisburgh, by way of Chambersburgh, yesterday.
lead_paragraph: We have intelligence from the National Capital up to 3 o'clock, on Tuesday afternoon, through a New-York merchant who reached Harrisburgh, by way of Chambersburgh, yesterday. He says that there are now more than ten thousand troops in Washington, while the force of Virginia Secessionists previously reported at Alexandria, numbers only about two thousand, and that not more than one-half of the latter are armed. It was known to the Government that Gen. BEAUREGARD, lately commanding the secession forces at Charleston, was expected in Richmond on Tuesday, but nothing is said of JEFP. DAVIS' proximity to that point, though the statement that the secession President has already made Richmond his headquarters is positively made. Washington, however, may now be considered safe. Gen. SCOTT is rapidly, extending his pickets into Maryland, and they will soon reach Annapolis, and thus the line of road will be kept open to the Capital for the transportation of troops going through Harrisburgh, and also by water from Havre de Grace and other points, until such time as a safe passage can be insured through Baltimore. For a highly interesting account of the condition of affairs at Washington up to Tuesday morning, we refer to the statement of our special correspondent.

abstract: A meeting was held at Palace Garden, on Monday evening last, for the purpose of organizing a guard of men over 45 years for home defence. The following Committee was appointed to carry out the objects of the meeting: Major A.M. BININGER, Col. CHARLES B. TAPPEN, Col. BURR WAKEMAN, SAMUEL HOTALING, Esq., and Judge EDMONDS. Upwards of 300 names were enrolled on Monday evening, and the meeting adjourned to 7 1/2 P.M. to-day, when further measures will be adopted for the organization of this "Old Men's Home Guard."

abstract: The Administration have not yet begun to comprehend that the conspiracy with which they are dealing is one of more than ten years' growth, and that the leaders in it are men of great experience, boldness and capacity, animated by a fanatical hatred of the North, and the non-slaveholding portions of the Union. So far from being a consequence of LINCOLN's election, this armed outbreak would have taken place on the admission of California as a State, had it not been that the simultaneous passage of the measures of compromise, and the admitted prudence, forbearance and firmness of President FILLMORE furnished a ground for the conservatives of the Southern States to rally upon, and drive back the hordes of secession. The Browns, Thompsons, Quitmans and Davises, of Mississippi, were ready at that time to proclaim, with the Convention of the Southern Rights Associations of South Carolina, that, "with or without cooperation, they were for a dissolution of the Union." At the Nashville Convention of 1850, the States of Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Mississippi, South Carolina and Virginia were all in favor of a Congress of Slaveholding States to expedite and accomplish this dissolution. The treason was staggered by the defection of Tennessee, and soon afterwards the adoption of resolutions of acquiescence in the Compromise measures in the Convention of Georgia, by the overwhelming vote of 237 to 19, arrested the current of rebellion, and brought back all the malcontent States, except South Carolina, to a seeming, but delusive loyalty.
lead_paragraph: The Administration have not yet begun to comprehend that the conspiracy with which they are dealing is one of more than ten years' growth, and that the leaders in it are men of great experience, boldness and capacity, animated by a fanatical hatred of the North, and the non-slaveholding portions of the Union. abstract: Does the Secretary of the Navy see the point? In twenty days, when the Government may perhaps have waked up to the fact that it wants gun-boats by the dozen, and wonders why the great shops cannot turn them out like sewing machines or cockades, there will be but a half or a quarter of the usual complement of artisans to build them.
lead_paragraph: Does the Secretary of the Navy see the point? In twenty days, when the Government may perhaps have waked up to the fact that it wants gun-boats by the dozen, and wonders why the great shops cannot turn them out like sewing machines or cockades, there will be but a half or a quarter of the usual complement of artisans to build them. We were yesterday informed at the large shops in this City, that the men generally preferred leaving regular work for the excitement of military service, and that large numbers declared their willingness to sacrifice regular pay to serve the Government gratis. Some of the managers, knowing the Government's necessity for ships, boilers and engines, are making an effort to keep their men within reach, hoping for orders by every courier. In a week it will be too late to act with maximum effect.

abstract: CARE FOR THE SICK. -- The preparation of lint and bandages and similar articles has been organized on a large scale and is earned forward efficiently. But there may be quite as much suffering from sickness as from wounds. Many of the members of our regiments are unused to a hard and irregular life; all of them undergo a change of habit, climate and diet, which would be trying to any constitution. It is important, therefore, that the requisite garments and other articles of hospital use, should be provided, in addition to those of lint and bandage which are now being so liberally supplied. In order to meet these wants some ladies in the upper part of the City have secured the large social parlors of the Broadway Tabernacle, corner or Thirty-fourth-street, which the trustees of the building have gladly given use of, and invite a meeting this afternoon at 2 o'clock, to organize for the purpose.

abstract: A NEW ADJUTANT-GENERAL - Gov. MORGAN has appointed Major PATRICK to the office of Adjutant-General. He is a man of experience and great energy; has served in the Florida and Mexican wars, and possesses ample qualifications for the post. He has occupied for several years the post of President of the Agricultural College at Ovid, but gladly vacates it to take part in the war. -- Evening Post.

abstract: The chartered steamer Empire City arrived at this port yesterday, from Indianola, Texas, via Havana, where she put in for coal and provisions. At the time the Empire City left, the steamer Star of the West, which has since been seized by the authorities of Louisiana, was anchored in the harbor, awaiting the arrival of more troops from Forts Lancaster, Blies, Davis, and other posts. The soldiers that reached here yesterday embarked on the 12th inst., and belong exclusively to the Third Infantry and Second Cavalry -- 277 of the latter, and 316 of the former -- 593 men, all told.

abstract: The funds on the 12th opened steadily, but were subsequently depressed to the extent of 3/8@1/2 cent. by disquieting -- but unconfirmed rumors from Paris. The chief allegations were that 60,000 French, troops had been suddenly ordered to Marseilles, and that the French Government had notified, or was about to notify its intention to protract indefinitely the occupation of Syria. Consols finally closed dull at 91 3/8@1/2 for money and 91 3/8@3/5 for account. There was increased rate in the discount market under the reduction of the Bank minimum from 6 to 5 cent. and good bills were done at 4 1/2@4 3/4 cent. The demand at the Bank was moderate.

The chief allegations were that 60,000 French, troops had been suddenly ordered to Marseilles, and that the French Government had notified, or was about to notify its intention to protract indefinitely the occupation of Syria. Consols finally closed dull at 91 3/8@1/2 for money and 91 3/8@3/5 for account. There was increased rate in the discount market under the reduction of the Bank minimum from 6 to 5 cent. and good bills were done at 4 1/2@4 3/4 cent. The demand at the Bank was moderate.

abstract: Secession in such a State as Virginia is certain repudiation. She has seceded, and will of necessity repudiate; yet Virginia can to-day raise a million in Wall-street, (but nowhere else,) by the sale of her already depreciated bonds. These are as current, at a price, as are New-York securities. It is no matter at what price the State gets
lead_paragraph: Secession in such a State as Virginia is certain repudiation. She has seceded, and will of necessity repudiate; yet Virginia can to-day raise a million in Wall-street, (but nowhere else,) by the sale of her already depreciated bonds. These are as current, at a price, as are New-York securities. It is no matter at what price the State gets off a security it never intends to pay. It would be a crowning triumph for the people of Virginia to take a million dollars out of New-York, in exchange for worthless bonds, to be expended in arming and equipping themselves to attack our own citizens. Yet this can be done without the least difficulty. We see no other mode by which Virginia can raise money. She can sell bonds in no other market but our own. We know that the operation described has already suggested itself to the astute compatriots of FLOYD, who took more than a million of clean money out of the North for similar objects, by his fraudulent acceptances, and he is one of the honored men of the State, and quite recently its Governor.

abstract: A special messenger from the TIMES Office has just returned to this City from a tour of observation in the South. He left Norfolk on Monday night; was present at the burning of Gosport Navy-Yard; and visited the new defences erected by the Virginians below Norfolk and Portsmouth. He confirms the statements of our correspondent "York," that Gov. WISE was at Norfolk on Monday, and that as late as Tuesday neither DAVIS nor BEAUREGARD were in Richmond, nor had any formidable army been concentrated anywhere in Virginia.

abstract: There seems now to be no longer any necessity for fearing for the safety of Washington. From information furnished to us from apparently authentic sources, we have no doubt that the Sixth, Seventh, Twelfth and Seventy-first New York Regiments are now there, and prepared, with the troops from other States which have also reached there, to oppose successfully any demonstration which the Secessionists may see fit to make against the place.
lead_paragraph: There seems now to be no longer any necessity for fearing for the safety of Washington. From information furnished to us from apparently authentic sources, we have no doubt that the Sixth, Seventh, Twelfth and Seventy-first New York Regiments are now there, and prepared, with the troops from other States which have also reached there, to oppose successfully any demonstration which the Secessionists may see fit to make against the place. It is reported that the latter are rapidly concentrating at some point in the vicinity; but the report that JEFF. DAVIS has already arrived in Richmond is now positively denied. It is also denied that Gen. BEAUREGARD is there, or anywhere else in Virginia. It is a fact, however, that ALEX. H. STEPHENS, the Secessionist Vice-President, is there, and we publish, this morning, a report of a speech made there by him only two nights ago.

abstract: A dispatch received by Mr. STETSON, of the Astor House, states that the Seventh Regiment arrived in Washington on Thursday, at 12 o'clock noon. The eighth., Massachusetts Regiment, arrived at 4 o'clock P.M. The Rhode Island Regiment, and the Seventy-first, New-York, were at the junction, Thursday, but are undoubtedly in Washington are this. The Sixth and Twelfth New-York Regiments had just arrived at Annapolis, Communication is complete between Annapolis and Washington. The arrival of there troops at Washington was the first positive information that the North were bestirring themselves in behalf of the Government, and produced great rejoicing.

abstract: When the boats from the Baltic landed at Fort Monrce, one of them was left at the fort under the command of Lieut. SNYDER, U.S.A., who was a passenger in the Baltic.
lead_paragraph: When the boats from the Baltic landed at Fort Monrce, one of them was left at the fort under the command of Lieut. SNYDER, U.S.A., who was a passenger in the Baltic. Soon afterwards he started from the fort, having in his boat a hewitzer, with two boxes of ammunition and 16 boxes of rifle cartridges. The current was so strong that the heavy-laden boat could not make the ship, and was only brought up about five miles away from her by making an anchor of a box of rifle cartridges, and she drifted into shallow water, awaiting either a change of tide or succor from the Baltic. While lying there, two horsemen came down to the beach, and after surveying the boat for a few minutes, retired and retorted to a company of soldiers, who were concealed in the bushes at some distance from the beach. The horsemen returned in about half and hour, and riding into the water, flourishing their swords, hailed the boat and asked who she was and what was her business there. Lieut. SNYDER replied that it was a boat from the Baltic, with a howitzer and ammunition for that vessel. The horsemen rode off without further question, the word howitzer probably conveying the idea of sharper work than they were prepared to encounter, and Lieut. S. was unmolested during the remainder of the night. At the change of tide he made his way to the Baltic, reaching her about daylight, with the loss of one box of rifle cartridges.

abstract: We have held some very plain talk with the Government, lately, on behalf of the People.
lead_paragraph: We have held some very plain talk with the Government, lately, on behalf of the People. We have told them that, so far as we could judge from their acts, they did not at all comprehend the real nature of the struggle that awaits the country; that while the people regard it as a struggle for life, as a contest on the issue of which hangs the existence of this Republic, with the preservation of its liberties and rights, to all appearance the Government look upon it as merely a temporary ebullition of passion, involving nothing more important than the safety of the Capital at Washington. The apparent inactivity of the Government, -- its repeated and disastrous defeats in its contests with the Rebellion its loss of Sumter, us waste of arms at Harper's Ferry, the needless destruction of its ships-of-war and of the vast amount of munitions of war collected at the Navy-yard at Gospert, its apparent surrender of the right of way for the Flag of the Republic through the City of Baltimore and the State of Maryland, -- these and other mishaps scarcely less serious, infused into the public mind a feeling of profound sorrow, which threatened the most perilous consequences, unless it should be removed by the revived energy and intelligent activity of the Government.

abstract: We commend to the earnest attention of the authorities at Washington the Virginia correspondence of the TIMES.
lead_paragraph: We commend to the earnest attention of the authorities at Washington the Virginia correspondence of the TIMES. It was through this correspondence that the public were yesterday enabled to read the riddle of Virginia politics, and understand why is was that when DAVIS and BEAUREGARD had promised to lead an army on Washington, only STEPHENS, the Vice-President and civilian, appeared at Richmond. It is now at once recognized that Virginia has not been in accord with South Carolina and the Confederate States. Many members of the Virginia Convention who voted for the Secession Ordinance, did so with the distinct understanding that Secession did not mean union with the Gulf States. And this point was readily conceded by the immediate Secessionists, in order to secure something near unanimity in the vote for Secession.

abstract: Gentlemen have arrived in this City from Montgomery, whence they took their departure on Sunday last. The utmost dismay was caused by the announcement of the fact that New-York City was furnishing troops to support the Federal Government. On Sunday a telegraphic dispatch was published in which the statement was made that about a hundred of the New-York Seventh Regiment had been killed at Baltimore, and the remainder taken prisoners. This piece of forgery excited the Secessionists to the highest pitch of enthusiasm, demonstrated by wild shouts and other evidences of excitement. Every Northern man was in peril, and New-Yorkers were particularly denounced. JEFF. DAVIS was in Montgomery on Sunday evening.

abstract: The follwing are the names of two boats' crew picked up at sea by steamship De Soto, off Dividing Creck, Va., Thursday, April 25, 1861, belonging to schooner T.O. Thompson, wrecked on Bluff Point, Va., April 9.
lead_paragraph: The follwing are the names of two boats' crew picked up at sea by steamship De Soto, off Dividing Creck, Va., Thursday, April 25, 1861, belonging to schooner T.O. Thompson, wrecked on Bluff Point, Va., April 9. They were notified to leave within two hours, or take the oath to fight for the South. They escaped in open boats, and were only out a few hours when discovered by Capt. JOHNSTON, of the De Soto. Two of their men are in jail at Lancaster, Va., and were told that they should be starved to death unless they took the oath to fight for the South. They are British subjects, belonging in Novia Scotia:

abstract: One effect of the ordinance of Secession, passed by the Convention of Virginia, to be followed immediately by a similar one by Maryland, will be to transfer this question them the board field of National to that of State politics.
lead_paragraph: One effect of the ordinance of Secession, passed by the Convention of Virginia, to be followed immediately by a similar one by Maryland, will be to transfer this question them the board field of National to that of State politics. The territories comprising these two States are as dissimilar in soil, climate and material features and productions as are New-York and South Carolina. As a necessary consequence, a dissimilarity nearly as striking exists in the industrial and social organization of the people, occupying what may be termed the Highland and Lowland portions of them. Those of the former being composed almost entirely of freemen, while upon the Lowlands of each State the negro composes nearly one-half of the population. These people consequently are irreconcilably opposed to each other, and the moment they dissolve their ties with the Federal Government, the question of secession of one section from the other arises with tenfold force, and will, unless these States return to their allegiance, divide each of them into several distinct communities.

abstract: Mr. WM. B. ASTOR, on Thursday, placed $5,000 in the hands of WM. H. ASPINWALL, to appropriate for the purpose of keeping open communication between Havre de Grace and Annapolis.
lead_paragraph: Mr. WM. B. ASTOR, on Thursday, placed $5,000 in the hands of WM. H. ASPINWALL, to appropriate for the purpose of keeping open communication between Havre de Grace and Annapolis. In twenty-four hours' time the steamer Yankee was chartered, equipped, and dispatched upon this mission. She sailed at 11 o'clock A.M., yesterday, in command of Capt. Fox. The Yankee will convoy vessels from the Capes up the Chesapeake, and run as a dispatch steamer between Havre de Grace and Annapolis, until the route through Baltimore is reestablished. She is armed with two long 32-pounder guns, small arms, &c.

abstract: To what extent it may be necessary to make the war with the rebels aggressive will depend upon how the rebels may behave: but parents yield up their children now to fight the battles of the country and fathers take the field, leaving behind them their wives and children without a regret or misgiving, because they feel that they are going to a war of self-defense.
lead_paragraph: To what extent it may be necessary to make the war with the rebels aggressive will depend upon how the rebels may behave: but parents yield up their children now to fight the battles of the country and fathers take the field, leaving behind them their wives and children without a regret or misgiving, because they feel that they are going to a war of self-defense. The issue is no longer one of Slavery and Anti-Slavery opinion -- of dissolution of the Union by consent of the People, or dismemberment at the will of an Oligarchy; but it is between the Supremacy of the Law and the Rule of a Mob -- between Order and Anarchy -- between a Constitutional Republic and a Military Despotism. It is indeed a war of self-defence that the loyal States are now waging for the maintenance of their Government. It is a question with them of life or death -- a choice between upholding their flag and their Government, or being disgraced in the eyes of the world and blotted forever from the catalogue of nations.

abstract: Mr. G. TWICHELL, President of the Boston and Worcester Railroad, arrived from Washington yesterday, having been engaged by the Government to [???] forwarding the mails. He came through the Potomac and by sea, -- in the Keystone State. He states that the Potomac does not seem to be obstructed, -- is he saw no evidence of hostile batteries at any point. On Thursday, at 11 A.M., they met, off Rappahannock Point, about 175 miles from Washington, the James Aager with the Sixty-ninth N.Y. Regiment, together with the Alabama and Marion, and the United States brig Perry. They stopped, and the Keystone State gave them notice of the destruction of the lights at the entrance of the Potomac. At 1 P.M. on the same day, they met the propeller Montgomery, going with the Eighth New-York Regiment to Annapolis. They stopped and boarded her off Wolf-Trap light. At 4 1/2 o'clock they met the Philadelphia ice-boats, loaded with troops. No mails had been received at Washington from North of Baltimore since Friday of last week.

abstract: The steamship De Soto, Capt. JOHNSTON, arrived last night from Annapolis, Md., where she has been to convey troops for the defence of Washington.
lead_paragraph: The steamship De Soto, Capt. JOHNSTON, arrived last night from Annapolis, Md., where she has been to convey troops for the defence of Washington. The De Soto left New-York on Monday morning, April 22d, with 650 troops of the Fifth Regiment of Massachusetts, and 120 of the Flying Artillery of Boston, and 72 horses. She went to Fort Monroe, and from there to Annapolis. The De Soto left on her return for New-York on Thursday, in company with the Baltic and Columbia. Passed the Florida, Augusta and Marion, with the brig. Perry in tow, within six hours' sail of Annapolis, and at 3 P.M. same day passed the steamship Montgomery, off Smith's Point, with the Eighth Regiment of New-York on board. We found all lights out on the Virginia and Maryland shores.

abstract: The U.S. steamer Corwin, under revenue colors, is doing valuable service in the lower bay. All vessels outward bound are boarded by her officers, and if the vessels papers are found correct, they are allowed to proceed. Occasionally it is necessary to throw a shot across the bows of a vessel, which speedily has the effect to bring them to. Officers MCMANNUS an MORRIS are detailed on this service.

lead_paragraph: In this Court, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Mr. Garvin prosecuring for the people, there was but one case, that of Strohmeyer for larceny; the prisoner was indicted with the three prisoners, Meyers, Hoffman and Brown, in whose case of the day previous the jury had disagreed. The same testimony was produced against the present prisoner, as in the other case, and the jury, as then failing to agree, were discharged, and the prisoner was regarded.

abstract: The steamer Keyseone State, direct from Washington arrived here at noon, yesterday, bringing as passegers, Col. BONHEVILLE, of the United States Army, and Gen. TWITCHELL and SETH BRYANT, Esq., both of Boston, and Mr. PARROTT, member of Congress from Kansas, bound home.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Keyseone State, direct from Washington arrived here at noon, yesterday, bringing as passegers, Col. BONHEVILLE, of the United States Army, and Gen. TWITCHELL and SETH BRYANT, Esq., both of Boston, and Mr. PARROTT, member of Congress from Kansas, bound home. The Keystone State left Washington on Wednesday, afternoon at 4 o'clock, and brings some forty or fifty bags of mail matter for the North and East, all of which is in charge of Gen. TWITCHELL. She also brings the dispatches and instructions from Government to Mr. ADAMS, our newly appointed Minister to London. The Keystone State has two Companies of United States marines on board, and is well armed and was well provided to resist any attack that might be made on her, but she met with no interruption on her passage down the Potomac.

abstract: The advantages in the struggle for position may now be considered as decidedly in favor of the Government. The troops now in Washington, -- including the Seventh of this City, which has positively arrived there in safety, -- are amply sufficient to hold the city against any Secessionist forces likely to be brought against it for some time to come. But activity is not to cease with the present safety of the Capital, and troops will continue to be concentrated there until they reach a number which shall render any ultimate attempt against it improbable. The Secessionist forces now collected in Virginia are said to number some 14,000, but it is not likely, from all we can learn, that they are more than had armed. Meantime, from every point in the North and West the note of preparation continue to be sounded, and troops are being placed at the disposal of the Government with marvelous rapidly.

abstract: The steamship Columbia, Capt. WHITING, arrived yesterday in 29 hours from Annapolis. Left at Annapolis the United States cutter Harriet Lane, also steamers Coatzocoalcos, Boston and the R.R. Cuyler the latter discharging stores.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Columbia, Capt. WHITING, arrived yesterday in 29 hours from Annapolis. Left at Annapolis the United States cutter Harriet Lane, also steamers Coatzocoalcos, Boston and the R.R. Cuyler the latter discharging stores. Thursday, 2 P.M., off mouth of the Potomac River, passed steamers Marion, Alabama and James Adger, the latter having in tow the United States brig Perry. Off the mouth of the Rappannock River, passed a three-masted propeller, bound to Annapolis.

abstract: A deputation of sixteen Virginians and eight Marylanders visited the President on Monday, and demanded a cessation of hostilities until after the session of Congress, Mr. LINCOLN of couse declined the preposition. One of the deputation said that 75,000 Marylanders would contest the passage of troops over her soil; to which the President replied that he presumed there was room enough on her soil to bury 75,000 men. The answer was prompt and decided.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, April 24, 1861.

abstract: In the year 1861 we do not travel by stage-coach and sail, nor put out fires by hand-pumps, nor back manufactories up to mountain sides for water-power, nor make things out of wood and metal with jack-knives, breast-drills and hand-tools, as a general rule. Steam, the incarnation of power, grapples the ship's crank, the car coupling, the fire-engine break, the machine-tool, with its ten thousand iron fists, and stands ready to produce any finite dynamical result that it hath entered into the brain of man to conceive. Steam traction engines are this day dragging artillery and stores for the British Government over swamps where animals cannot walk, and steam-wagons are in service here and in Europe which can run with men and artillery twenty miles an hour through such places as Pratt-street, Baltimore, anchors and paving-stones to the contrary, notwithstanding, especially if the grand objection to steam in the streets -- that it may run over somebody -- is valid.
lead_paragraph: In the year 1861 we do not travel by stage-coach and sail, nor put out fires by hand-pumps, nor back manufactories up to mountain sides for water-power, nor make things out of wood and metal with jack-knives, breast-drills and hand-tools, as a general rule. Steam, the incarnation of power, grapples the ship's crank, the car coupling, the fire-engine break, the machine-tool, with its ten thousand iron fists, and stands ready to produce any finite dynamical result that it hath entered into the brain of man to conceive. abstract: The medical men of this City, of all classes and schools, veterans and students, have rushed forward at the present crisis to offer their services to their country with an enthusiasm with which the Faculty would hardly be credited.
lead_paragraph: The medical men of this City, of all classes and schools, veterans and students, have rushed forward at the present crisis to offer their services to their country with an enthusiasm with which the Faculty would hardly be credited. Professors, such as the noble DALTON and others, have forsaken their luxurious chairs to join in the hardships of a soldier's life; some of the most distinguished practitioners have left a practice worth tens of thousands, that they may go to alleviate the sufferings of the camp; and now the medical Head-quarters of the army are daily crowded with the most brilliant surgeons offering themselves for service in the field; while others, unable to get appointments on account of the number offering, have volunteered as privates, in hopes that their science and skill might somehow be made available to their country.

abstract: The Second Regiment of the Hudson County Brigade took their departure, on Friday afternoon, at 1 o'clock from the Jersey City Depot for their rendezvous at Trenton.
lead_paragraph: The Second Regiment of the Hudson County Brigade took their departure, on Friday afternoon, at 1 o'clock from the Jersey City Depot for their rendezvous at Trenton. At an early hour in the morning men, women and children gathered around the quarters of the different companies, and by 10 or 11 o'clock the member had swelled to many thousands, and at the time of the departure of the soldiers there could not save been less than 20,000 persons in the Depot, and for half a mile or more along the line of the Railroad.
