abstract: The special session of the Legislature, convened by the Governor at a period in the fearful crisis of the day, when almost all hope is banished, and legislative action can be at best only remedial, demands the exercise of the utmost wisdom and prudence.
lead_paragraph: The special session of the Legislature, convened by the Governor at a period in the fearful crisis of the day, when almost all hope is banished, and legislative action can be at best only remedial, demands the exercise of the utmost wisdom and prudence. We are unwilling to fling reproach against any man in official position, and we can only say that the accountability which the Governor of Maryland has incurred in deferring to this eleventh hour the act he has now authorized, can be best relieved by the wise and discreet deliberations of those upon whom the aggravated burden of responsibility is now devolved. It is impossible to say what has conduced to the sad procrastination which seems to have been fruitful only of perplexity and disaster; but accepting it as an error of judgment, or an unfortunate subordination to the opinions of others, or to the strong prejudices of party, it remains now for the Legislature to make the best of the condition.

abstract: I have been about ten days in Washington. My business was not urgent, but my curiosity was intense; and for the first week it had ample food in watching the coolness with which a great Government participated in squabbles about Spoils, while the thunders of armed rebellion were rousing the echoes of the Capital.
lead_paragraph: I have been about ten days in Washington. My business was not urgent, but my curiosity was intense; and for the first week it had ample food in watching the coolness with which a great Government participated in squabbles about Spoils, while the thunders of armed rebellion were rousing the echoes of the Capital. But the best three days were spent in the midst of panic. The City of Baltimore had interposed between the Government and its military succors a mob power, backed by an overwhelming public sentiment, and had shed in its streets the first blood of the new Revolution; and the great question at Washington was whether an Administration, strong in resources and popular support, but having permitted its officers to be hemmed in by foes, could indeed draw to itself in time the needful succors to prevent the capture of the Capital and the possible extinction of the Government, by one bold stroke on the part of the conspirators.

abstract: The following is the ordinance of secession of Virginia, passed on the 17th inst., and which has just been made public. Accompanying the document is a long schedule, setting forth the time and manner of holding a poll for its ratification by the people, &c.A poll will be opened in each military camp of Virginia volunters, whether in or out of the State, and the voters there suffered to vote; this will be besides the regular election precincts. The election for members of Congress for Virginia to the Housse of Representatives of the Congress of the United States, required by law to be held on the 4th Thursday in May nest, is suspended and prohibited until otherwise ordained by the Convention.

abstract: The Vanderbilt line of steamers between New-York and Aspin wall have been armed against assault by privateers. Howitzers have been placed on board, with an adequate supply of the most approved arms. The crews, it is argued, supported by the large number of passengers always in transit, and amply provided with weapons and munitions, will be able to defend the several vessels against any force which Southern piracy may send for their capture.
lead_paragraph: The Vanderbilt line of steamers between New-York and Aspin wall have been armed against assault by privateers. Howitzers have been placed on board, with an adequate supply of the most approved arms. The crews, it is argued, supported by the large number of passengers always in transit, and amply provided with weapons and munitions, will be able to defend the several vessels against any force which Southern piracy may send for their capture. The officers in command are instructed, as an additional precaution, to give a wide berth to any suspiciously "long, low, black schooner" which may exhibit a desire to seek closer quarters than the exigencies of sea-room may require. This is all very well, and very wise. So far as the treasure-ships are concerned, the lines on both sides of the Isthmus -- the Pacific Mail Steamship Company having previously completed similar arrangements -- are thus upon a war footing, and perhaps able to resist the attack of any single vessel which may venture to dispute their safe passage.

abstract: former proprietor of the New-York Sun, sends a patriotic letter to a meeting in his native town, Wallingford, Conn., offering to assist the Government to the extent of $100,000. He also provides for a flag and liberty pole, and equips a Company of volunteers. Over 50 men enrolled at once. After the meeting adjourned, they visited Mr. BEACH's house and serenaded him. He is a Breckinridge Democrat.

abstract: We learn from sources that we cannot altogether discredit, that there are already near 10,000 volunteers assembled at Richmond, and that by the end of this week there will be fully 25,000 there.
lead_paragraph: We learn from sources that we cannot altogether discredit, that there are already near 10,000 volunteers assembled at Richmond, and that by the end of this week there will be fully 25,000 there. Some persons will ask why there is such a gathering of troops at Richmond, if, according to the theory of our Virginia correspondent, there is no organized plan on the part of the authorities of Virginia to seize the City of Washington? We can easily explain the presence of the military mob at Richmond, by republishing one of the editorials of the Richmond Examiner, of about ten days ago, which is a specimen of many of like tenor, not only from it, but from all the secession papers of Richmond:

abstract: The various steamers which have just returned from the Chesaperke, whither they were dispatched last week with troops, carne home in good condition for immediate service; he reduced number of pasaengers on the return trip affording the crew "scope and verge enough" to clean up the ships, and have them in reaoiness for use.
lead_paragraph: The various steamers which have just returned from the Chesaperke, whither they were dispatched last week with troops, carne home in good condition for immediate service; he reduced number of pasaengers on the return trip affording the crew "scope and verge enough" to clean up the ships, and have them in reaoiness for use. The Columbia, Baltic, Ariel, De Soto and R.R. Cuyler, are each receiving their coal for another voyage. Army-stores and provisions have been sent down, and there are indications that all there vessels will be ready by Monday to receive fresh regiments of troops. The Augusta, Capt. WOODHULL, of Samuel L. Mitchell's line, has been ready for a week. The Florida, of the same line, the last which arrived from Charleston, and the Star of the South, a fine screw-steamer, commanded by Capt. LYON, owned by MITCHILL & SON, has been taken up. She is about 1,000 tons burden, and will make an excellent transport. These vessels are receiving their coal and provisions, and are getting ready to sail at an hour's notice.

abstract: No portion of our population better understand the nature of the controversy between the North and South, or have responded more promptly to the call of Government for men and money, than our adopted citizens, and foreigners who have chosen this country as their residence. A vast proportion of them are from States where the workingman has few privileges, and is a subject rather than a citizen, and must accept, without hope of rising above it, the condition in which he was born. They know by experience the value of the blessings which our form of government has secured to them, and they are prepared to sustain them with as much alacrity as our most gallant native-born citizens. They see that where Slavery exists there must be a despotism infinitely more intolerable than those from which they have fled. They rush to arms to meet its first approach. The Irish and Germans already compose their full proportion of our forces. Every people of Europe will be represented in the great contest. This fact speaks volumes for the justice of a cause, that it enlists the hearty cooperation of those differing as widely as the poles in their nationalities, habits, education and training. Each of these nationalities will be emulous of excelling the other, so that an engagement on the field will be a consest to see who shall display the highest gallantry and conduct.

abstract: It is about time, now, that Virginia, magnificent Virginia, with her glorious climate, her exuberantly fertile soil, her infinite mineral resources, and her splendid commercial and manufacturing facilities, should be opened up for the occupation and settlement of free white men. In all the advantages which generous Nature can bestow, Virginia is unequaled by any State of the Union; she has within herself all the resources for an imperial realm unsurpassed by any other portioa of the globe. The early explorers described her wealth and beauty in language so rapturous that it would seem absurd, did not every man who has traversed her surface know that it does not half come up to the reality. Yet the fertile mother is now shriveled up into a premature hag; and her untilled and deteriorated soil, her wretched negro shanties, and her squalid mongrel population, actually seem like a burlesque on the magnificent surroundings of Nature.

abstract: The Jury of Inquest over the body of Mr. R.W. Davis met on Saturday morning at the Southern Distict police Station, at 9 o'clock.
lead_paragraph: The Jury of Inquest over the body of Mr. R.W. Davis met on Saturday morning at the Southern Distict police Station, at 9 o'clock. The first witness examined was Mr. T.W., Hall, Jr., who being sworn testified that he was on Pratt-street attending to some business about 11 o'clock A.M., when he saw the first car containing troops from the President-street Station pass through; hearing that the troops were the Seventh Regiment from New-York, and wishing to verify that fact by personal observation, started for the Camden-street station to see the soldiers change cars; on the way was overtaken by Mr. Davis, who joined him, and with him passed through the station on to the track beyond; being told by a reporter that a crowd of people had gone up the road to destroy the track, Mr. Davis and witness determined to walk out a short distance in advance of the train to see if such was really the case; they went as far out as the intersection of the Washington turnpike, and finding but few people and little excitement on the road, started to return; on the way back, overtook Mr. Buckler, of the firm of Buckler, Shipley & Co., and two others, also returning to the City; had just turned up the first paved street, on the outskirts of city, when they saw the train approaching, and unhappily stopped to gratify their curiosity by seeing the troops pass; took a position for the purpose by the roadside, on some cross ties thrown across a ditch; the windows of the first car were closed, and witness and Mr. Davis were speculating as to whether the troops were really on the train, when they observed the windows of the rear car open, and several muskets produced through, and pointed at them; in reply to what they considered a mere place of bravado on the part of the troops -- being ignorant at the time of any bloodshed, or that any collision with the people that taken place -- the party raised a cheer for Jefferson Davis and the Southern Confederacy; instantly several shots were fired -- five or six in all, witness thinks -- though there may not have been more than three or four; the group scattered instantly, Mr. DAVIS falling; witness, thinking that Mr. DAVIS had slipped upon the cross-ties, watch were wet, and afforded a very insecure footing, asked him if he was hurt; his reply was. "I am killed" Witness called to Col. SHUTT, whom he recognized, standing on the rear platform of the train, to stop the cars, that there were murderers on board. The others of the party snatched up missiles to and after the receding train; witness assisted to raise Mr. DAVIS; saw the wound in his left shoulder, and that he was dead, and placing the body in the hands of the police, who came up at the moment hastened to town to carry the terrible news to Mr. DAVIS' partners and friends.

abstract: A meeting was held at the Astor House, yesterday, for the purpose of organizing a Home Guard, Hon. CHAUNCEY SHAFFER in the chair.
lead_paragraph: A meeting was held at the Astor House, yesterday, for the purpose of organizing a Home Guard, Hon. CHAUNCEY SHAFFER in the chair. It is proposed that 20,000 men be enrolled for this guard, 10,000 whom will be armed with the Minie rifle. Many of our most influential business men have already enrolled their names in this corps, and it is expected that the majority of our leading merchants will become members of the Metropolitan Home Guard. Mr. GEORGE LAW was present and was offered the command of the Legion, but declined, stating that his sympathies were with the movement, but that his many engagements would not allow him to accept the honor. He was then offered the chairmanship of the Association, which he refused on the same grounds. Finally he was elected a member of the Committee for the further and better organization of this movement. Mr. LAW also said that he would assist the movement with all his might, and that his aid would be given just as freely, and to as great an extent, as though he were at the head of the organization.

abstract: In view of possible danger to vessels in the West India trade from attack by piratical cruisers equipped by the Southern Confederates, all the Murine Insurance Companies of this City, have, within a few days, decided upon an advance of one per cent. upon the ordinary rates. Captains of merchantmen are generally excited at the prospect of having to defend the property confided to them, and go to sea, in the majority of instances, well prepared for a stout resistance in case of a chance encounter with the men of the "black flag, raw head and bloody bones." We are cognizant of several instances wherein owners of "American bottoms" have deemed it policy to hoist the British flag upon their vessels until the present troubles are over. The transfer of the vessel from the American to the British flag is very easily accomplished. All the American owner has to do is to find a nominal purchaser for his vessel, and a dollar paid is sufficient to make the sale lawful. The purchaser applies to the British Consul for a British charter, which that official furnishes, and the vessel may sail under colors which Southern pirates will not dare to insult. The merchants who have adopted this ruse are engaged in supplying the West India Islands with cattle, and a prize of fat beef would be especially valuable to a people whose madness in time will probably bring them to starvation.

abstract: Mr. T. RAWLINGS, formerly of this City, but lately of Baltimore, arrived in Philadelphia yesterday morning. He was taking a compulsory journey with his family northward. It seems that Mr. RAWLINGS was suspected of favoring the Administration from the fact that he had been an applicant for the Consulship at Southampton. After the late outbreak in Baltimore he received several anonymous letters warning him to leave the city, the alternative offered being death. On applying to the Mayor for protection he was informed that he was in no danger, that the police would protect him. He was admonished, how ever, by sundry demonstrations made towards other parties, which elicited no protective interference on the part of the police, that safety could only be secured by complying with the suggestions of his anonymous friends.

abstract: This is a sublime spectacle upon which our country and the world are now gazing. Deplorable as is this rebellion, it has solved the disputed question, that the people of this Republic are competent for self-government; that we can not only administer our affairs in peace, and bring foreign wars to a successful conclusion but that we are able also to perform the far more difficult task of suppressing rebellion within our limits. [Loud cheers].
lead_paragraph: This is a sublime spectacle upon which our country and the world are now gazing. Deplorable as is this rebellion, it has solved the disputed question, that the people of this Republic are competent for self-government; that we can not only administer our affairs in peace, and bring foreign wars to a successful conclusion but that we are able also to perform the far more difficult task of suppressing rebellion within our limits. [Loud cheers]. On this question we seen united people from the southern boundary of my native State of Pennsylvania, to the lanes of the North, and within these latitudes, from the Atlantic to the Pacific. [Loud cheers.]

abstract: The last five or six days in New-York City and New-York State show where we are lacking, and likely to be. Not in the People. But those in power our Governors, State Major-Generals and Generals, the high inilitiaofficers generally, the Mayors, Common Councils, and a pretty long list beside.
lead_paragraph: The last five or six days in New-York City and New-York State show where we are lacking, and likely to be. Not in the People. But those in power our Governors, State Major-Generals and Generals, the high inilitiaofficers generally, the Mayors, Common Councils, and a pretty long list beside. The great directing officers of New-York, both civil and military, are, so far, miserably unfit for the duties of the times. Perhaps it is not to be wondered at. They gained, or were put in their positions, with reference to other sets of circumstances -- the circumstances of peace, peaceful contests, political parties, dress parades, personal supremacy, &c. There are too many old fogies among them. And as to political parties, we have all, as in the twinkling of an eye, passed beyond them, and almost forgotten their names.

abstract: We publish this morning a Discourse delivered by WENDELL PHILLIPS a week ago to-day, in Boston, on the great Rebellion. A fortnight previous he made a speech deprecating, in the most emphatic manner, any appeal to arms, as certain to result in the renewed and per-...
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a Discourse delivered by WENDELL PHILLIPS a week ago to-day, in Boston, on the great Rebellion. A fortnight previous he made a speech deprecating, in the most emphatic manner, any appeal to arms, as certain to result in the renewed and permanent triumph of Slavery. The people of the North, he said, would not fight, and the first insult of a military demonstration would be the complete surrender of the North, and the concession of everything that might be demanded at their hands.

abstract: The steamship Ariel, Capt. WILSON, arrived Friday night from Fort Monroe, which place she left on the 25th inst., at 7:30 P.M. Several prizes had been taken
lead_paragraph: The steamship Ariel, Capt. WILSON, arrived Friday night from Fort Monroe, which place she left on the 25th inst., at 7:30 P.M. Several prizes had been taken at Fort Monroe, one of them a schooner, loaded with artillery and ammunition; the other a propeller steam-tug, which was towing the schooner from under the guns of the Cumberland frigate. The Capt. of the schooner was supposed to be the commander of the Revenue Cutter surrendered to the Southern Confederacy some time since. He was to be tried by Court-martial the next day, and would, undoubtedly, be sentenced to be shot or hung. Supplies had been cut off from the Fort by the people living near, and all the lights in the Capes and Chesapeake Bay had been extinguished with the exception of Willewby Light Ship which is lighted by the crew of the U.S. ship Cumberland, and this had been put out several times by the people from the shore after it had been lighted by the crew of the frigate. On the 25th inst., a guard was detailed from the frigate to prevent similar proceedings.
headline: {'main': 'ARRIVAL OF THE ARIEL.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'ARRIVAL OF THE ARIEL.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington are of the most important and gratifying character. Telegraphic communication has at last been reestablished, and we are enabled to give, from our special correspondent, a reliable account of affairs there.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Washington are of the most important and gratifying character. Telegraphic communication has at last been reestablished, and we are enabled to give, from our special correspondent, a reliable account of affairs there. The number of troops now at the Capital cannot number less than 20,000. 13,000 were there on Friday night, and yesterday 8,000 men were on the road from Annapolis, and must ere this have reached there. This condition of affairs is having a calming effect upon the Secessionists on each side, in Virginia and Maryland, which has exhibited itself in assurances from the former that no attack upon the Capital from her soil would be permitted. This assurance comes both from Can. HARPER commanding the Virginia forces at Harper's Ferry, and from Gov, LETCHER himself. Probably by the time a few more thousand more troops arrive in Washington, it will be made to appear that no attack was ever intended.

abstract: It is due to our unfortunate city, as well as to the State of Maryland, that an explanation should be given in relation to the events of Friday, the 19th of April, that occasioned the mingling of the blood of our citizens with that of citizens of Massachusetts upon our soil.
lead_paragraph: It is due to our unfortunate city, as well as to the State of Maryland, that an explanation should be given in relation to the events of Friday, the 19th of April, that occasioned the mingling of the blood of our citizens with that of citizens of Massachusetts upon our soil. As a city, Baltimore was not guilty of the deed, and it is not just that she should be charged will it. On Thursday, the 18th, the passage of some of the unarmed troops from Pennsylvania over our streets, on their way to Washington, attracted a very large crowd of spectators, who followed them with shouts and sneers of derision to the Camden station. The Police, however, prevented any attack on them. From this circumstance it became apparent on Friday morning that there was a disposition to interrupt the passage of the troops from Massachusetts through the city, which were expected by the Philadelphia road, the parties in the purpose doubtless imagining that they were composed of the same sort of material that had attracted the crowd of Thursday.

abstract: From an officer of the Second Cavalry, which arrived in the City yesterday from Texas by the Empire City, we have obtained some interesting fants relative to the attempts made by tre rebel leaders in Texas, to seduce the Federal troops from their loyalty.
lead_paragraph: From an officer of the Second Cavalry, which arrived in the City yesterday from Texas by the Empire City, we have obtained some interesting fants relative to the attempts made by tre rebel leaders in Texas, to seduce the Federal troops from their loyalty. When Maj. VAN DORN, of Mississippi, who commanded the Second Cavalry, resigned, and returned to New-Orleans, he made his boasts that the would bring the entire regiment of the Second Cavalry in of he service of the Secessionists, and recently he made his appearance in Texas to carry out his purpose, but he met with a signal failure. The officers, to a man, refused to accompany him, though each was offered a promotion. His disgust was so great that he left without making efforts to effect his purpose.

abstract: Exceedingly rich gold mines have lately been discovered in the the department of Chontales in this State, and great numbers of persons have gone thither. During the past week, in this state alone, over six hundred ounces have been sold. It is calculated that the mines are very extensive, reaching through the entire mountain range of Chontales and Legonia. The gold is, on an average, from 16 to 18 carats fire.

abstract: papers that the occupation of Cairo, Ill., by one thousand troops, was ordered by Gov. YATES. The troops are of the Illinois State Militia. A battery has been planted on the levee at the Point, commanding both the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers. The Mayor of Cairo protested against the presence of the troops, and many of the citizens, who sympathize with the Secessionists, were indignant. About two hundred of the troops were stationed along the Illinois Central Railroad above the town, where the pile-work and bridge cross Cache Creek, to prevent the same from being burnt. Every part of Illinois except Cairo is loyal.

abstract: A mass meeting of the citizens of Staten Island was held at Tompkinsville, yesterday afternoon, at which speeches were made by several prominent citizens, and the greatest enthusiasm was manifested. abstract: The Persia was delayed until Thursday morn- to afford time for the messenger of the British Minister, at Washington, to arrive with dispatches. As he did not arrive, and as there was no intelligence of his being on the way, the British Consul decided not to detain the steamer any longer. Mr. ARCHIBALD, however, sent out full details of all matters which have transpired since the sailing of the previous steamer, including the President's proclamation decreeing a blockade of all the Southern ports. The English Government, therefore, will be fully apprised of everything of importance touching the interests of the two countries.

abstract: The world is witnessing a new revelation; Northern men are developing the ardor of the tropics. The attack upon the flag of the nation -- the fall of Sumter, and the audacious barbarism which has evoked and is conducting a war against the Federal Government -- which has struck a blow at Constitutional liberty, and by that blow has made an assault upon the rights of man, and the integrity of nations throughout the world, has thrilled the electric nerve which unites man with man, and startled the slumbering misses into one common life, and one common purpose.

abstract: Over a dozen American flags were raised in Baltimore en Friday. The Chief of Police has ordered all flags to be taken down during the session of the General Assembly here. In some instances there was refusal to obey, and arrests were made. The Police in some cases refused to take down the flags where the people would not. abstract: The Harbor Police, on Saturday afternoon, seized six sloops in the harbor, laden with powder, which it was supposed, was intended for the use of Secessionists. The United States Marshal is making inquiries. On the same day, Capt. SQUIRES, of the Fifteenth Ward Police, seized several pairs of military pantaloons at the shop of a tailor in Ridge-street, who was recently in the employ of NEWBECK & Co., No. 4 Dey-street, where 1,000 uniforms intended for the South, were recently seized. The tailor in Ridge-street could not be found.

abstract: We have referred more than once to the recent speech of Mr. A.H. STEPHENS, claiming to be the Vice-President of a Southern Confederacy, because Mr. STEPHENS is supposed to represent a large portion of the brains of the rebel Government, and because he may, therefore, be esteemed a fair exponent of its plans and policy. He is a good de
lead_paragraph: We have referred more than once to the recent speech of Mr. A.H. STEPHENS, claiming to be the Vice-President of a Southern Confederacy, because Mr. STEPHENS is supposed to represent a large portion of the brains of the rebel Government, and because he may, therefore, be esteemed a fair exponent of its plans and policy. He is a good debater, a popular orator, and has enjoyed the reputation of a statesman. It is interesting, therefore, to know in what manner he explains the philosophy of secession, and reconciles the doctrine in any degree with the idea of organized and practical Government. At first blush, nothing could seem more preposterous than a Government providing for its own disintegration, by giving free license to its members to sever from the body politic at pleasure. By what ingenious device -- by what instrumentality or absence of all instrumentality -- this process may be accomplished, Mr. STEPHENS explains in his speech, at Richmond, in a manner that could have been entirely satisfactory only to an audience drunk with bad enthusiasm and worse whisky.

abstract: There is, without doubt, a wide difference between the ideas and purposes of the Administration and those of the people, which should be reconciled with the least possible delay. Without wishing to trespass in any degree upon the legitimate functions of Government, we take it that where the aims and wishes of the people are unmistakably expressed, they should become the law of the Government.
lead_paragraph: There is, without doubt, a wide difference between the ideas and purposes of the Administration and those of the people, which should be reconciled with the least possible delay. Without wishing to trespass in any degree upon the legitimate functions of Government, we take it that where the aims and wishes of the people are unmistakably expressed, they should become the law of the Government. In me present instance, we believe, the people have the most correct idea of the true nature and significance of the contest. They see a succession of outrages, one following fast upon the heels of the other, all perpetrated by the same spirit, and directed to the same end -- the subversion of all law, the destruction of all our material interests, and finally the subjugation of ourselves to the worst of all forms of despotism. The seizure of nearly every fort in the South; of the Navy-yard at Pensacola; of the Mint at New-Orleans; the attack upon Fort Sumter; the treason of TWIGGS; the burning of the Navy-yard at Norfolk and the Arsenal at Harper's Ferry, to prevent their seizure by the enemy; and, finally, the threatened attack upon Washington, mean, to the unsophisticated, a war upon law, order, and upon property, which, unless met and defeated, will cost us our civilization and our liberty.

abstract: The United States frigate Constitution, from Annapolis, arrived last night, in tow of the screwsteamer Constitution, bringing 151 midshipmen from the Naval Academy, and 25 seamen. Sailed on Friday A.M. Has had strong southerly winds to the bar.
lead_paragraph: The United States frigate Constitution, from Annapolis, arrived last night, in tow of the screwsteamer Constitution, bringing 151 midshipmen from the Naval Academy, and 25 seamen. Sailed on Friday A.M. Has had strong southerly winds to the bar. After the secession of Virginia, the demonstrations of the Secessionists became so apparent that it was deemed of the greatest importance to get her out over the bar. Her crew of 25 men and officers had been at their quarters with shotted guns night and day for four days. Troops were drilling on the shore; signals between them were constantly made; large parties were around the ship to find out her assailable point. She had four anchors and seven chains out, when the order came at 7 A.M. to get her over the bar. The steamer Maryland, in Gen. BUTLER's charge, came alongside, one anchor was hove up, for use, all the other chains were slipped, and the ship started at 9 A.M., drawing 20 1/2 feet. There was then but 19 feet on the bar, and for some time it was doubtful if she would go, but by great exertion -- by lighting and careening her, she was forced over. The captain, pilot and engineers of the Maryland, which had been seized by Gen. BUTLER, were very averse to do their duty, and it was only by putting them under a guard with revolvers, that they would proceed with the vessel. After dragging her over the bar, the vessel grounded on the outer spit. About 10 P.M., information having been brought off shortly after that the channel outside the ship would be obstructed, kedges were laid out, and it was endeavored to warp the ship over the spit, part of the men being at the guns. The Maryland having been run aground by her officers during the warping, a squall came up and drove the ship ashore again. At daylight a steam tug from Havre de Grace came in sight and was taken to tow the ship out. She was then taken in tow by the R.R. Cuyler and brought to this port.

abstract: In consequence of the non-arrival of arms and uniforms, this Regiment did not parade yesterday to receive the stand of colors prepared for them by Mrs. ASTOR. Having been favored with a private view of this magnificent testimonial to gallant men, we append a brief description of them: The regimental flag
lead_paragraph: In consequence of the non-arrival of arms and uniforms, this Regiment did not parade yesterday to receive the stand of colors prepared for them by Mrs. ASTOR. Having been favored with a private view of this magnificent testimonial to gallant men, we append a brief description of them: The regimental flag is about 6 by 10 feet, of rich crimson satin, lined with heavy white satin, with yellow silk fringes and tassels. On it are embroidered in white silk the words, "U.S. National Guards, First Regiment Zouaves, New-York." The staff is of black oak, mounted with a silver spear-head. The other is an American flag of heavy white, red and blue silk, with the 34 stars sewed on the blue ground. The staff is also of black oak but is mounted by a silver eagle.

lead_paragraph: Military preparations were actively carried on yesterday in the churches, barracks, and elsewhere. Business at the clothing depot, No. 166 Fulton-street, of which Judge ADAMS has charge, was particularly active. The clothing for the detachmeat of the Thirteenth Regiment (left behind) was given out, and also the clothing and accoutrements of the Twenty-eighth and Fourteenth Regiments. Aldermen DAYTON, SCHOLES and VAN BRUNT, of the Common Council Committee, were at the depot up to 1 o'clock yesterday morning, attending to their arduous duties.

abstract: When the Fool-killer goes his rounds, we have a special favor to ask of him. We beg him to deal gently with our neighbors of the World. Appearances are against them;
lead_paragraph: When the Fool-killer goes his rounds, we have a special favor to ask of him. We beg him to deal gently with our neighbors of the World. Appearances are against them; but they are not such hopeless idiots as their recent senseless gabble would indicate. The fact is, they have an object to accomplish, and have become somewhat desperate and reckless in their endeavors to reach it. They began life under the delusion that they had a character to sustain -- and the hopeless effort to sustain it cost them a good deal of trouble, and other people a good deal of money. They have abandoned the undertaking in despair -- and their only concern now is, to prolong their precarious and unprofitable existence by whatever shifts their limited ingenuity can devise. Something must be pardoned to a journal which began by trading on its affectation of religious principle. It is naturally compelled to resort to lying for a livelihood.

abstract: Dr. FRANK H. HAMILTON delivered, on Saturday, the second lecture of his course on Military Surgery, to a large number of physicians, surgeons and medical students. After describing a number of disqualification...
lead_paragraph: Dr. FRANK H. HAMILTON delivered, on Saturday, the second lecture of his course on Military Surgery, to a large number of physicians, surgeons and medical students. After describing a number of disqualification for active service, with the reasons for inefficiency in each case, the lecturer stated that from 25 to 50 per cent. of those persons who usually offer themselves as recruits ought to be rejected. An army, to be of use, ought to be composed of picked men. Hence a grave responsibility rested on the medical examiner. For the consequence of want of care and sound judgment on his part, would be to crowd prematurely the ambulances or army hospitals, to overwhelm with labor the Regimental Surgeons, and seriously to impair the effectiveness of the army in the field. Among the disabilities mentioned were hernia, strabismus, loss or maiming of certain fingers, and various injuries of the knee or foot. In regard to the effects of wounds, many interesting facts and principles were stated. Thus, while injury of the knee-joint often caused the loss of the limb, a dislocation of the thigh frequently left the man able to march as well as before. This was sometimes the case even where there was a shortening of the limb. The test was, did the man limp? It was not enough to measure the length of the two limbs. For it was notorious that while some men would limp if a leg was shortened half an inch, it required 1 1/2 inches shortening to produce limping in others. The difference probably arose in part from the ability conferred by nature on certain persons of lowering the pelvis and exercising more perfect control for the coordination of the parts, so as to compensate for the deficiency in the length of the leg; while this faculty of adaptation was not enjoyed to the same extent by others. The custom of the Indians was to turn their toes inward while walking, as experience had taught these children of Nature that swiftness and endurance in war or in hunting were thus obtained with the least expenditure of muscular force. Experience showed that those persons who were splay-footed were unable to walk long distances or to endure forced marches. It was also remarked that those who had the foot well arched, walked better than flat-footed persons; and that while by nature, the two arches of the foot were defective in some persons, there were habits, such for instance as that of dancing, which had a tendency to injure both these arches, and to impair the walking power of men to whom nature has given a well shaped foot. Many other interesting facts were pointed out and illustrated in an extremely lucid and felicitous manner. At the close of the lecture, specimens of shot and shell were exhibited, which had been supplied by Dr. GANESVOORT, of the United States Navy; also, various sedans for carrying the wounded from the field. A miniature model was also shown, of a temporary tent, which could be reared in a few moments, by the union of four knapsacks. Although the sun-shades thus extemporized, were black, and thus absorbed the rays of heat, still, as they were open at the ends, it was stated that they did not become so hot as might have been expected. On the contrary, they had been found, in practice, to afford a refreshing and grateful protection, even under a tropical sun.

lead_paragraph: Already we hear of the returning reason of Maryland and Virginia. God grant that their repentance may not prove another ruse to satisfy timid patriotism to disarm suspicion, if not soldiers to gain time, position and victory. abstract: The First Regiment of Advance Guards, Col. ABRAM DURYEA, are reported to be getting along comfortably at their new quarters at Fort Schuyler. They are progressing very rapidly in their drill and are in an excellent state of discipline. The officers state that they are under obligations to the public for the prompt manner in which they have come forward with the necessary supplies for the regiment. They are amply provided for, and are anxiously waiting for marching orders. About 100 more men of unquestioned qualifications will be received to make the fall regiment.

abstract: On Thursday night a presentation meeting was held at the Welsh Presbyterian Church, Thirteenthstreet, for the purpose of presenting an address, and a purse of $500, to the worthy Pastor, Rev. W. ROBERTS, in consideration of his indefatigable exertions in collecting funds for the removal of the debt on the Church. W. MILES, Esq., was called to preside.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night a presentation meeting was held at the Welsh Presbyterian Church, Thirteenthstreet, for the purpose of presenting an address, and a purse of $500, to the worthy Pastor, Rev. W. ROBERTS, in consideration of his indefatigable exertions in collecting funds for the removal of the debt on the Church. W. MILES, Esq., was called to preside. He made some beautiful and pithy remarks in reference to the Pastor's noble efforts to sweep off the debt on the Church, and hoped he would also raise his voice in order to stir up the honest and loyal hearts of his countrymen for the vindication of the honor of that flag, (pointing to the Star Spangled Banner extended over the singers' gallery.) After some appropriate remarks from Rev. A.D. SMITH, D.D., the address was read and purse presented. In course of the Pastor's response, he referred in very eloquent terms to the present important and all-absorbing crisis on the country. He liked the American character, admired the American institutions, loved the Government of the United States, and honored the Star Spangled Banner of the Union. He said that silence now was a crime. He was conscious of the sacredness of the place they met. He felt he was in the immediate presence of the Great Arbiter of all human affairs; that he would take his stand by the sacred altar of his sanctuary-place, his hand on his Divinely-inspired Book, and most solemnly swear unflinching allegiance to the Union, Constitution and flag of the United States. (Tremendous cheers.] Rev. J.M. KREBS, D.D., in closing his remarks, said he was glad to find symptoms of true loyalty in the honest Welsh people to the flag of the Union. The flag, he said, was the coat of arms of WASHINGTON -- our land is the land of WASHINGTON, and our Church is the Church of WASHINGTON; for he was a Christian. [Immense applause.] He would now appeal to his Welsh brethren, whether they would defend that flag at the hazard of their life. "Ah!" said he, "it is a thousand shames that men who had been bred and born under the protection of the flag should precipitately insult it, while adopted citizens are willing and ready to lay down their life in its defence. Rev. R. LITTLER and Mr. R. ROGERS took part in the proceedings, and the choir, conducted by E. DAVIES, Esq., added greatly to the interest of the meeting. It was concluded by singing the "Star Spangled Banner," the whole congregation standing and joining in the chorus, while the Stars and Stripes were waved in a masterly style over the gallery. The benediction being pronounced by Dr. KREBS, the congregation departed.

abstract: Our advices from Washington this morning are interesting and important. The city is without doubt secure from any attack indeed we hear no more of any intention to attack it. On the contrary, we have repeated assurances from Virginia that no invasion of the Capital would ever be permitted from her soil. Not withstanding these assur
lead_paragraph: Our advices from Washington this morning are interesting and important. The city is without doubt secure from any attack indeed we hear no more of any intention to attack it. On the contrary, we have repeated assurances from Virginia that no invasion of the Capital would ever be permitted from her soil. Not withstanding these assurances, however, it is not the intention of the Government to desist from its preparations for any emergency which may be precipitated upon it by the Secessionists, but under the direction of the veteran Gen. SCOTT everything is being put in the most complete order. Our dispatches give interesting accounts of the manner in which the Sabbath was spent by the troops at the capital. Divine services were had in several of the regiments. Nothing is heard of the movements of the Secessionist forces in Virginia; but from a report which reaches us by a vessel which arrived here yesterday, we think it probable that something of a secession character has been going on in the vicinity of Fort Monroe. The Captain of the vessel states that he heard cannonading on Friday in the direction of Old Point Comfort, and that it continued the entire afternoon.

abstract: Thousands of citizens were disappointed yesterday at the non-departure of Col. ELLSWORTH's Fire Brigade. The streets were crowded with men, women and children, anxious to witness the first parade in their new uniforms. The muskets, however, were not forthcoming, and the expected escort of firemen did not make their appearance. Should the arms arrive, the regiment will leave to-day, receiving en route a present of a stand of colors from the ladies of the Astor House and Mrs. JOHN JACOB ASTOR, of Thirty-third-street. The demonstration will be imposing. But it is useless to conceal the fact that great dissatisfaction exists among our gallant volunteer firemen, that no arms have been furnished them. They will never desert -- no fireman would do that -- but they declare they will not go on till they have something better than their bare fists to fight with.

abstract: Our brave German citizens are about to organize another regiment of rifles. Most of those who have already joined have seen active service in Baden, Schleswig, Holstein, and the Crimea. Their head-quarters are at Palace Garden. As many of the men are without means, subscriptions sent thither will be very desirable.
lead_paragraph: Our brave German citizens are about to organize another regiment of rifles. Most of those who have already joined have seen active service in Baden, Schleswig, Holstein, and the Crimea. Their head-quarters are at Palace Garden. As many of the men are without means, subscriptions sent thither will be very desirable.

abstract: A matronly lady, accompanied by her son, a fine youth of about nineteen years, entered a gun store on Broadway, on Saturday, and purchased a full outfit for him. Selecting the best weapons and other articles for a soldier's use, that could be found in the store, she paid the bill, remarking, with evident emotion, "This, my son, is all that I can do. I have given you up to serve your country, and may God go with you -- it is all a mother can do." The incident attracted considerable attention, and tearful eves followed this patriotic mother and her son, as they departed from the place.

abstract: Capt. TABER, of the ship Samuel Robertson, which arrived at this port yesterday, reports that it was generally believed that commissions for privateers were preparing, and would be issued at the first convening of the Southern Congress on the 29th inst. It was
lead_paragraph: Capt. TABER, of the ship Samuel Robertson, which arrived at this port yesterday, reports that it was generally believed that commissions for privateers were preparing, and would be issued at the first convening of the Southern Congress on the 29th inst. It was well known that three vessels, at least, are prepared, and are now only waiting at Savannah for the letters of marque and reprisal promised them by the President of the Southern Confederacy. They were expecting them in a few days. These parties are said to have their bonds ready and handed in. Capt. T. says Northern shipping on this coast must be on the alert, as skillful seamen are waiting to take command of these piratical craft, and that among them will be found some rebel Yankees. Excitement was never greater than it is now. Recruits were pouring in from the back counties, ready, as they say, to sacrifice their lives in the cause of the South. For three days before the sailing of Capt. TABER, companies were preparing to join their army in the Border States for the overthrow of the Federal Capital. What few Union men there are remaining are overawed, and there was but one cry. "Down with the Lincoln Administration, and death to all who shall attempt in any way to support it."

abstract: On the passage home in the Baltic, arrived last week, our reporter had the good fortune to fall in with a member of the Seventh Regiment, National Guards, who was with the regiment on the march from Annapolis, and who uses sent home invalided in consequence of a sun-stroke, which rendered the present performance of duty impossible.
lead_paragraph: On the passage home in the Baltic, arrived last week, our reporter had the good fortune to fall in with a member of the Seventh Regiment, National Guards, who was with the regiment on the march from Annapolis, and who uses sent home invalided in consequence of a sun-stroke, which rendered the present performance of duty impossible. From him, -- and he is a very intelligent gentleman, clerk in one of the largest houses in the City, -- much interesting intelligence was obtained, which we hasten to lay before our raders.

abstract: The apparent inaction of the Administration is accounted for in some quarters, on the supposition that Mr. LINCOLN desires the authority of Congress, at its extra session, for decided military measures.
lead_paragraph: The apparent inaction of the Administration is accounted for in some quarters, on the supposition that Mr. LINCOLN desires the authority of Congress, at its extra session, for decided military measures. The fact that the troops now in Washington have been mustered for a term which will expire about the period fixed for the meeting of Congress seems to lend color to this conjecture; and it acquires additional probability from the determination of the Government to restrict itself for the present to the protection of the Capital.

abstract: Great floods have taken place in this island, causing calamities only interior to those in Holland. Hundreds have lost their lives, and many thousands have been ruined. Several villages have been completely submerged. The destruction of horses, crops, stores, roads, , have been such that many millions will not compensate for it. The Government has sent 800,000 florins for the relief of the sufferers. The commercial community of Batavia has already subscribed 150,000 florins.

abstract: The schooner B.D. Pitts, Capt. CARSON, from Charleston, arrived yesterday at this port, with 21 passengers, among whom were the crew of the steamship Nashville. An Irishman, named JOHN TRACY, was also on board, with his wife and five children. He was possessor of a small farm of twenty acres, well stocked, which was confiscated by the South Carolina authorities, for his refusal to fight against the flag he had sworn to protect. He was seized and tied up to a fence, with his hands fastened ever his head. In this position 500 lashes were given him. His wife was kicked, beaten, and otherwise brutally ill-treated. Mr. TRACY fought in the Mexican war under Gen. HALL. As he is entirely destitute, Capt. CARSON kindly allows him to remain for a few days on board the schooner B.D. Pitts, at Pier No. 10 North River. His back presents a fearful appearance.
lead_paragraph: The schooner B.D. Pitts, Capt. CARSON, from Charleston, arrived yesterday at this port, with 21 passengers, among whom were the crew of the steamship Nashville. abstract: Within two weeks time from to-day we shall have a new phase of the secession question, of deep interest to the Federal Government and to the State of Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Within two weeks time from to-day we shall have a new phase of the secession question, of deep interest to the Federal Government and to the State of Virginia. A very large meeting was held at the Court-house in Harrison County, Northwestern Virginia, on the 22d inst. The number present was from one thousand to twelve hundred -- all good and lawful citizens, not only of Virginia, but of the United Stales. The meeting adopted with entire unanimity -- not one dissenting voice being heard -- a set of resolutions utterly condemning and repudiating the action of the Virginia State Convention in passing a Secession Ordinance. They denounce Gov. LETCHER for issuing a proclamation calling on the volunteer soldiery of the State to hold themselves in readiness to make war upon the Federal Government. They denounce the glaring inconsistency of the Convention's passing an ordinance of secession which is to be voted for by the people before it is valid, and in advance of its ratification by the people, committing acts of violence against the Federal Government by obstructing rivers, seizing Custom Houses, and marching upon the National Armory at Harper's Ferry. They pronounce that Northwestern Virginia is separated by natural barriers from the rest of the State, which precludes all hope, if they were assailed, that they should receive succor from other portions of the State; and therefore they declare that they should look to their own safety in the present fearful emergency.
headline: {'main': 'A New Duty of the Government--Virginia Not Lost.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A New Duty of the Government--Virginia Not Lost.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Administration, it will be seen from our dispatches this morning, has decided upon a policy which will be likely to impress our secession friends with the idea that they have undertaken a hard task.
lead_paragraph: The Administration, it will be seen from our dispatches this morning, has decided upon a policy which will be likely to impress our secession friends with the idea that they have undertaken a hard task. Troops in addition to those already called for, will be immediately required -- swelling the whole number to one hundred and fifty-eight thousand men, as follows: 75,000 militia already called for; 40,000 to be called for for three years' service; 25,000 regulars for five years' service, and 18,000 seamen for the same period. Even this large number falls short of the actual offerings of troops already made.

abstract: The public mind has been so stunned by a succession of public dishonors and disasters, that it can hardly comprehend them as they come along. A little time must elapse before...
lead_paragraph: The public mind has been so stunned by a succession of public dishonors and disasters, that it can hardly comprehend them as they come along. A little time must elapse before the latest is appreciated -- and it may be so much time that it would seem we had forgotten how to be astonished at anything. But the European world will be amazed to learn of the recent catastrophe at Norfolk; and posterity will marvel over it and mourn over it, more than over the treason of TWIGGS, or the fate of Fort Sumter.

abstract: The Twenty-eighth Regiment, Col. BENNETT, paraded yesterday with about 600 men, and were reviewed by the City authorities in the City Hall Square. Patriotic speeches were made to the command by Gen. CROOK, Mayor POWELL, Mr. KALBFLEISCH, Mayor elect, and others. The Regiment will leave for the Seat of War at 9 o'clock this morning. They take a ferry-boat at the foot of Fulton-street, and proceed directly to the steamer in which they will take their departure.
